headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone and welcome to our First Quarter 2015 [ph] Earnings Conference Call. This is Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning. Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison,
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone and welcome to our First Quarter 2015 [ph] Earnings Conference Call. This is Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning. 
Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison, who will be phoning in from Italy; as well as David Bernstein, our Chief Financial Officer; and Beth Roberts, who heads up our Investor Relations, here in Miami. 
Before I begin, please note that some of our remarks on this call will be forward-looking. Therefore, I must refer you to the cautionary statement in today's press release. 
Our company is off to a strong start this year, with first quarter adjusted earnings nearly doubled the prior year and well above the high end of our December guidance range. The first quarter result combined with our strong book position has enabled us to increase the midpoint of our previous guidance range by $0.05 and raise the floor on our full year earnings expectations. 
I'm proud to acknowledge all of our employees globally for the industry-leading guest experience [indiscernible] that are central to our sustained earnings improvement. I especially thank our travel agent partners for the critical role they play in connecting guests with our great brand experience. 
It was reinforcing to see revenue yield growth of 5.7% in constant currency, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of mid-single-digit yield improvement. We enjoyed ticket price improvements for both our North American and our EAA brands, with particularly robust ticket price improvements in our core Caribbean itinerary which represents 47% of our first quarter [ph] deployment. We drove revenue yield growth at Costa by creating relative scarcity through our brand team success in increasing demand via our ongoing guest experience efforts, coupled with new impactful creative featuring Shakira. While at the same time, we reduced supply in the more challenging trading environment in Southern Europe by transferring Costa capacity to China. 
As you recall, our Costa brand was the first global cruise line to home port in China back in 2006. Today, we are the largest in China and the first global cruise company with 6 ships based there across 2 our brands, Costa and Princess, representing nearly half of the Chinese cruise industry. 
While it represents less than 5% of our global capacity, for us, China continues to be a promising unit growth opportunity. China has quickly become the world's largest outbound travel market at an estimated 135 million strong, yet just over 1 million cruise today. We expect to continue our growth over time and have further plans for AIDA and Carnival Cruise Lines to enter China in the near future. 
China contributed to our strong quarterly results. We have [indiscernible] over 60% more capacity there and enjoyed strong profit improvement and return on invested capital accretion. At the same time, the capacity shift to China help create relative scarcity in our other markets, supporting global revenue yield growth. 
Beyond China during the quarter, we made further progress globally in creating demand for all of our brands at excess of measured capacity growth. Part of that demand creation is the excitement around the much anticipated delivery of AIDAprima. And I can tell you, she is well worth the wait. The ship is absolutely fantastic. The first of the next generation platform for AIDA that combines leading-edge environmental attributes and well-designed features that foster an exceptional guest experience. 
All of our features, whether raising water flies, [indiscernible] multiple, climbing walls, an expensive German spa, an ice rink for skating, for hockey, for curling and even a traditional Christmas market, together, create an experience that truly resonates with [indiscernible] that is nearly exclusively German guests. 
And we have additional opportunity for demand creation just for few short days with the delivery of Holland America's new flagship, Koningsdam. Koningsdam was designed as Holland American guest in mind and reintroduce Holland America to those who have yet to experience our award winning service, our 5-star dining, our extensive enrichment program and compelling worldwide itineraries. 
Our new flagship will offer fine dining in several alternative restaurants, including a new French seafood [indiscernible] and a new immersive far in the table dinner experience in the Culinary Arts Center. 
Part of enhancing an already great Holland America experience includes taking onboard entertainment to a whole new level. We have carefully engineered a new [indiscernible] which showcases different genres offering chamber music in Lincoln Center Stage, rocking the crowd with [indiscernible] and instant billboard on board and bringing the best of Memphis music to see in our popular B.B. King's Blues Club. 
Responding to our guest, our new flagship will future Holland America Lines first ever purpose-built [indiscernible] for families as well as single stay bedrooms. 
Newbuilds will also provide additional demand creation opportunities later this year as well, with the delivery of Carnival Vista followed by Seabourn Encore. When it comes to shift, newbuild are not the only way to simulate demand creation. We continue to invest in our existing fleet to further enhance guest experiences including the recently recreation of Holland America's [indiscernible] incorporating many of the same experiences on board as Koningsdam. In addition, we are ongoing an extensive remastering of Q North, Queen Mary 2 later this year. 
Destination is also been a powerful tool for demand creation as well especially when combined with the attractive public relations. Last week, we made history when we became the first U.S. cruise operator in over 50 years to receive cumulative approval to bring U.S. cruise guests directly from the U.S. to Cuba. 
We made worldwide news, showcasing cruise on a very positive light, with nearly 5 billion media impressions [indiscernible]. We very much look forward to launching our historic Cuba inaugural seasonal [indiscernible] initially with itineraries including Havana, Cienfuegos and Santiago de Cuba. We believe there is no better way to experience so much of Cuba in 7 days than with the enriching guest experience in our premium fathom brand. 
As the Adonia just carries 700 guests per sailing, if you have any interest in seeing Cuba through an extraordinary family experience, I sincerely recommend you book now. 
Concerning the future of cruises in Cuba, we have already begun the process for approval for other brands for sail for Cuba in the months and years ahead. 
Now beyond ships and destinations, our ongoing marketing and promotional efforts are also part of demand creation. As part of our effort to keep cruise in the forefront of vacationers minds, [indiscernible] is airing a new reality-based show on prime time U.K. television entitled The Cruise. The documentary falls [indiscernible] with our early to guest on board Regal Princess through a 6 week series. In fact, we've already seen a 40% [ph] increase in web traffic for Princess in the U.K. since the show began airing. 
Also airing in the U.K., P&O Cruises Battleships, a new cookery concept [indiscernible] on board with [indiscernible], featuring 5 celebrities testing their culinary skills and judged by celebrity chef, Marco Pierre White. 
In Italy, Casa Fortunate will set up a major motion picture for [indiscernible], holidays in the Caribbean, launched early in the quarter, partially cast with Costa crew members. More recently, an episode on Italian reality TV, [indiscernible], the Colors of Love, was based on the love story between 2 young Costa crew members who met on board. 
In North America, just last week, Carnival Cruise Lines featured nightly on the [indiscernible] television show, [indiscernible] Fortune. While early in the quarter, Carnival announced an exceptional partnership with Grammy award-winning country music superstar, Carrie Underwood, and operation home front, supporting our U.S. Military personnel. Media coverage from that announcement alone generated more than 1 billion media impressions and our Carnival brand continues to outperform. 
Also in North America, we partnered with AT&T and Samsung to create a virtual reality experience that showcase in nearly 1,200 AT&T stores, promoting consideration for cruise by allowing new-to-cruise to virtually experience a cruise vacation. We estimate nearly 400,000 people have already have the virtually reality experience, showcasing our portfolio of leading brands. All of these efforts heighten global awareness and consideration for our [indiscernible] cruise line as we continue to capture a greater share of the vacation suitcase. 
During the quarter, we continue to make progress on cross brand efforts to leverage our scale. On the revenue side, work on our revenue yield optimizing system continues. And in summer of 2016, will be rolled out on 30% of our inventory. The prototype will [indiscernible] yield uplift as well as aspiring [indiscernible] for final system development. Since most of the shifts will [indiscernible] will be behind us by the summer, we look forward to a greater contribution on this effort in 2017. 
And on the cost side, work in our procurement area continues. We have negotiations underway on 16 separate purchasing categories, with 22 more RFPs outstanding. All of which will contribute to our outstated [ph] $75 million of expected cost savings in 2016. 
Our ongoing operational improvement is a testament of the success of our combined efforts to create demand in excess of measured capacity growth and to leverage our scale. The strong first quarter we have enjoyed affirms our conviction to deliver this year's earnings forecast and accelerates progress toward double-digit return on invested capital. We remain well on track for the delivery of over 8.5% return on invested capital this year and crossing the double-digit threshold in the next 2 to 3 years. At the same time, we have accelerated our return of capital to shareholders. Since resuming our stock repurchase program late last year, we have completed our first $1 million share repurchase authorization and are well into our second billion, bringing the cumulative total of purchase to date to $1.3 billion and approximately 27 million shares. We plan to continue to return free cash flow to shareholders with our strong balance sheet and leverage ratios now comfortably at the better end of our target range. 
And now, I will turn the call over to David.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arnold. Before I begin, please note all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 first quarter results. Then I'll provide som
componenttext:
Thank you, Arnold. Before I begin, please note all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. 
I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 first quarter results. Then I'll provide some insights on booking trends. And finish up with an update on our full year 2016 guidance. 
Our adjusted EPS for the first quarter was $0.39. This was $0.09 above the midpoint of our December guidance despite a $0.01 drag from foreign [ph] currency. The improvement was essentially driven by 2 things: $0.07 from net ticket revenue yields, which benefited from stronger pricing on close-in bookings on both sides of the Atlantic; and $0.03 from lower net cruise costs excluding fuel as a result of timing of certain expenses between the quarter. 
Now let's turn to the first quarter operating results versus the prior year. Our capacity increased almost 4%. Our total net revenue yields were up 5.7%. 
Let's break apart the 2 components of net revenue yields. Net ticket yields were up almost 7%. As Arnold indicated, we enjoyed ticket price improvements on both sides of the Atlantic. The increase was driven by the strength in pricing in the Caribbean, which represented 47% of our capacity in the quarter. In addition, our European, Australian and Asian brands also known as our EAA brands, saw solid price improvements on their year-round European program. 
Onboard and other yields increased almost 3%, in line with December guidance. The increase was mainly related to bar, casino and communications as our efforts in these areas continued to pay dividends. Net cruise costs per ALBD excluding fuel, were up about 1.5%, which was less than planned in our December guidance, again due to the timing of expenses between the quarters. 
In summary, first quarter adjusted EPS was $0.19 higher than the prior year, driven by operational improvements worth $0.15 and favorable net impact of lower fuel prices and currency worth $0.03. 
Now let's turn to booking trends for 2016. Bookings during this year's wait season was strong, volumes are ahead of last year's historically high level at higher prices. At this point in time, for the remaining 3 quarters of 2016, cumulative fleet wide bookings are well ahead at slightly higher prices. The fact that we're well ahead on the book position, with less inventory left to sell for the remainder of the year compared to last year bodes well for pricing over the next few months. 
Now let's drill down into the cumulative fleet wide book position. First, for our North American brand. Caribbean occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at nicely higher prices. For Alaska, occupancy is in line with the prior year, also at nicely higher prices. 2015 was a great Alaskan season and I'm happy to say 2016 is shaping up to be even better. For the seasonal European program, occupancy is nicely ahead of the prior year at lower prices, driven by the geopolitical risk impacting the Mediterranean trade as anticipated in our guidance. 
Secondly, for our EAA brands, for Europe, occupancy is ahead of the prior year at slightly higher prices. Australia and Asia are consistent with our prior guidance. While we are behind on pricing, and not surprisingly behind on percentage occupancy, given our over 60% increase in China capacity and our significant increase in Australia capacity, remember, Asia and particularly China, is a unit growth opportunity and we are achieving strong unit profits and returns that exceed our corporate average. 
Finally, I want to provide you with an update on our full year 2016 guidance. As Arnold indicated, our first quarter results, combined with strong book position, enabled us to increase the midpoint of our previous guidance range by $0.05 and raised the floor on our earnings expectations for the year. Our 2016 March guidance is now $3.20 to $3.40. The $0.05 improvement was driven by improved [indiscernible] revenue yields worth $0.04 and the accretive impact from the additional shares we repurchased [indiscernible] our December call worth $0.05. These improvements were partially offset by a $0.04 drag from fuel and currency. 
Net cruise costs without fuel per ALBD are still expected to be up approximately 2%, no change from our December guidance. While we were favorable to the guidance for the first quarter, as I previously indicated, the favorability was due to the timing of expenses between the quarter. 
Remember that while the year is expected to be up approximately 2%, there are differences between the quarters. The first quarter was up about 1.5% while the guidance for the second quarter is expected to be up only 0.5% to 1.5%. However, for the first quarter, we expect net cruise costs without fuel per ALBD to be up 5% to 6%, driven by the remastering of Queen Mary 2 in dry dock and higher advertising expense. Offsetting that, however is the expectation that cost will be down slightly in the fourth quarter. 
So far this fiscal year, we have repurchased over 21 million of our shares and we still have almost $700 million left under the second $1 billion share repurchase authorization that was approved by the Board of Directors just 2 months ago. Our March guidance EPS calculation assumes approximately 760 million shares outstanding on a weighted average basis. 
On a final note, for your planning purposes, I wanted to let you know that we expect our June conference call to be a little later in June than usual to allow some extra time for quarter end reconciliation and analysis, given that we are currently in the process of implementing a significant upgrade to our Oracle Enterprise Recording Platform, which includes moving to a single instance of the general ledger as we further leverage our scale. 
And now I'll turn the call back over to Arnold.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Operator, please open it up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, David. Operator, please open it up for questions.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, first, can you just -- I think it was David, you just made some comments on China and I wanted to understand them. Are you saying that pricing is still higher in China than the rest of the world? You are adding capacity in Chin
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, first, can you just -- I think it was David, you just made some comments on China and I wanted to understand them. Are you saying that pricing is still higher in China than the rest of the world? You are adding capacity in China and that this is a unit growth story. I wanted to understand those 2 things. So to me, it sounds like almost you're simply adding more capacity at a higher price relative to the rest of the fleet but that the pricing maybe is not as high as it was maybe last year, is that what you're saying? And then one other thing on this China opportunity, which I think is outside the [indiscernible] because it's really is a huge opportunity and is a big pricing opportunity too is how were the travel agents doing in that market? Is there anything we can read from them and their reaction to the capacity that is coming on?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer that, this is Arnold. First of all, good morning and thanks for your questions. I'll answer the travel agent or what we call the, distributors in China question first. We don't have direct line of sight into their profitability. But what I can
componenttext: I'll answer that, this is Arnold. First of all, good morning and thanks for your questions. I'll answer the travel agent or what we call the, distributors in China question first. We don't have direct line of sight into their profitability. But what I can tell you is that our relationships are strong. They continue to book with us. Our actual occupancies on sailings are the same and we're seeing great results and we see no easing of interest or demand or anything from the distributors and the best line of sight we have since that the relationship is working for us and for them and it's definitely working for us. You had a question, I'll let David answer directly what you asked of him.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve. The yields are higher than the group average on the ticket prices. But that's not really our key metric. I mean, operating income per ALBD is really the key metric. And there are too, the yields are higher. So that is what we're looking at as
componenttext: Yes, Steve. The yields are higher than the group average on the ticket prices. But that's not really our key metric. I mean, operating income per ALBD is really the key metric. And there are too, the yields are higher. So that is what we're looking at as a metric in terms of overall for China. But one other thing I will add, keep in mind is since last -- mid last year, the renminbi has also devalued by 7%. So when you're looking at an apples-to-apples comparison on a current dollar basis, that does affect the overall ticket yields and the overall yields for our China business.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, David, the main point is, China is a very positive story for us. It's strong, it's a contributor. It only represents 5% of our capacity today. So we are well-positioned from that regard as well. But it's definitely a nice add and we certainly hav
componenttext: I think, David, the main point is, China is a very positive story for us. It's strong, it's a contributor. It only represents 5% of our capacity today. So we are well-positioned from that regard as well. But it's definitely a nice add and we certainly have benefited from it and we see continued strength.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let's not forget the benefit that we see in the rest of the world as a result of the growth in China and the more measured capacity growth in the established markets, which is 95% of our business.
componenttext: And let's not forget the benefit that we see in the rest of the world as a result of the growth in China and the more measured capacity growth in the established markets, which is 95% of our business.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 questions. One is, I'm just curious, there's no change in your full year yield guidance. But Q1 obviously came in quite a bit stronger. So that sort of implies that your next 3 quarters guidance are lower from what you thought it was, which I think is n
componenttext: 2 questions. One is, I'm just curious, there's no change in your full year yield guidance. But Q1 obviously came in quite a bit stronger. So that sort of implies that your next 3 quarters guidance are lower from what you thought it was, which I think is not the case and you're probably just being conservative. So I wonder if you could, if there's anything that I would think that the strength of the close-in bookings in Q1 would lead you to feel better about the next 3 quarters. I guess I just wonder if you can sort of address that?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Robin, as I indicated in my comments, the first quarter revenue yield was worth $0.07 beat on the guidance. So $0.07, keep in mind, is 0.4 for us in total in terms of the full year yield. And when you take a look at it, our yield guidance for the ye
componenttext: Sure. Robin, as I indicated in my comments, the first quarter revenue yield was worth $0.07 beat on the guidance. So $0.07, keep in mind, is 0.4 for us in total in terms of the full year yield. And when you take a look at it, our yield guidance for the year was approximately 3%. So depending on where you are, if you are 0.2% below that, now you're 0.2% above that. So essentially, its still approximate 3% and the rest of the year didn't change.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so the strength of the closing does not change your view on the next 3 quarters?
componenttext: Okay. And so the strength of the closing does not change your view on the next 3 quarters?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we're going to strive to do better. But what we've experienced so far give us conviction to maintain our guidance and actually increase guidance by $0.05. And we feel very positive about our booking situation. So obviously, we're going to
componenttext: Well, obviously, we're going to strive to do better. But what we've experienced so far give us conviction to maintain our guidance and actually increase guidance by $0.05. And we feel very positive about our booking situation. So obviously, we're going to strive to do even better. But at this point, with all the dynamics around the rest of the world and the fact that the Caribbean, which is -- have been very strong for us, becomes a smaller percent of the total in the subsequent quarters. We think it's prudent that we stick to the guidance we've given.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. Thank you. And then my other question was just on China and you talked about the tremendous potential for unit growth there. Can you just put a little color around the Carnival brand originally was going to send the ship there for the
componenttext: Okay, that's great. Thank you. And then my other question was just on China and you talked about the tremendous potential for unit growth there. Can you just put a little color around the Carnival brand originally was going to send the ship there for the first time in '17, it sounds that that's going to be '18. Is that just sort of taking time to market a new brand that you want to have a little bit more lead time to? Or just given the positive volume growth in China? Thanks.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No problem, Robin. The CCL decision, the Carnival brand decision in China, when we originally -- when they originally gave their estimate, it was a preliminary thing. And they got to the detailed deployment planning, we have a number of home ports here in
componenttext: No problem, Robin. The CCL decision, the Carnival brand decision in China, when we originally -- when they originally gave their estimate, it was a preliminary thing. And they got to the detailed deployment planning, we have a number of home ports here in the U.S. serviced by the brand. And as they looked at moving ships, ships fit in certain ports and others not, so on and so forth, it just became prudent for them to look at launching in '18 rather than an '17. But it's strictly around deployment planning. It had nothing to do with the environment in China.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up question on the booking and yield strength. Just turning to Europe for a second. Can you give us a sense of the recent incident in Brussels and whether or not that's had any impact? And David, I think that I didn't catch your, fully, your outl
componenttext: A follow-up question on the booking and yield strength. Just turning to Europe for a second. Can you give us a sense of the recent incident in Brussels and whether or not that's had any impact? And David, I think that I didn't catch your, fully, your outlook for Europe based on your current booking strength. I think you said it was slightly higher, but I didn't catch the occupancy.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Harry. First of all, obviously, our thoughts and prayers go to the victims and their families in the Brussels situation. It's really too early for us to know the immediate [ph] impact of that. Historically, there's been some [indiscernible] imp
componenttext: Thank you, Harry. First of all, obviously, our thoughts and prayers go to the victims and their families in the Brussels situation. It's really too early for us to know the immediate [ph] impact of that. Historically, there's been some [indiscernible] impact from events like this and the level of impact depends on a lot of different factors. But historically, eventually people adapt. We don't know exactly where we are in the process at this point. But right now, we see no reason to change guidance. And as you know, our philosophy is things happen every year. And we anticipate that, without knowing exactly where or what, things will happen and we factor that in to an extent. So it's too early to see the full fall out of that. But at this point in time, we're comfortable with the guidance that we've given. We see no reason to change it.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as the booking position, for our EAA brands, which really is the majority of our European program, we said that for Europe, occupancy is ahead of the prior year at slightly higher prices. And for the seasonal programs for our North America bra
componenttext: Yes. As far as the booking position, for our EAA brands, which really is the majority of our European program, we said that for Europe, occupancy is ahead of the prior year at slightly higher prices. And for the seasonal programs for our North America brand, which is really just like 5% of our overall capacity for the company, we said that occupancy was nicely ahead but that pricing was slightly -- was a little bit lower because of the geopolitical risk and the things that Arnold has indicated.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. And then my follow-up question speaks to the share count assumption. David, you mentioned, but I'm not sure I caught this right, that the guidance for the balance of the year assumed a fully diluted share count of 760 million shares, is that co
componenttext: Very good. And then my follow-up question speaks to the share count assumption. David, you mentioned, but I'm not sure I caught this right, that the guidance for the balance of the year assumed a fully diluted share count of 760 million shares, is that correct?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was for the whole year. And as think I'd indicated in the December call, the way we do our guidance is we include the shares that we purchased to date because, as we've always said, our share repurchase program is opportunistic. So built into our gui
componenttext: That was for the whole year. And as think I'd indicated in the December call, the way we do our guidance is we include the shares that we purchased to date because, as we've always said, our share repurchase program is opportunistic. So built into our guidance does not include any future share repurchases. And as I mentioned, we do have almost $700 million left on that second $1 billion. So we do have the opportunity to continue to repurchase.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Hardiman with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Hardiman with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a real quick clarification on some of what's been going on in Southern Mediterranean just based on some of that terrorist attacks. Have you had to move any itineraries around at all? And if so, did that have an impact on your numbers?
componenttext: So just a real quick clarification on some of what's been going on in Southern Mediterranean just based on some of that terrorist attacks. Have you had to move any itineraries around at all? And if so, did that have an impact on your numbers?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, good morning. There is always, in every year, some itinerary adjustments. And we go where people want to go. So if we see there is a heavy reaction from guests about going to a particular itinerary we have previously planned, obviously, we w
componenttext: First of all, good morning. There is always, in every year, some itinerary adjustments. And we go where people want to go. So if we see there is a heavy reaction from guests about going to a particular itinerary we have previously planned, obviously, we will choose to alter that. So yes, there have been some changes in some of the ports in Turkey for example this year. We still have a number of brands going to Turkey. And we are in constant contact with every intelligence agency in the world and all the various security enforcement agencies as well. Safety to our guest is #1. But frankly, right now, we see more just -- what's driving our decision-making is the desire of guests to go to locations. And that's where we are right now.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And then maybe just walk us through the changes in fuel and currency since the last time you guys reported. The constant currency numbers for both yields and costs look to be unchanged. But the current currency numbers look to be slightly be
componenttext: Very helpful. And then maybe just walk us through the changes in fuel and currency since the last time you guys reported. The constant currency numbers for both yields and costs look to be unchanged. But the current currency numbers look to be slightly better for both. Now this might just be a rounding thing and these are all approximate estimates or maybe it's a function of the repositioning of ships. But, normally, sort of things get better for yields and worse for costs or vice versa. It seems like they got a little bit better with respect to FX and then with fuel, certainly, the crude oil prices that we look at have gotten a little bit worse although your guidance for the year seems to have gotten a tad better. Just walk us through some of the puts and takes there.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, as far as -- I'll start with fuel. You probably noticed that overall, we -- for the year, we were $2 -- our guidance is $2 per metric ton better. At the moment in time, that we did the December call versus our March guidance, I mean, Brent was
componenttext: Yes. Well, as far as -- I'll start with fuel. You probably noticed that overall, we -- for the year, we were $2 -- our guidance is $2 per metric ton better. At the moment in time, that we did the December call versus our March guidance, I mean, Brent was within $1. The crack spread was virtually the same. So the numbers move very little on the fuel side. Of course, you have -- we have a little benefit there. We had -- offsetting that was some additional derivative losses. So the overall fuel number was negligible in terms of a change from our December guidance. Currency did move against us. And remember, we have a basket of currencies. So it depends on the movement. The one currency from December through March that moved the most was the British pound. And if you look back, we were guiding -- we were using 1 51 as the rate for the British pound back in December. The rate now, I think, in our press release in the second quarter was like 1 43. So there was like a 5% movement it. So depending on what you're looking at, because of the different basket of currencies and the movements, the British pound is the biggest impact. And that was a negative impact on our bottle line. And that's what drove the majority of the currency drag.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

In the release, you said that they're well ahead of the prior year at slightly higher prior constant currency prices. And then in the December release, you talked about 2016 in a context of slightly higher prices. So I was just wondering, is there any difference in the two outlooks?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: No, they're both constant currency.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Thank you. And then also, Arnold, on the last call, you had talked about the high end of the guidance range, the net yield guidance range for the year being 4%. I know you reiterated the mid 3%. But I'm just wondering if you're looking at the high end simply?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I think Robin...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: Felicia, sorry, I apologize. The reason we set the high end of the range was 4%, is related to the $3.40. And when you start looking at the midpoint of our guidance, it was a $0.30 range and 1 point of yield is $0.15, so we had said the 3 40 related to a 1% higher yield or 4%. So obviously, time has gone on. And we've narrowed the range down to a $0.20 range. But we still -- we're giving you the best estimate that we can. It's still relatively close to approximately 4% at the high-end.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then can you just refresh us in terms of how much of that is ticket and on board, has that changed?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really hasn't changed significantly from the December guidance, the ticket on board. The December guidance, we used about 2% for onboard and it was a little over 3% for ticket. And it's [indiscernible] [indiscernible] lead through.
componenttext: It really hasn't changed significantly from the December guidance, the ticket on board. The December guidance, we used about 2% for onboard and it was a little over 3% for ticket. And it's [indiscernible] [indiscernible] lead through.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Katz with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Katz with Morningstar.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on this revenue management yield system that you guys are using across your brands. And I think the commentary you guys indicated that's about 30% of the inventory would be up over the course of the year. I'm curious, first one that m
componenttext: My first question is on this revenue management yield system that you guys are using across your brands. And I think the commentary you guys indicated that's about 30% of the inventory would be up over the course of the year. I'm curious, first one that might be completed it follows the brands will eventually be on it. And there was a comment that there would be some yield uplift. So I guess I'm curious what your expectations for benefit there are?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good morning, Jamie. So on the revenue management tool that we're implementing, we have 6 brands, 6 of our brands, that initially will be on the new tool. When it's implemented this summer, we'll only have about 30% of their collective inventory goin
componenttext: Yes, good morning, Jamie. So on the revenue management tool that we're implementing, we have 6 brands, 6 of our brands, that initially will be on the new tool. When it's implemented this summer, we'll only have about 30% of their collective inventory going through the tool. Obviously, that will ramp up over time and we'll have a more inventory that goes through it. By the time it's up and running, '16 will be pretty much booked. And so the real impact, we won't see until '17. But I had to tell you, we are enjoying some benefits now just from the brands collaborating, working on the tool together, showing lots of information. There's improved decision-making going on on revenue management all along the way and is definitely contributing to some of the yield improvement that we have enjoyed the past few quarters and including this past quarter. So over time, when we go to the next phase of the tool, which will be implemented next year, pretty much all the brands will be using the tool. We have some brands that have already more sophisticated tool than others. And at this tool baseloaded will be 1 sophistication, we'll put the next layer on top. So it will be a whole level of sophistication. So we'll have a build of impact over the next few years from having the tool. And then it will make a difference.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I have sort of an esoteric question for you guys. How do you guys think about differentiating the brands that are going into the China market versus the competitors? Obviously, Costa has been there for sometime. There's a lot more brand awa
componenttext: Okay. And then I have sort of an esoteric question for you guys. How do you guys think about differentiating the brands that are going into the China market versus the competitors? Obviously, Costa has been there for sometime. There's a lot more brand awareness than maybe some of the other brands. But I think the messaging that's going through the travel agent, the way that the distribution network there works, might be a little bit skewed. So I'm curious if there's an easy way to articulate how Carnival's brands in the region are different and maybe of better value to those consumers?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the easiest way to do it is to actually have the distributors experience the brands. Because once they go on the ships and experience the brand, the difference is dramatic and you very much get a very different feel from 1 brand to the next in terms
componenttext: Yes, the easiest way to do it is to actually have the distributors experience the brands. Because once they go on the ships and experience the brand, the difference is dramatic and you very much get a very different feel from 1 brand to the next in terms of what type of cruise experience it is. And because those brands resonate around the world across different, what we call, psychographic segments, with 1.3 billion people, China is very capable of absorbing lots of different brands. And so we see it, at this stage, as we just have a toe in the water. There's 135 million estimated outbound Chinese tourists today already. And less than 1 million of them or roughly 1 million today are cruising today. So we haven't even touched, begun to touch the surface, hardly. So there's plenty of room and capacity. Our belief is that at the consuming level, at the guest level, that in the price ranges we are in, the guests today are relatively pricing elastic. Whether, I'm in Australia, or Cuba last week, the Mainland Chinese, filled the [indiscernible] that was in a private restaurant in Havana that I was then. And so they have money, they able to travel. They're not exactly shopping for price. They fill out the retail outlets and spend several levels higher than the typical tourist from other places in the world. So we don't see any major barriers at this point except, as you just referred, good communication, execution, training the distribution system, giving them the exposure they need so they can represent the various brands well. We think there's plenty of room for everybody, for several of our brands. We're going to bring AIDA in in '17 and the Carnival brands is scheduled to go on in '18.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, just a housekeeping question. With so much capacity coming on, can you guys offer your outlook for D&A in the current year?
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, just a housekeeping question. With so much capacity coming on, can you guys offer your outlook for D&A in the current year?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: 1.760 billion to 1.780 billion is the range for the year.
componenttext: 1.760 billion to 1.780 billion is the range for the year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to put the Brussels impact in perspective, kind of comparing it to the Paris attacks. Any change in behavior that you've seen that were different than the initial 10 days or so with North American source passengers versus European sourced as well as
componenttext: Just to put the Brussels impact in perspective, kind of comparing it to the Paris attacks. Any change in behavior that you've seen that were different than the initial 10 days or so with North American source passengers versus European sourced as well as cancellation rates?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, it's early. In Paris, there was some impact on bookings, which faded pretty quickly. May have had some net minor impact on results. But again, it's one of many things affecting us in Europe. And we factor that into our guidance. But it's still earl
componenttext: Again, it's early. In Paris, there was some impact on bookings, which faded pretty quickly. May have had some net minor impact on results. But again, it's one of many things affecting us in Europe. And we factor that into our guidance. But it's still early for Brussels. We don't see -- haven't seen anything dramatic yet. The question is how things build and so on. But frankly, again, we've kind of have it in our guidance, [indiscernible] some major dramatic shift in reactions.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so nothing dramatic?
componenttext: Okay, so nothing dramatic?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing dramatic.
componenttext: Nothing dramatic.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. And then moving, just to Cuba and kind of thinking about the opportunity, and congratulations by the way in getting your ship there. How quickly before you think that you'll be able to ramp up capacity in Cuba? And I know there's a regulatory perspe
componenttext: Good. And then moving, just to Cuba and kind of thinking about the opportunity, and congratulations by the way in getting your ship there. How quickly before you think that you'll be able to ramp up capacity in Cuba? And I know there's a regulatory perspective and then there's just a logistical perspective.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you nailed it both. First of all, regulatory first. So we already are talking to Cuba, obviously, about the other brands and when might they come and which ports and so on and so forth. We're looking forward to working with Cuba to help develop the c
componenttext: Yes, you nailed it both. First of all, regulatory first. So we already are talking to Cuba, obviously, about the other brands and when might they come and which ports and so on and so forth. We're looking forward to working with Cuba to help develop the cruise industry there. We think, again, it's a different story than China. But it's similar and that there's room for everybody. And we're looking at it as a refresher for the Caribbean. We think it's going to help us, it's going to help the industry, it's going to help the Caribbean and its certainly going to help Cuba. So we're excited, we're very honored and privileged to have been given the honor of being first for approval by Cuba and we are really enjoying the working relationship and looking forward to working with them. In terms of timing of all of this, the logistics do matter too because our ships, we just talked about, the brands being booked by the summer for '16 pretty much. And so itineraries have been established, guests are planning on going places. As we get additional brands approved by Cuba, those will have to adapt to their current itinerary planning schedule. So practically speaking, while we may have some additional itineraries in 2016, you're probably looking at 2017 from any kind of significant impact.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of clarification questions. One, on your yield guidance. The basically 1% difference to the change in the [indiscernible] that you called out in December, is that built into the guidance now? Or not? I just wanted to clarify that. And then s
componenttext: Just a couple of clarification questions. One, on your yield guidance. The basically 1% difference to the change in the [indiscernible] that you called out in December, is that built into the guidance now? Or not? I just wanted to clarify that. And then secondly, David, I think -- or Arnold, you're commenting on China relative to one of the earlier questions. Did you, just to clarify, did you say, at this point, yields were up, down as it's looking for the year?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, in China, again, it's a unit growth story, we want to keep emphasizing that. But to answer your question, yes, ticket yields are higher than the average for the fleet and we forecast that will be that for the year. So that's the truth. But w
componenttext: First of all, in China, again, it's a unit growth story, we want to keep emphasizing that. But to answer your question, yes, ticket yields are higher than the average for the fleet and we forecast that will be that for the year. So that's the truth. But we don't want to get you over focusing on yield because the real story is the great accretion in earnings that we're getting from China. And it is going to be a volume growth story for a while because we're at the very beginning, we're nascent in that market. And there's just so much potential in that market. In terms of...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: But on the year-over-year [indiscernible]
componenttext: But on the year-over-year [indiscernible]

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other question was about the accounting reclassification. But yes, we built into the guidance in December and we built that into the guidance in March. There's no change in the methodology. And is about 1%.
componenttext: The other question was about the accounting reclassification. But yes, we built into the guidance in December and we built that into the guidance in March. There's no change in the methodology. And is about 1%.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I apologize, just my question and clarification on China was just more -- yes, I totally understand it's a unit growth story and that they're the highest in the world and it's a positive mix as those things continue to grow. But just more on a y
componenttext: Okay, and I apologize, just my question and clarification on China was just more -- yes, I totally understand it's a unit growth story and that they're the highest in the world and it's a positive mix as those things continue to grow. But just more on a year-over-year comparison, perhaps slightly down?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've never given a range on yields in China. But yields are down on just a year-to-year basis. But we've never given a range in [indiscernible]
componenttext: We've never given a range on yields in China. But yields are down on just a year-to-year basis. But we've never given a range in [indiscernible]

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then, just staying [ph] on that versus the rest of the world. Any color for the industry that you could comment on us to how maybe the China yields combined are different relative to say, North America or Europe?
componenttext: Okay, and then, just staying [ph] on that versus the rest of the world. Any color for the industry that you could comment on us to how maybe the China yields combined are different relative to say, North America or Europe?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't have any color for you on that. No.
componenttext: No, I don't have any color for you on that. No.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then two other things on yield and that will be it. The implied net yields in your guidance for the year, just by major geographic region, Europe, Asia, North America. And then specifically, related to the Brits and onboard spending, anything th
componenttext: Okay. And then two other things on yield and that will be it. The implied net yields in your guidance for the year, just by major geographic region, Europe, Asia, North America. And then specifically, related to the Brits and onboard spending, anything that you're seeing given the pound depreciation that you've seen here since the beginning of the year over the last 6 months and onboard spending trends by Brits in particular?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just onboard in general, onboard revenues for us has increased every year over the last, I don't know, 10, 12 years, except one. And so onboard revenues tend to increase every year and the question is, how much? Last year, we had a large percentage increa
componenttext: Just onboard in general, onboard revenues for us has increased every year over the last, I don't know, 10, 12 years, except one. And so onboard revenues tend to increase every year and the question is, how much? Last year, we had a large percentage increase in onboard revenues overall. And this year, we're seeing again an increase on top of that. But not necessarily at the same level as last year, but a nice increase. And so, the correlation to the economy and all that tend not to -- we have difficulty tracking that and correlating in any specific way, even the degree of increase and onboard revenue isn't always correlated to particular economic conditions in a given destination market or given source market. And so there's just so many variables that come into that. Not the least of which is just constantly giving guests more of what they want. And if you do that, the guests onboard will spend more. And it's really -- the issue for us is always tweaking that and figuring out exactly what the guests want. So we give it to them in the way they want it, what they want, the way they want it and then we continue to grow. So to be honest with you, we haven't seen -- we tried it every which way and we just haven't seen a high correlation to general economic trends.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also, keep in mind that the overwhelming majority of our British guests sail and P&O Cruises, which is the British pound onboard, so as far as they're concerned, there really is no change. Of course, it does affect on a translation basis, those onboar
componenttext: And also, keep in mind that the overwhelming majority of our British guests sail and P&O Cruises, which is the British pound onboard, so as far as they're concerned, there really is no change. Of course, it does affect on a translation basis, those onboard revenues into U.S. dollars. But we -- it doesn't change their spending patterns onboard. And as far as the overall cruise revenue yields are concerned, we had talked in December, between our North American brands and our EAA brands, we were expecting increases in both segments of our business. The increases were slightly better in the North American brands than the EAA brands once you net out the accounting reclassification, which I had mentioned affected the EAA brands in December.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Milota from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Milota from JPMorgan.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones here. First, obviously, China is very small right now in terms of total capacity of 5%. With your capacity introductions in '17 and '18, could you give us a sense for where your total -- where those capacity stats will go in those years?
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones here. First, obviously, China is very small right now in terms of total capacity of 5%. With your capacity introductions in '17 and '18, could you give us a sense for where your total -- where those capacity stats will go in those years? And then secondly, I guess for David, on fuel. At current fuel levels, could you give us a sense for what's baked into the 3 20 to 3 40 guidance as it relates to the unrealized losses from your derivatives? Thank you.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you for your questions. First of all, in China. As you know, the industry, believe it or not, is capacity constraint because of the limited number of shipyards to build ships. And obviously, we've got partnerships with [indiscernible] and [ind
componenttext: Okay. Thank you for your questions. First of all, in China. As you know, the industry, believe it or not, is capacity constraint because of the limited number of shipyards to build ships. And obviously, we've got partnerships with [indiscernible] and [indiscernible] and with Meyer in Germany in terms of securing slots and enhance our fleet. Having said that, in China, we can't grow too fast because definitely, availability of ships. So we'll probably be by 2020, somewhere in the 8% to 9% range of our fleet, which means most of the growth in capacity we have will actually be going to China. And that means that we'll be growing at a much lower rate in the rest of the world markets, 1% to 2% there while [indiscernible]  Percentage increases in China. But in terms of absolute number of ships, they are relatively small compared to the latent demand that exists in the country. So to answer your question, by 2020, depending on how things go, [indiscernible] we have flexibility, depending on how things go, we can be 8%, 9% of our capacity in China. And that means therefore that we didn't grow a lot than the rest of the world. But that fits with our measured capacity growth overall plan to help create relative scarcity, and we continue to drive demand to create excess demand relative to that measured capacity which obviously, allows us to capture more of the value gap that currently exists between land-based vacations and cruise, we still have a much better value than land-based vacations. So we have a lot of room to move. David?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as far as the derivative, you said unrealized. But I think what you meant is how much was in our guidance in terms of realized losses on the fuel derivatives for the year. And the number is 300 -- about $330 million of realized losses.
componenttext: And as far as the derivative, you said unrealized. But I think what you meant is how much was in our guidance in terms of realized losses on the fuel derivatives for the year. And the number is 300 -- about $330 million of realized losses.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ian Rennardson from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ian Rennardson from Jefferies.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions for you. How much more are you sold in this time last year? Is it 5%? Is it 10%? Is it 20%? Could you give us a sort of numerical answer, please? And moving on to yield expectations. Q2, 1.5% to 2.5% growth in constant currency after
componenttext: A couple of questions for you. How much more are you sold in this time last year? Is it 5%? Is it 10%? Is it 20%? Could you give us a sort of numerical answer, please? And moving on to yield expectations. Q2, 1.5% to 2.5% growth in constant currency after a very strong end to Q1, you mentioned closing pricing. Why this sort of slight disconnect? Please, thank you.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as far as how -- we are ahead on bookings but we don't give the details for competitive reasons about exactly what percentage points we are ahead. So we just rather leave it more general. And as far as the comparisons on the quarterly basis, last -- th
componenttext: So as far as how -- we are ahead on bookings but we don't give the details for competitive reasons about exactly what percentage points we are ahead. So we just rather leave it more general. And as far as the comparisons on the quarterly basis, last -- the first -- the second quarter is lower than the first quarter. But you got to remember, you've got to look back against the prior year. The second quarter last year was much stronger than the first quarter. We were up 2% more the second quarter. So it has a tougher comparison in the prior year as well as the fact that in the first quarter this year, we had indicated we were 47% in the Caribbean versus 30% in the second quarter. The Caribbean was a very strong market for us. And so you are seeing some differences between the first and second quarter in terms of yield increases.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: But that yield improvement in the second quarter obviously is consistent with the overall guidance and is going to lead us to 20% or better at the midpoint of our current guidance, earnings improvement year-over-year.
componenttext: But that yield improvement in the second quarter obviously is consistent with the overall guidance and is going to lead us to 20% or better at the midpoint of our current guidance, earnings improvement year-over-year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Stuart Gordon with Nrnberg.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Stuart Gordon with Nrnberg.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the close-in bookings, have obviously been very strong and held beat on the yield. Can you give an indication as to whether this has been helped by less sort of onboard concessions that's helped drive up the ticket price rather th
componenttext: Just a quick question on the close-in bookings, have obviously been very strong and held beat on the yield. Can you give an indication as to whether this has been helped by less sort of onboard concessions that's helped drive up the ticket price rather than driving up on board spend? Thank you.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When the package -- what you're talking about is some value added packages and when we provide those value added packages, we do segregate a portion of the revenue and record it in onboard. So you wouldn't see an artificial drive up in ticket prices
componenttext: Yes. When the package -- what you're talking about is some value added packages and when we provide those value added packages, we do segregate a portion of the revenue and record it in onboard. So you wouldn't see an artificial drive up in ticket prices from a value-added package.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But did you had to give away a less value-added packages and the closing of this quarter which then perhaps, has been the case in previous quarters?
componenttext: Okay. But did you had to give away a less value-added packages and the closing of this quarter which then perhaps, has been the case in previous quarters?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, starting capacity to the prior quarter, the yields are up significantly. So overall, pricing in total was stronger, whichever way you want to look at it. And so that means I don't know whether they gave more packages, I don't know but would reflect
componenttext: Well, starting capacity to the prior quarter, the yields are up significantly. So overall, pricing in total was stronger, whichever way you want to look at it. And so that means I don't know whether they gave more packages, I don't know but would reflect onboard versus ticket. But the practical reality across the fleet -- we have so many different brands. But across the fleet, overall, closing was much stronger at this year than last. So that means they reduced pricing less.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jared Shojaian of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jared Shojaian of Wolfe Research.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have you guys stopped hedging fuel? Looks like you haven't put on anything new for a while? Can you give us an update on your current policy here?
componenttext: Have you guys stopped hedging fuel? Looks like you haven't put on anything new for a while? Can you give us an update on your current policy here?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have collars that went out a number of years and right now, we continue to live with those as you can see from the derivative losses. So at this point in time, we evaluate it constantly to see what we should do. In the past, we did it to avoid si
componenttext: Well, we have collars that went out a number of years and right now, we continue to live with those as you can see from the derivative losses. So at this point in time, we evaluate it constantly to see what we should do. In the past, we did it to avoid significant spike in fuel pricing. That could have created any kind of short-term cash issues. And -- we don't see, at this point in time, a need to do anything. We are collared all the way into 2018 at various levels, I think, next year is --

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next year, we've got 8.1 million barrels collared.
componenttext: Next year, we've got 8.1 million barrels collared.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible]

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: A little over 50 million and 5.4 million barrels in 2018 which is less than 50%. But as Arnold said, we're collared out almost 3 years. So we are comfortable with our current position. We constantly talk about it and analyze it and think about it. But as
componenttext: A little over 50 million and 5.4 million barrels in 2018 which is less than 50%. But as Arnold said, we're collared out almost 3 years. So we are comfortable with our current position. We constantly talk about it and analyze it and think about it. But as you said, we haven't done any fuel derivatives since, it was October of '14. And we'll give it more consideration as we go forward.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, thanks. And then should we expect the pace of your buyback year-to-date to continue throughout the balance of the year? And if so, are you comfortable financing CapEx in order to do that? And if not, can you just help us understand why you wo
componenttext: Okay, great, thanks. And then should we expect the pace of your buyback year-to-date to continue throughout the balance of the year? And if so, are you comfortable financing CapEx in order to do that? And if not, can you just help us understand why you wouldn't take on some incremental debt right now while still being able to maintain the investment grade credit rating? Thank you.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all -- you bet. First of all, we do have an authorization. We will be using that authorization. Beyond that, that's a board decision and the board is constantly looking at it. In terms of our debt position, we are, as you can tell, our bala
componenttext: Well, first of all -- you bet. First of all, we do have an authorization. We will be using that authorization. Beyond that, that's a board decision and the board is constantly looking at it. In terms of our debt position, we are, as you can tell, our balance sheet is in pretty good shape. David, any additional color, if you like, go ahead.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have said many times that we would return all our excess free cash flow to the shareholders. We have done that. We did get the second $1 billion authorization from the Board of Directors. We'll be opportunistic as we purchase throughout the rest o
componenttext: Yes. We have said many times that we would return all our excess free cash flow to the shareholders. We have done that. We did get the second $1 billion authorization from the Board of Directors. We'll be opportunistic as we purchase throughout the rest of this year. And when we get completed with that, we'll take a look and we'll talk to the board about what's next. But you had to keep in mind, this is a board decision. So we don't want to preempt the board. But when we get done with the $700 million, we'll look at potentially what's next in the program.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: With respect to the revenue beat, I'm just wondering how much was tied to investments at advertising spend over the past year? And then with respect to the uptick in advertising in the third quarter, I'm wondering why then and how you've been measuring th
componenttext: With respect to the revenue beat, I'm just wondering how much was tied to investments at advertising spend over the past year? And then with respect to the uptick in advertising in the third quarter, I'm wondering why then and how you've been measuring the link between the campaigns and the revenue production?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, we have 10 brands. They all have segments that they are catering to. And they all have their independent marketing plans. We do look at it collectively. We are leveraging our scale in terms of [indiscernible] buying those types of thing
componenttext: Well, as you know, we have 10 brands. They all have segments that they are catering to. And they all have their independent marketing plans. We do look at it collectively. We are leveraging our scale in terms of [indiscernible] buying those types of things, even more efficient that's paying dividends for us. But the reality is, we are expecting a return on any investment we make. And that includes advertising. It's whether mass media advertising, product placement advertising digital, all the various forms of it. And PR, public relations efforts. So our belief is that we had to keep crews out in the public space, in a positive way on a constant basis. So that when people are considering vacation, there's been enough noise about cruise that they say, I have an idea. Let's go to a cruise. And so the idea is just to keep it out there and realize all the various forms. There's no question. We have created incremental demand. We also know there's no question that an incremental demand has been in part, created by the fantastic work of our team members across our 10 brands who literally exceed guest expectations everyday when they come on board and that word-of-mouth and that personal experience with having your expectations exceeded is the most powerful marketing tool we have by far. And that's by the work of our people in engineering. Experiences on board and then delivering the guests to it. And so to your question, yes, we've increased advertising overall. We'll continue to look at it. We don't do a willy-nilly. We do a lot of measuring and tracking to see what kind of impact we get, both in attitude and in bookings and so on. And we're constantly monitoring that and tweaking it. But the third quarter rationale is a peak communication time to prepare for the coming year. And that's why you also see an increase in that period.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. The next question, gets the competition for the upper scale traveler and specifically, your key competitors have products within their core brand, the chip away at that market share and that segment. So you got the Norwegian haven, the [indisce
componenttext: Very good. The next question, gets the competition for the upper scale traveler and specifically, your key competitors have products within their core brand, the chip away at that market share and that segment. So you got the Norwegian haven, the [indiscernible] suite product, that we had version, seems poised to also chip away at the upper scale traveler. So I'm wondering if you can help us put some brackets around the revenue that this market segment represents? How you're thinking about these moves by key competitors and how Carnival is responding? And thanks for the questions.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet. Our primary competitor is land-based vacations. 1 of every 2 people cruise in the world cruise with us. And we have tremendous respect for the other companies that operate. And we want them to be successful. We -- that's helped us a lot, the stro
componenttext:
You bet. Our primary competitor is land-based vacations. 1 of every 2 people cruise in the world cruise with us. And we have tremendous respect for the other companies that operate. And we want them to be successful. We -- that's helped us a lot, the stronger they are, the better it is for us. So having said that, we have 10 brands. We have ultra luxury in Seabourn, we have luxury in Cunard, both in Queen Elizabeth and Princess, we have Holland America Line and Neptune, we have premium brands in fathom, our newest premium brand. But obviously our long-established premium brand is Princess and Holland America and AIDA. And then we have contemporary bands like [indiscernible] and Carnival. So we look at that. But again, the really important thing about cruise is this, we've had [indiscernible], we paid to lecture on Seabourn. But he pays to go on Carnival, okay? Because it's not a demographic choice per se. We had taxi drivers who will stay for 5 years going on Seabourn cruise and have billionaires who want to sail on Carnival. And the reality is the experience that you're looking for. And each brand is a different experience, caters to a different psychographic market. So we have ultra luxury brands, luxury brands, premium brands, [indiscernible] with their own experience and that's what drives this us. But for us, we're definitely looking at penetrating more land-based vacations because all the cabins in the world added altogether represents less than, in the industry, less than 2% of hotel rooms in the world. So that means there's 98% of the market to chase as opposed to 1% because -- of that 2%, 1% is ours already. That's kind of our approach. 
Thank you very much. I really appreciate the questions. Thanks for your support. Look forward to talking to you guys next quarter and in between. And as always, feel free to call Beth with any additional questions or insights you might want to offer us. So thank you.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 30, 2016
