componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I am Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning.Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; Davi
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I am Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning.
Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; David Bernstein, our Chief Financial Officer; and Beth Roberts, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Before I begin, as always, please note that some of our remarks on this call will be forward looking. Therefore, I must refer you to the cautionary statement in today's press release.
We delivered the strongest second quarter in the history of our company, with record adjusted earnings per share nearly double the prior year and well above the high end of our March guidance range. The second quarter result, combined with our strong book position, has enabled us to maintain the midpoint of our full year guidance range despite a $0.17 drag from fuel and currency. 
Essentially, the strength and underlying demand for our products fostered greater ticket price in both the quarter and in the remainder of the year, offsetting the rise of fuel prices since the time of our last guidance as well as the very recent significant movements in currency exchange rates following the Brexit vote.
Our record results reflect our passionate 120,000-plus employees who, in their efforts, go above and beyond every day, and who together with our hundreds of thousands of travel partners, are the foundation of our sustained earnings improvement. 
This was among the most remarkable quarters in the history of the company not only because of our record-breaking financial results but because of a significant number of milestones, which will contribute meaningfully to our future success. 
We introduced 3 new flagships, including Carnival Vista, purposely designed for our fun-loving Carnival Cruise Line guests with an onboard experience, entertaining IMAX theater and exhilarating skyride experience. Carnival Vista has already generated over 1 billion media impressions. 
Holand America Lines [indiscernible] and Rotterdam by Her Majesty Queen Maxima The Netherlands delivers a new premium experience where our guests can blend their own wine, enjoy high-end flight [indiscernible] in our engineered music walk. And last but not least, the AIDAprima made its debut with a spectacular live show, fireworks and memorable ceremony witnessed by over 1 million people gathered in Hamburg. 
These well-publicized introductions are certain to continue increased consideration for cruising within our portfolio of the world's leading cruise lines. Moreover, we welcomed our 10th brand in April with inaugural impact to the Dominican Republic [indiscernible] followed by a historic first sailing for Cuba in May. 
Barring none, one of the most publicized events in the history of the cruise industry was on our to Cuba with over 20 billion media impressions, bringing the cumulative total media impressions for Carnival and Cuba to nearly 55 billion to date. We could not have been more proud than when General Counsel [indiscernible] and his wife Carmen, both Cuban-born, were first to disembark when we made history as the first U.S. cruise line in more than 40 years to sail to Cuba. 
Having sailed there myself, I can assure you, there is no better way to experience Cuba today than on our brand. We are working hard to enable more of our brands to bring guests to Cuba in the near future, a promising long-term driver of continued demand for our Caribbean itineraries. Indeed, we have had an eventful quarter.
Returning to the financials. China, which is definitely the world's largest cruise market, continues to deliver accretive returns on invested capital. We again achieved significant earnings growth this quarter and continue to fully expect earnings growth for the full year directionally proportionate with our over 60% capacity increase. 
In China, our occupancy levels remain comparable to the high levels we have consistently achieved as we introduced hundreds of thousands of new recruits to our brands. the penetration level for the sizable and rapidly expanding addressable market is well below 1%, just a fraction of the more developed cruise markets. While these guests stay within Asia today, over time, we have an opportunity to take them to all the great destinations our ship [indiscernible] they have not yet been like the unique beauty of Venice and the amazing glaciers in Alaska.
We remain confident in the long-term development of the cruise industry in China, with our capacity growth expected to be up over 30% in 2017. Now that's following over 60% increase [indiscernible] in 2016. These large year-over-year percentage increases are on a very small base, so these growth rates are already equivalent to adding about one 4,000-berth [ph] vessel each year. 
As a result, China represents less than 5% of our global capacity this year and will grow to just 6% next year after the entry of Majestic Princess, the first purpose-built ship for Chinese guests and AIDAbella, the first ship in China for our AIDA brand. Of course, the capacity shift to China helps create relative scarcity in our other markets, supporting global revenue yield growth. We remain confident in the outlook for [indiscernible] supply growth in 2017, our global supply growth is just 2.7%. 
Within that, we are rebalancing our portfolio to optimize the current demand environment. We expect a 5% capacity reduction in Europe, stemming from a capacity reduction in the Mediterranean region, which is down over 10%. We expect a modest 5% and 3% growth in capacity in the more robust Caribbean and Alaska deployments, respectively. On the margin, these deployment changes should contribute to yield next year. 
During the quarter, we continued to make progress on our cross brand efforts to leverage our scale. On the revenue side, work on our revenue yield optimizer system continues. And as previously noted, we'll be rolled out on 30% of our inventory across 6 of our brands this summer. We are on track to begin prototype testing in July. Even their early stage of implementation will [indiscernible] uplift as we refine our techniques to contribute to enhanced demand forecast. [indiscernible] this year's bookings will be behind us by the summer, we continue to expect a greater contribution from this effort in 2017.
And on the cost side, work in our procurement area continues. We remain on track for our updated $75 million of expected cost savings in 2016. Most recently, we announced a strategic coordination of our global media planning and buying for our 7 brands in North America and the U.K., generating significant double-digit savings on our $100 million annual media spend. 
Our record quarterly results and our strong book position are a testament to the success of our ongoing strategy to drive demand well in excess of our measured capacity growth. All things considered, bookings for our ships sailing the Europe has held up well. And bookings in the Caribbean and Alaska for the remainder of the year are very strong for our brands, enabling us to raise our revenue yield expectation and affirming our conviction to deliver over 20% earnings growth this year.
We are on track for the delivery of nearly 9% return on invested capital this year and remain well on track in accelerating progress towards a double-digit threshold, again given our ongoing efforts to create demand in excess of supply, coupled with our revenue management enhancement and opportunity to further leverage our scale. 
Despite the geopolitical events in Europe, including the Brexit vote, we remain confident in our long-term outlook, given the attractive value proposition our strong and diversified brand portfolio offers the, particularly in the U.K. where our local brands, PO Cruises and Cunard, sold in British pound have an increasingly competitive advantage to land-based vacation alternatives to Europe and abroad.
Our increasingly strong cash flow enables us to accelerate distribution to our shareholders. Since resuming our stock repurchase program late last year, we're nearing completion on our second $1 billion share repurchase authorization, bringing the cumulative total of repurchases to date to approximately $1.9 billion and 38 million shares. 
In addition, recently, we announced our second dividend increase inside of a year, bringing our annual dividend distribution to over $1 billion. We plan to continue to return free cash flow and more to shareholders with our strong balance sheet and leverage ratios now comfortably at the better end of our targeted range. 
Our sustained earnings improvement, coupled with our strong balance sheet, has resulted in Moody's upgrading our credit rating from Baa1 to A3 [ph]. And just yesterday, our Board of Directors authorizing our third $1 billion share repurchase program, all of which demonstrate continued confidence and realization of sustained double-digit return on invested capital, which our company is inherently capable of delivering. And now I'd like to turn the call over to David.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arnold. Before I begin, please note, all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 second quarter results. Then I'll provide som
componenttext:
Thank you, Arnold. Before I begin, please note, all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 second quarter results. Then I'll provide some insights on booking trends and finish up with an update on our full year 2016 guidance. 
Our record adjusted EPS for the second quarter was $0.49. This was $0.13 above the midpoint of our March guidance. The improvement was essentially driven by 2 things: $0.05 from net revenue yields, which benefited from stronger pricing on close-in bookings at our North American brands; and $0.06 from lower net cruise costs, excluding fuel as a result of timing of certain expenses between the quarters.
Now let's look at our second quarter operating results versus the prior year. Our capacity increased 2%. The North American brands were flat, while the European, Australia and Asian brands, also known as our EAA brands, were up over 5%. Our total net revenue yields were up 3.6%.
Now let's break apart the 2 components of net revenue yield. Net ticket yields were up 3.5%. The increase was driven by our North American brands deployment in the Caribbean and Alaska. Net onboard and other yield increased almost 4%, with increases on both sides of the Atlantic mainly related to bar and casino. Net cruise costs per ALBD, excluding fuel, were down almost 2%, which is about a 3-point improvement versus what was planned in our March guidance, but again, this was due to the timing of expenses between the quarters.
In summary, a record second quarter adjusted EPS was almost double the prior year or $0.24 higher, driven by operational improvements worth $0.18, a favorable net impact of lower fuel prices and currency worth $0.04 and share buyback accretion worth $0.02.
Now let's turn to booking trends. Since March, bookings for the remainder of the year are at higher prices, with less inventory remaining for sale and at the same time last year. At this point in time, for the remaining 2 quarters of 2016, cumulative bookings are well ahead at slightly higher prices. The fact that we are well ahead on the book position with less inventory left to sell for the remainder of the year compared to last year, even with our capacity increase, bodes well for pricing over the next few months.
Now let's drill down into the cumulative book position. First for our North American brands. Caribbean occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at nicely higher prices. For Alaska, occupancy is in line with the prior year, also at nicely higher prices. For the seasonal European program, occupancy is ahead of the prior year at lower prices driven by geopolitical risk impacting the Mediterranean trade as anticipated in our guidance. 
Secondly, for our EAA brands. For Europe, occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at a higher price. Australia and Asia are consistent with our previous guidance. As expected, we are behind on pricing given our 60% increase in China capacity and our 15% increase in Australia capacity. For 2017, we continue to move out the booking curve. At this point in time, for the first 3 quarters of 2017, cumulative fleet-wide bookings are well ahead at prices that are in line with 2016. And recent trends have been very positive with robust booking activity at slightly higher prices. These are early indications for 2017 and I do caution you not to read too much into these trends.
Finally, I want to provide you with an update on our full year 2016 guidance. As Arnold indicated, our second quarter results, combined with a strong book position, enabled us to maintain the midpoint of our previous guidance range. This is actually a $0.17 improvement offset by a $0.17 drag from fuel prices and currency. 
Our 2016 June guidance is $3.25 to $3.35. The $0.17 improvement compared to our March guidance was essentially driven by 3 things: one, improved net revenue yields worth $0.10, $0.05 of which was achieved in the second quarter and an additional $0.05 we expect to achieve in net ticket revenues during the remainder of the year; second, lower net cruise costs, excluding fuel, were $0.03; and third, the accretive impact of the additional shares we purchased since our March guidance call worth $0.03.
Net cruise costs without fuel per ALBD are now expected to be up approximately 1.5% for 2016, 0.5 points better than our March guidance. Remember that while the yield expected to be up approximately 1.5%, there are differences between the quarters. The first quarter was up about 1.5 points while the second quarter was down almost 2%. 
However, as I mentioned during the last earnings call and taking into account the reseasonalization of our planned second quarter costs into the second half of the year, we expect third quarter net cruise costs without fuel per ALBD to be up 6% to 7%, driven by the timing of advertising expense and the remastering of Queen Mary 2 in dry dock. The expectation for the fourth quarter is that costs will be flat.
At the midpoint of our June guidance, net cash provided by operating activities is approaching $5 billion. As Arnold indicated, with such strong cash flows since late last year, we repurchased approximately 38 million of our shares, and our Board of Directors authorized a third $1 billion stock buyback program yesterday. 
In addition, we still have about $100 million remaining on our second $1 billion stock buyback authorization. Our June guidance EPS calculation assumes shares repurchased through last week. For the full year, the calculations assume approximately 715 [ph] million shares outstanding on a weighted average basis while for the third quarter, the calculations assume 743 million shares outstanding.
On a final note, given the volatility of FX rates since the Brexit vote, we want to share with you our current rules of thumb about the impact that currency and fuel prices can have on our 2016 results. To start with, a 10% change in all relevant currencies relative to the U.S. dollar would impact our P&L by approximately $0.18 for the remainder of the year and $0.09 for the third quarter. 
For fuel price changes, a 10% change in the current spot price represents a $0.07 impact for the remainder of the year and $0.04 for the third quarter. Fuel expense in our guidance is about $920 million for the full year. The third rule of thumb relates to our fuel derivative portfolio. A 10% change in Brent would result in a $0.03 change in realized losses on fuel derivative for the remainder of the year and $0.02 for the third quarter.
And now I'll turn it back over to Arnold.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could give a little color, you're raising your full year yield guidance for the year. Is it China yield coming in line with expectations, like Caribbean coming in better? Wonder if you could throw a little bit of color on how the different
componenttext: I wonder if you could give a little color, you're raising your full year yield guidance for the year. Is it China yield coming in line with expectations, like Caribbean coming in better? Wonder if you could throw a little bit of color on how the different regions are coming in versus your previous expectations. And also a little bit of some investors have been concerned Eastern may be worse than expected but clearly, overall things coming better than expected, so just wondering what areas are driving that more than others.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robin, thanks for your question. Yes, generally speaking, obviously as we said -- just said that Alaska and the Caribbean are strong. So those primarily North American-sourced markets definitely are providing a lot of higher yield expectations. At the sam
componenttext: Robin, thanks for your question. Yes, generally speaking, obviously as we said -- just said that Alaska and the Caribbean are strong. So those primarily North American-sourced markets definitely are providing a lot of higher yield expectations. At the same time, we are continuing to show strong improvement in Europe from our EAA brands. The seasonal European business [indiscernible] America brands going to Europe have experienced more challenge as we previously communicated. But most of the drive is coming from the strength of the North American markets.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And China still in line with your previous expectation?
componenttext: And China still in line with your previous expectation?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very pleased with China. China continues to be accretive to us. It's, as we've indicated before, a volume and return story more than a yield story. Yields are down in China this year. But overall, our earnings are proportionate to our capacity growt
componenttext: We're very pleased with China. China continues to be accretive to us. It's, as we've indicated before, a volume and return story more than a yield story. Yields are down in China this year. But overall, our earnings are proportionate to our capacity growth. We see continued demand. And again, as we said just a few minutes ago, our capacity changes are -- they sound like big percentage increases but in terms of the actual volume, we're going to go from 5% of our capacity to 6% next year. But China is doing well for us and we continue to have great confidence in the business. And overall, the business is accretive especially for the brands that are there.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, did the Brexit vote, has that changed your outlook for the remainder of the year? Is there any sort of different view factored in from that, I mean, obviously, the FX impact that you've updated today?
componenttext: And then just lastly, did the Brexit vote, has that changed your outlook for the remainder of the year? Is there any sort of different view factored in from that, I mean, obviously, the FX impact that you've updated today?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So at this point in time, it's the FX impact, which obviously, we calculated in. We've taken a strong look at our business obviously in the U.K. and in Europe and everywhere else what ramifications will be but at this point, we have no reason to adju
componenttext: Yes. So at this point in time, it's the FX impact, which obviously, we calculated in. We've taken a strong look at our business obviously in the U.K. and in Europe and everywhere else what ramifications will be but at this point, we have no reason to adjust anything.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016

componenttext: Thank you for the acknowledgment on the quarter. We see in Europe overall that again, the booking curve is getting a little further out. componenttext: Yes, keep in mind that in our situation, 90% of the guests on our European itineraries are Europeans, and so that's a very different picture than North Americans flying over. And I think as we had said a number of times earlier this year, the North Americans -- while the pricing was down, we are filling the ships. And recently, we have seen some very good demand for the European itineraries from the North Americans.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, thank you for the color on next year. Looks like things are starting to shape up well although it's early days. Just wanted to talk for a moment about the yield optimization or the revenue management optimization program that you're undergoing now.
componenttext: David, thank you for the color on next year. Looks like things are starting to shape up well although it's early days. Just wanted to talk for a moment about the yield optimization or the revenue management optimization program that you're undergoing now. And recognizing that we'll start to see the impact next year, just wondering if you could help us understand what kind of yield contribution you might be able to get from that, from having those 6 brands more on that program.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is Arnold first. First of all, on the new revenue management tools, we're very excited about it. We feel the brands are collaborating exceptionally well on it. It's going to allow us many, many more capabilities in terms of more timing inquirie
componenttext: Okay. This is Arnold first. First of all, on the new revenue management tools, we're very excited about it. We feel the brands are collaborating exceptionally well on it. It's going to allow us many, many more capabilities in terms of more timing inquiries, smaller movements and price movements to optimize pricing, and therefore maximize on the yield results. And as we said, we'll be pretty much booked by the end of the summer, so most of the impact of this initial phase we'll see next year. And then into next year, we'll add some additional features, which will bring in the rest of the brands as well and will be able to max out going to 2018 from the tool itself and the better management skills that our people will develop from being able to utilize this tool and being [indiscernible] in a more timely and [indiscernible] respond in a more rapid fashion. I'll let David comment beyond that but

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I agree with Arnold. It's really a multiyear process as we keep rolling out more of the inventory on the system and we learn from it. It is a little early to try to give guidance for 2017 or the exact impact in 2017 from the system. We'll talk more a
componenttext: Yes, I agree with Arnold. It's really a multiyear process as we keep rolling out more of the inventory on the system and we learn from it. It is a little early to try to give guidance for 2017 or the exact impact in 2017 from the system. We'll talk more about yields in December. But keep in mind overall, to achieve our double-digit ROIC goal, our expectation is that we will see solid yield improvement in 2017 and beyond to achieve those goals. I will give you more color come December.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for my next question, I apologize if it sounds like a repeat of something that you've already said and answered. But I keep getting investor questions about this so I'm going to ask for as a point of clarification. As you look at your second half of t
componenttext: And for my next question, I apologize if it sounds like a repeat of something that you've already said and answered. But I keep getting investor questions about this so I'm going to ask for as a point of clarification. As you look at your second half of the year, given where you viewed the second half of the year when you provided your guidance previously in the spring versus today, has anything changed?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess overall, we took the ticket yield guidance, as I mentioned in my comments, up by $0.05. And so I think as Arnold alluded to before, we're seeing strength in the North American market. And as a result of that, we took our yield guidance up for the
componenttext: I guess overall, we took the ticket yield guidance, as I mentioned in my comments, up by $0.05. And so I think as Arnold alluded to before, we're seeing strength in the North American market. And as a result of that, we took our yield guidance up for the back half of the year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what's changed is obviously, we have more clarity on line of sight we're ahead on bookings. We've got less volume to sell. We had higher prices and so we have affirmation for being positive.
componenttext: Yes, what's changed is obviously, we have more clarity on line of sight we're ahead on bookings. We've got less volume to sell. We had higher prices and so we have affirmation for being positive.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So [indiscernible] sounds like you're more optimistic at the second half because you have better visibility than you were when you last -- when we last met in this forum.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. David, just housekeeping. Is there -- just given the uncertainty, given Brexit, given the volatility in the market, the fact that everybody is trying to figure out which companies are most exposed to which currencies, I know in the past, you haven'
componenttext: Great. David, just housekeeping. Is there -- just given the uncertainty, given Brexit, given the volatility in the market, the fact that everybody is trying to figure out which companies are most exposed to which currencies, I know in the past, you haven't broken this out. But is there any way to give us an understanding or any kind of magnitude to how exposed you are to the British pound?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the British pound represents about 30% of our currency exposure. So we talked about a full year impact of $0.27 for a 10% change in all currencies relative to the U.S. dollar. So for the British pound, you're talking about roughly $0.08 for the -- o
componenttext: Well, the British pound represents about 30% of our currency exposure. So we talked about a full year impact of $0.27 for a 10% change in all currencies relative to the U.S. dollar. So for the British pound, you're talking about roughly $0.08 for the -- on a full year basis.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citi.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just for the first question, you mentioned that North American passengers is going to Europe as that trend recently strengthened. And I'm wondering just with the volatility in Europe, the currency changes, would you expect North American-sourced business
componenttext: Just for the first question, you mentioned that North American passengers is going to Europe as that trend recently strengthened. And I'm wondering just with the volatility in Europe, the currency changes, would you expect North American-sourced business to become a bigger portion of passengers sailing on European itineraries over the next several quarters? And I think it's like 10% sourced goes to -- of the European itineraries, I think 10% are sourced from North America. Would you expect that to increase over the next 3 [ph] quarters?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really hard to say. You're talking about a lot of itineraries, multiple brands. Our brands do a great job looking at it itinerary by itinerary and sourcing based off of where they can get the maximum amount of yield. And so there's a lot of factors to con
componenttext: Really hard to say. You're talking about a lot of itineraries, multiple brands. Our brands do a great job looking at it itinerary by itinerary and sourcing based off of where they can get the maximum amount of yield. And so there's a lot of factors to consider, and a call like that in the short term would be very difficult for us to opine on at this point.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to even further clarify if I can, which I think we all know the answer, you gave us a different way. But from your vantage point, you're not seeing any material drop-off in the last, let's say, since you reported March. You haven't see
componenttext: Okay. And then just to even further clarify if I can, which I think we all know the answer, you gave us a different way. But from your vantage point, you're not seeing any material drop-off in the last, let's say, since you reported March. You haven't seen a material drop-off in pricing or booking trends either at the travel agent or charter level or in terms of renegotiating at significantly lower prices with the charter companies that you have yield with for 2016 pricing. Is that the case or not?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For us, as I said, first of all, our occupancy on our sailings is very comparable, which is very small [ph] to prior year. We see no major change in occupancy whatsoever. In terms of yields, of course, the yields are down but on the other hand, our earnin
componenttext: For us, as I said, first of all, our occupancy on our sailings is very comparable, which is very small [ph] to prior year. We see no major change in occupancy whatsoever. In terms of yields, of course, the yields are down but on the other hand, our earnings are up proportionally. So we are pricing at what we need to price for it to make sense for our business in China. We're achieving that pricing in our charters and our contracts and our distributors. And obviously, they have to win as well. And they won't be in the business if they're not winning but they're in the business. And so I think that overall things again, in a market that's really so sizable and we had such an early beginning that we have such low penetration for a market of that scale. I think we're in good shape going forward.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Jamie Katz with Morningstar.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Jamie Katz with Morningstar.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the double-digit ROIC goals. And I know in the past, you guys had mentioned that the Carnival brand, I think, was already yielding double digits. So I'm curious if most of the other brands are sort of catching up to speed or if the
componenttext: My first question is on the double-digit ROIC goals. And I know in the past, you guys had mentioned that the Carnival brand, I think, was already yielding double digits. So I'm curious if most of the other brands are sort of catching up to speed or if the brands tend to be up bifurcated some way, and maybe it might take a little longer for some of the underperforming brands to catch up.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said in the past, we expect to achieve double-digit return on invested capital. Earlier this year, we said in the next 2 to 3 years. At the end of this year, will be the next 1 to 2 years. We are going to approach 9% return on invested capital
componenttext: Well, as we said in the past, we expect to achieve double-digit return on invested capital. Earlier this year, we said in the next 2 to 3 years. At the end of this year, will be the next 1 to 2 years. We are going to approach 9% return on invested capital this year. So that's the time for what you can expect going forward. So on balance, we're going to get there. You're right, we did share Carnival brand itself was already a double-digit return on invested capital. We have other brands that are. And overall, we will be there across the base of our business [indiscernible].

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are differences between the brands but we generally don't provide detail by brand.
componenttext: There are differences between the brands but we generally don't provide detail by brand.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then do you guys want to offer any color on early reads on I mean, how you guys are thinking about that brand going forward, whether maybe it can be a much more important part of the business down the road just by the early demand you've seen. I
componenttext: Okay. And then do you guys want to offer any color on early reads on I mean, how you guys are thinking about that brand going forward, whether maybe it can be a much more important part of the business down the road just by the early demand you've seen. I know it's only one ship but just curious if you have any commentary.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Yes, it is only one ship. For the Dominican Republic part of the story. Those that have gone have loved the experience and thought that they were personally transformed, et cetera. It's a different targeted segment, it's travel segment more tha
componenttext: Thank you. Yes, it is only one ship. For the Dominican Republic part of the story. Those that have gone have loved the experience and thought that they were personally transformed, et cetera. It's a different targeted segment, it's travel segment more than a cruise segment. And our ability to access that segment is challenging. We remain very optimistic about the brand but the reality is we have to see the bookings from that segment. With regards to Cuba, where we literally made history through the Fathom brand, our fall bookings are very strong for Cuba. We got a late approval. The summer has not been full although the experience has been phenomenal. We do have opportunities remaining on some of the summer sailings into Cuba, and we'll just have to let it play out. And the team's done a marvelous job of the on the ground product and the ship onboard product for DR. And obviously, we're honored and privileged and somewhat humbled to be the first one in Cuba.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to drill a little bit further into your bookings for the third and the fourth quarter in Europe just to get a sense of the visibility but also the risk. How booked are you for the European brands in the third and the fourth quarters?
componenttext: I wanted to drill a little bit further into your bookings for the third and the fourth quarter in Europe just to get a sense of the visibility but also the risk. How booked are you for the European brands in the third and the fourth quarters?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally speaking, we give -- we don't give a little details by brand, but for the third quarter, we're generally 80% to 90% booked has been the historic range. And for the quarter, the fourth quarter, which will be 1 quarter out, it would be 50% to 70%
componenttext: Generally speaking, we give -- we don't give a little details by brand, but for the third quarter, we're generally 80% to 90% booked has been the historic range. And for the quarter, the fourth quarter, which will be 1 quarter out, it would be 50% to 70% booked. Now, I think on the last call, I said we were sort of in the middle of those ranges or maybe that was the December call, I don't remember exactly. And the booking curve has continued to move out so we're a little bit higher than the midpoint of those ranges. Every brand has a slightly different booking curve and that has to do with the nationalities and the people. And so there are differences between the brands all around the world, but it's more cultural than economic, generally speaking. So hopefully that gives you enough color to make some judgments.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then recently, have you seen any deviations from those trends? Do you expect the kind of the slope of the line to continue to trend in the same pattern that it's done recently?
componenttext: And then recently, have you seen any deviations from those trends? Do you expect the kind of the slope of the line to continue to trend in the same pattern that it's done recently?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No significant deviations. I mean, generally speaking, the booking curve all around the globe has been moving out somewhat. And we feel very good about that situation for all the brands.
componenttext: No significant deviations. I mean, generally speaking, the booking curve all around the globe has been moving out somewhat. And we feel very good about that situation for all the brands.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And moving over to China for my second question, there seems to be a fair amount of debate over the relationships with the charter operators. Do you have any -- you mentioned that your earnings have grown in line with your capacity growth. Do you expect t
componenttext: And moving over to China for my second question, there seems to be a fair amount of debate over the relationships with the charter operators. Do you have any -- you mentioned that your earnings have grown in line with your capacity growth. Do you expect that to continue as you look into the capacity that you're introducing in 2017? And the reason that I ask the question is that there seems to be some pushback on -- from some investors in China that with another year of such large supply growth, that there's going to be a -- you're going to hit a demand wall.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, just to put things in perspective again, while the percentages sound so large, it's the equivalent of moving one additional ship down to a market that in time is going to be far larger than the North America market and could be as large the entire
componenttext: Again, just to put things in perspective again, while the percentages sound so large, it's the equivalent of moving one additional ship down to a market that in time is going to be far larger than the North America market and could be as large the entire global cruise market is right now. So while there may be some bumps and temporary discontinuities as distributors ramp up with their own personnel to move the volume of cruises all those other type of travel products obviously and there might be some bumps along those lines, overall, China remains a robust opportunity, and we're still at the very, very beginning of it. So I don't see that. You're going to have some negotiations going on. Everybody wants a better price. It is a B2B business almost now, and of course, will be negotiations trying to get lower prices better returns or what-have-you. But overall things are very good. The cruise product that we offer is well received and excellent. We're going to have our first purpose-built ship, the Majestic Princess, going in next year. She's being met with very, very positive response by the distributors already. And we have our first ship, AIDA as I mentioned, going in next year. And then we have our base for Costa and the rest of the Princess. But on balance, it's the equivalent of adding one ship. And so we'll be going from 5% of our capacity to 6% of our capacity, which is large at all even with the industry moving in a few additional ships it's that can be managed may be a bumpy are in the road here or there. But over time, it's going to be great and we do expect to see continued earnings improvement directional with the expansion.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And keep in mind, we're also expanding the number of offices we have in China. We're now up to 12 offices and there are more to be opened. We're working with more and more travel agents and expanding that base. Plus we continue to educate the travel agent
componenttext: And keep in mind, we're also expanding the number of offices we have in China. We're now up to 12 offices and there are more to be opened. We're working with more and more travel agents and expanding that base. Plus we continue to educate the travel agents on more about cruising and how to better sell cruises. So we continue to expand the opportunity in the marketplace as well as really as Arnold indicated, it's really just one additional -- the equivalent one additional 4,000-passenger ship, entering a huge market with tremendous opportunity.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of just clarification follow-on items. David, on the British pound, that 30%, just to make sure, that was on an annual net income exposure basis?
componenttext: A couple of just clarification follow-on items. David, on the British pound, that 30%, just to make sure, that was on an annual net income exposure basis?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any additional color you could give? I know you got borrowings and everything in euro, but any -- where is the pound, I guess, euro, and maybe a couple other currencies rank annually on that net income exposure basis? Maybe highest to lowest of the top 3,
componenttext: Any additional color you could give? I know you got borrowings and everything in euro, but any -- where is the pound, I guess, euro, and maybe a couple other currencies rank annually on that net income exposure basis? Maybe highest to lowest of the top 3, 4, 5, whatever you want to feel comfortable in providing and if so, the percentages?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the Aussie dollar is probably about 35%. I think historically, I have told everybody that the British pound and the Aussie dollar represented 2/3 of our currency exposure. The remaining exposure is -- you've got the Canadian dollar, the euro and the
componenttext: Well, the Aussie dollar is probably about 35%. I think historically, I have told everybody that the British pound and the Aussie dollar represented 2/3 of our currency exposure. The remaining exposure is -- you've got the Canadian dollar, the euro and the Chinese renminbi. And those 3 are probably about 10% apiece. And this is, of course, all from a net income bottom line exposure. We have a lot more than 10% of our business in euros, but we also have a lot of expenses in euros, which net out the exposure when you get to the bottom line.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. Great, helpful. And then the other question and we get it -- we're getting it more frequently, is given some Asian-based competitors adding, buying and then therefore adding apparent capacity long term, it would appear that if we go out '18, '
componenttext: Okay, okay. Great, helpful. And then the other question and we get it -- we're getting it more frequently, is given some Asian-based competitors adding, buying and then therefore adding apparent capacity long term, it would appear that if we go out '18, '19, you could see some years of 6% capacity growth on a gross basis for the industry. Arnold, any color on that, maybe how that would shake out net or majority of the capacity also would be in China? Just any additional thoughts or color on that looking out '18 and beyond.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our commitment is definitely to measure capacity growth, measure supply growth. And as we are delivering double-digit return and as the ships we have do that, we will retain those ships in the fleet. As they don't do that, then obviously we would not
componenttext: Yes, our commitment is definitely to measure capacity growth, measure supply growth. And as we are delivering double-digit return and as the ships we have do that, we will retain those ships in the fleet. As they don't do that, then obviously we would not. But we are totally committed to measure capacity growth and given the large number of ships we have [indiscernible] represent that influences overall global capacity for the industry. So yes, a lot of the capacity growth are going to see us give already identified is targeted in China, which means the rest of the market, the rest of the world, [indiscernible] 95% of today's capacity is not seeing very much growth. And things change for whatever reason which we don't anticipate but if they were to change, we can easily modify change our strategy. We will always want the new ships because they're more efficient, more cost-effective. And so you'd always want the new ships and at the timing of moving out the ships that are less efficient and generate returns.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would you anticipate that number for the industry to maybe come down? Would you anticipate some higher scrappage rates going forward global [indiscernible].
componenttext: And would you anticipate that number for the industry to maybe come down? Would you anticipate some higher scrappage rates going forward global [indiscernible].

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, it depends on the demand in the market, right? So for us, things are robust. Keep in mind that the industry overall is underpenetrated. In our case with 10 brands, we have a huge base of people that have experienced cruise and love it. Cruise i
componenttext: Right now, it depends on the demand in the market, right? So for us, things are robust. Keep in mind that the industry overall is underpenetrated. In our case with 10 brands, we have a huge base of people that have experienced cruise and love it. Cruise is still the best vacation value there is. It's a tremendous vacation experience. Onboard revenues have grown every year in the cruise industry, except for us our onboard revenues have grown every year, except 1 year in the whole history of the time we've been in the business. And so we can look back doing fine and as in all kinds of environments, [indiscernible] recessionary environments, price environments, everything. So underpenetrated, big base of people who already want a cruise, great dynamics. It's hard to say but I don't anticipate acceleration of retirements of ships. But the point is we have global assets. We have a number of triggers we can pull, and we can do what we need to do because we are committed to double-digit return on invested capital and sustaining that.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from the line of Jared Shojaian with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from the line of Jared Shojaian with Wolfe Research.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Arnold, you talked about a 5% reduction in European capacity and 5% increase in the Caribbean. So my question is what are you seeing from competitors on global redeployment? And what gives you confidence that we won't have a repeat of 2014 when the Caribb
componenttext: Arnold, you talked about a 5% reduction in European capacity and 5% increase in the Caribbean. So my question is what are you seeing from competitors on global redeployment? And what gives you confidence that we won't have a repeat of 2014 when the Caribbean became oversupplied?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the near term, it's not going to happen because the deployments are mostly transparent at this point. So that's the best indication is that we kind of can see a lot of where the ships are going already. So you won't see a 2014 explosion of Caribb
componenttext: Well, in the near term, it's not going to happen because the deployments are mostly transparent at this point. So that's the best indication is that we kind of can see a lot of where the ships are going already. So you won't see a 2014 explosion of Caribbean capacity like in 2017. You won't see that. So having said that, that can still be additional capacity Caribbean because strong now for us, and I'm sure, it is for others too. And similarly to the extent possible in Alaska as well. We are anticipating that. Every year, there's overcapacity somewhere and so on and so forth. And again, we have lots of different ways to manage our business to ensure that we deliver the results we are committed to delivering, which is double-digit return on invested capital. But we don't anticipate an explosion in the Caribbean like you saw in 2014.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind that when we planned the 2014 deployments, our brands were not coordinating their own -- the deployment within our own company. So a number of individual brands each made with really good decisions. Now the deployment is well coordinated with
componenttext: Keep in mind that when we planned the 2014 deployments, our brands were not coordinating their own -- the deployment within our own company. So a number of individual brands each made with really good decisions. Now the deployment is well coordinated within our company and has more visibility across the whole corporation, which is how we wound up with the 5%.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. The 5% for us compares to a 20% [ph] growth we had in 2014 so it's considerably different.
componenttext: Right. The 5% for us compares to a 20% [ph] growth we had in 2014 so it's considerably different.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I just want to follow up on some of that capacity commentary because it's still -- I mean, it feels like a lot of investors are still pretty concerned about the amount of industry growth over the next several years. So what leverage do you
componenttext: Okay. And then I just want to follow up on some of that capacity commentary because it's still -- I mean, it feels like a lot of investors are still pretty concerned about the amount of industry growth over the next several years. So what leverage do you have to pull if you need to? I mean, you talked about the retirements, but I mean why wouldn't reducing utilization work? I mean, is that one opportunity? Or are there other areas that you see? Just love to hear about any flexibility you think you have there.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, you want the new ships because they're more efficient. So -- and inherently, they can give you a better return. So the new ships will come. The question is what do you do with the other ships. And as long as they're returning, you'll keep them and
componenttext: Again, you want the new ships because they're more efficient. So -- and inherently, they can give you a better return. So the new ships will come. The question is what do you do with the other ships. And as long as they're returning, you'll keep them and the demand is there. There's growth in China, Cuba opens up. There's renewed interest in the Caribbean, and so on and growth prospects for the Caribbean. All those things are drivers that can help give you yields and returns on some of the existing fleet. So the lever is pretty straightforward. You'll be able to tell what ships are performing and which ones aren't. And if you don't have a good redeployment plan, that would make sense to exit.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, on -- you had some realized gains on fuel derivatives for 2016. I think you said it was $330 million in March. Can you tell us what it [indiscernible] at now? And then your marketing programs shifted. What specifically was shif
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, on -- you had some realized gains on fuel derivatives for 2016. I think you said it was $330 million in March. Can you tell us what it [indiscernible] at now? And then your marketing programs shifted. What specifically was shifted and what was the rationale? And then [indiscernible] retrofit, are we going to see more Cunard and Queen ships follow-up couple of years?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll take the first question, Steve. In terms of realized losses on fuel derivatives, it's $285 million that was built into our June guidance as a result of the change in Brent, which moved up, the losses came down just a little bit. In terms of adv
componenttext: Okay. I'll take the first question, Steve. In terms of realized losses on fuel derivatives, it's $285 million that was built into our June guidance as a result of the change in Brent, which moved up, the losses came down just a little bit. In terms of advertising built into the guidance, I mean, it was -- these are small movements that the brands planned well ahead and make decisions over time based off of what they see happening in booking trends and other things. And they will reseasonalize. Keep in mind, every good plan has got to change as you see movement. It's no different when we see strength in bookings, we raise prices. We make changes over time. So that's really essentially is not a big deal, and it's just some seasonalization between the quarters.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We manage to yield. We don't manage to a time frame. And so costs can move in and out quarters but we're managing to yield and return. What was the question on the Queen Mary?
componenttext: We manage to yield. We don't manage to a time frame. And so costs can move in and out quarters but we're managing to yield and return. What was the question on the Queen Mary?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Cunard, the Queens, are we going to see more Cunard ships?
componenttext: The Cunard, the Queens, are we going to see more Cunard ships?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are we going to see more ships in Cunard?
componenttext: Are we going to see more ships in Cunard?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible].
componenttext: [indiscernible].

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry?
componenttext: I'm sorry?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I asked, are you going to retrofit more of the Queen?
componenttext: I asked, are you going to retrofit more of the Queen?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Retrofit.
componenttext: Retrofit.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Basically, Queen Mary 2 went into a dry-dock. The ships [indiscernible] 3 to 5 years depending on the class of ship. And the others are practically new, have gone through a dry dock recently. So it's just part of dry-dock. On the other hand, Queen Mar
componenttext: No. Basically, Queen Mary 2 went into a dry-dock. The ships [indiscernible] 3 to 5 years depending on the class of ship. And the others are practically new, have gone through a dry dock recently. So it's just part of dry-dock. On the other hand, Queen Mary 2, there was a remaster I mean, she is the only ocean liner out there and we're very, very proud of her. Wherever she goes, she's still iconic. People gather by the thousands and tens of thousands to see her sail in and sail out. And so we take great pride [indiscernible] also, we can generate the yield from the additional investments. So we did a remastering of the Queen Mary 2 versus just a traditional kind of dry-dock refresh.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Jamie Rollo with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Jamie Rollo with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few questions on China, first of all, please. Could you giveu s [indiscernible] for roughly how much your yields are down by year-on-year just sort of directionally? And what the yield premium is to the rest of the group now, please.
componenttext: Just a few questions on China, first of all, please. Could you giveu s [indiscernible] for roughly how much your yields are down by year-on-year just sort of directionally? And what the yield premium is to the rest of the group now, please.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- we've said all along, the yields are down. We had previously indicated that the ticket prices were higher than fleet average. And at this point in time, the ticket prices are in line with the overall fleet average, but it's really an apples a
componenttext: Well, the -- we've said all along, the yields are down. We had previously indicated that the ticket prices were higher than fleet average. And at this point in time, the ticket prices are in line with the overall fleet average, but it's really an apples and oranges comparison because in China, you've got a much higher percentage of the fleet is in the contemporary brands. And so you're comparing apples and oranges when you're taking the average China ticket yields to the overall fleet average ticket yields. So keep that in mind as you evaluate the numbers.

In terms of the third quarter, they way it works from an accounting perspective is the exchange rate gets locked in for accounting when the people pay for their cruise. From an actual exchange of physical currencies from one to another, we do that, generally speaking, on a daily or a weekly basis, depending on what currencies we need. We do have bills in British pound, we retain those currencies. And the extra we do exchange into U.S. dollars or Euros or whatever currency we're short.

componenttext: Keep in mind, there's 26,000 travel agents in China. About 2,600 of them have outbound licenses. And so what we're seeing happening is, while there's a small group that tends to charter, let's say, the full, we're probably dealing with 250 to 300 agents who are doing large groups and chartering part of a ship at this point in time. But those 250 or 300 travel agents are also selling through the other 24,000 travel agents around the country. That's why Arnold called like subagents and they're selling into these groups and charters. So it's a tremendous distribution system, and it can be leveraged and part of the reason why we're so optimistic about the growth in China, tremendous opportunity.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I am Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning.Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; Davi
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I am Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning.
Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; David Bernstein, our Chief Financial Officer; and Beth Roberts, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations.
Before I begin, as always, please note that some of our remarks on this call will be forward looking. Therefore, I must refer you to the cautionary statement in today's press release.
We delivered the strongest second quarter in the history of our company with record adjusted earnings per share nearly double the prior year and well above the high end of our March guidance range. The second quarter results, combined with our strong book position, has enabled us to maintain the midpoint of our full year guidance range despite a $0.17 drag from fuel and currency. Essentially, the strength in underlying demand for our products fostered greater ticket prices in both the quarter and in the remainder of the year, offsetting the rise in fuel prices since the time of our last guidance as well as the very recent significant movements in currency exchange rates following the Brexit vote.
Our record results reflect our passionate 120,000-plus employees, who in their efforts go above and beyond every day and who together with our hundreds of thousands of travel partners are the foundation of our sustained earnings improvement.
This was among the most remarkable quarters in the history of the company not only because of our record-breaking financial results but because of a significant number of milestones which will contribute meaningfully to our future success.
We introduced 3 new flagships, including Carnival Vista, purposely designed for our fun-loving Carnival Cruise Line guest with an onboard brewery experience, entertaining IMAX theater and exhilarating SkyRide experience. Carnival Vista has already generated over 1 billion media impressions. Holland America Line's Koningsdam, christened in Rotterdam by Her Majesty Queen Maxima of the Netherlands delivers a new premium experience where our guests can blend their own wine, enjoy high-end slice [ph] of scotch or dance the night away in our carefully engineered Music Walk. And last but not least, the AIDAprima made its debut with a spectacular live show, fireworks and memorable naming ceremony witnessed by over 1 million people gathered in Hamburg. These well-publicized introductions are certain to continue to stimulate increased consideration for cruising within our portfolio of the world's leading cruise lines.
Moreover, we welcomed our 10th brand, Fathom, in April, with the inaugural impact sailing to the Dominican Republic to do good [ph], followed by a historic first sailing for Cuba in May. Bar none, one of the most publicized events in the history of the cruise industry was our inaugural voyage to Cuba, with over 20 billion media impressions, bringing the cumulative total media impressions for Carnival and Cuba to nearly 55 billion to date. We could not have been more proud than when our General Counsel Arnie Perez and his wife Carmen, both Cuban born, were first to disembark when we made history as the first U.S. cruise line in more than 40 years to sail for Cuba. Having sailed there myself, I can assure you there is no better way to experience Cuba today than on our Fathom brand. We are working hard to enable more of our brands to bring guests to Cuba in the near future, a promising long-term driver of continued demand for our Caribbean itineraries.
Indeed, we have had an eventful quarter.
Returning to the financials.
China, which is definitely the world's largest cruise market, continues to deliver accretive returns on invested capital. We again achieved significant earnings growth this quarter and continue to fully expect earnings growth for the full year directionally proportionate with our over 60% capacity increase. In China, our occupancy levels remain comparable to the high levels we have consistently achieved as we introduced hundreds of thousands of new-to-cruise to our brands. Yes, the penetration level for this sizable and rapidly expanding addressable market is well below 1%, just a fraction of the more developed cruise markets. While these guests sail mostly within Asia today, over time, we have an opportunity to take them to all the great destinations our ships sailed and they have not yet been, like the unique beauty of Venice and the amazing glaciers in Glacier Bay, Alaska.
We remain confident in the long-term development of the cruise industry in China, with our capacity growth expected to be up over 30% in 2017. Now that's following the over 60% increase we observed in 2016. These large year-over-year percentage increases are on a very small base, so these growth rates are already equivalent to adding about one 4,000-berth vessel each year. As a result, China represents less than 5% of our global capacity this year and will grow to just 6% next year after the entry of Majestic Princess, the first purpose-built ship for Chinese guests; and AIDAbella, the first ship in China for our AIDA brand. Of course, the capacity shift to China helps create relative scarcity in our other markets, supporting global revenue yield growth. We remain confident in the outlook for measured supply growth. In 2017, our global supply growth is just 2.7%.
Within that, we are rebalancing our portfolio to optimize the current demand environment. We expect a 5% capacity reduction in Europe, stemming from a capacity reduction in the Mediterranean region which is down over 10%. We expect a modest 5% and 3% growth in capacity in the more robust Caribbean and Alaska deployments, respectively. On the margin, these deployment changes should contribute to yield next year.
During the quarter, we continued to make progress on our cross-brand efforts to leverage our scale. On the revenue side, work on our revenue yield optimizing system continues; and as previously noted, will be rolled out on 30% of our inventory across 6 of our brands this summer. We are on track to begin prototype testing in July. Even their early stage of implementation will [indiscernible] the yield uplift as we refine our modeling techniques to contribute to enhanced demand forecasting. So as most of this year's bookings will be behind us by the summer, we continue to expect a greater contribution from this effort in 2017.
And on the cost side, work in our procurement area continues. We remain on track to our stated $75 million of expected cost savings in 2016. Most recently, we announced a strategic coordination of our global media planning and buying for our 7 brands in North America and the U.K., generating significant double-digit savings on our $100 million annual media spend.
Our record quarterly results and our strong book position are a testament to the success of our ongoing strategy to drive demand well in excess of our measured capacity growth. All things considered, bookings for our ships sailing to Europe has held up well. And bookings in the Caribbean and Alaska for the remainder of the year are very strong for our brands, enabling us to raise our revenue yield expectations and affirming our conviction to deliver over 20% earnings growth this year.
We are on track for the delivery of nearly 9% return on invested capital this year and remain well on track in accelerating progress towards a double-digit threshold, again given our ongoing efforts to create demand in excess of supply, coupled with our revenue management enhancements and opportunity to further leverage our scale. Despite the geopolitical events in Europe, including the Brexit vote, we remain confident in our long-term outlook given the attractive value proposition our strong and diversified brand portfolio offers, particularly in the U.K. where our local brands P&O Cruises and Cunard, sold in British pounds, have an increasingly competitive advantage to land-based vacation alternatives in Europe and abroad.
Our increasingly strong cash flow enables us to accelerate distributions to our shareholders. Since resuming our stock repurchase program late last year, we're nearing completion on our second $1 billion share repurchase authorization, bringing the cumulative total of repurchases to date to approximately $1.9 billion and 38 million shares. In addition, recently, we announced our second dividend increase inside of a year, bringing our annual dividend distribution to over $1 billion. We plan to continue to return free cash flow and more to shareholders with our strong balance sheet and leverage ratios now comfortably at the better end of our targeted range. Our sustained earnings improvement, coupled with our strong balance sheet, has resulted in Moody's upgrading our credit rating from Baa1 to A3; and just yesterday, our Board of Directors authorizing our third $1 billion share repurchase program, all of which demonstrate continued confidence in the realization of sustained double-digit return on invested capital, which our company is inherently capable of delivering.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to David.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arnold.Before I begin, please note all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 second quarter results. Then I'll provide som
componenttext:
Thank you, Arnold.
Before I begin, please note all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 second quarter results. Then I'll provide some insights on booking trends and finish up with an update on our full year 2016 guidance.
Our record adjusted EPS for the second quarter was $0.49. This was $0.13 above the midpoint of our March guidance. The improvement was essentially driven by 2 things: $0.05 from net revenue yields which benefited from stronger pricing on close-in bookings at our North American brands; and $0.06 from lower net cruise costs, excluding fuel, as a result of timing of certain expenses between the quarters.
Now let's look at our second quarter operating results versus the prior year. Our capacity increased 2%. The North American brands were flat, while the European, Australia and Asian brands, also known as our EAA brands, were up over 5%. Our total net revenue yields were up 3.6%. Now let's break apart the 2 components of net revenue yields. Net ticket yields were up 3.5%. The increase was driven by our North American brands' deployment in the Caribbean and Alaska. Net onboard and other yields increased almost 4%, with increases on both sides of the Atlantic, mainly related to bar and casino. Net cruise costs per ALBD, excluding fuel, were down almost 2%, which is about a 3-point improvement versus what was planned in our March guidance, but again this was due to the timing of expenses between the quarters.
In summary, our record second quarter adjusted EPS was almost double the prior year or $0.24 higher, driven by operational improvements worth $0.18, a favorable net impact of lower fuel prices and currency worth $0.04 and share buyback accretion worth $0.02.
Now let's turn to booking trends. Since March, bookings for the remainder of the year are at higher prices, with less inventory remaining for sale than at the same time last year. At this points in time, for the remaining 2 quarters of 2016, cumulative bookings are well ahead at slightly higher prices. The fact that we are well ahead on the book position with less inventory left to sell for the remainder of the year compared to last year, even with our capacity increase, bodes well for pricing over the next few months.
Now let's drill down into the cumulative book position. First, for our North American brands, Caribbean occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at nicely higher prices. For Alaska, occupancy is in line with the prior year also at nicely higher prices. For the seasonal European program, occupancy is ahead of the prior year at lower prices driven by geopolitical risk impacting the Mediterranean trade as anticipated in our guidance. Secondly, for our EAA brands: For Europe, occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at higher prices. Australia and Asia are consistent with our previous guidance. As expected, we are behind on pricing given our 60% increase in China capacity and our 15% increase in Australia capacity.
For 2017, we continue to move out the booking curve. At this point in time, for the first 3 quarters of 2017, cumulative fleet-wide bookings are well ahead at prices that are in line with 2016. And recent trends have been very positive with robust booking activity at slightly higher prices. These are early indications for 2017, and I do caution you not to read too much into these trends.
Finally, I want to provide you with an update on our full year 2016 guidance. As Arnold indicated, our second quarter results, combined with a strong book position, enabled us to maintain the midpoint of our previous guidance range. This is actually a $0.17 improvement offset by a $0.17 drag from fuel prices and currency.
Our 2016 June guidance is $3.25 to $3.35. The $0.17 improvement compared to our March guidance was essentially driven by 3 things: one, improved net revenue yields worth $0.10, $0.05 of which was achieved in the second quarter and an additional $0.05 we expect to achieve in net ticket revenues during the remainder of the year; second, lower net cruise costs, excluding fuel, worth $0.03; and third, the accretive impact from the additional shares we purchased since our March guidance call worth $0.03.
Net cruise costs without fuel per ALBD are now expected to be up approximately 1.5% for 2016, 0.5 points better than our March guidance. Remember that while the yield is expected to be up approximately 1.5%, there are differences between the quarters. The first quarter was up about 1.5 points, while the second quarter was down almost 2%. However, as I mentioned during the last earnings call and taking into account the reseasonalization of our planned second quarter costs into the second half of the year, we expect third quarter net cruise costs without fuel per ALBD to be up 6% to 7%, driven by the timing of advertising expense and the remastering of Queen Mary 2 in dry dock. The expectation for the fourth quarter is that costs will be flat.
At the midpoint of our June guidance, net cash provided by operating activities is approaching $5 billion. As Arnold indicated, with such strong cash flows since late last year, we repurchased approximately 38 million of our shares, and our Board of Directors authorized a third $1 billion stock buyback program yesterday. In addition, we still have about $100 million remaining on our second $1 billion stock buyback authorization.
Our June guidance EPS calculation assumes shares repurchased through last week. For the full year, the calculations assume approximately 750 million shares outstanding on a weighted average basis, while for the third quarter, the calculations assume 743 million shares outstanding.
On a final note, given the volatility of FX rates since the Brexit vote, we want to share with you our current rules of thumb about the impact that currency and fuel prices can have on our 2016 results. To start with, a 10% change in all relevant currencies relative to the U.S. dollar would impact our P&L by approximately $0.18 for the remainder of the year and $0.09 for the third quarter. For fuel price changes, a 10% change in the current spot price represents a $0.07 impact for the remainder of the year and $0.04 for the third quarter. Fuel expense in our guidance is about $920 million for the full year. The third rule of thumb relates to our fuel derivative portfolio. A 10% change in Brent would result in a $0.03 change in realized losses on fuel derivatives for the remainder of the year and $0.02 for the third quarter.
And now I'll turn it back over to Arnold.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
