headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I'm Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc. Thank you, all, for joining us this morning.Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; Dav
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I'm Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc. Thank you, all, for joining us this morning.
Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; David Bernstein, our Chief Financial Officer; and Beth Roberts, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations.
Before I begin, as always, please note that some of our remarks on this call will be forward looking. Therefore, I must refer you to the cautionary statement in today's press release.
We delivered the strongest second quarter in the history of our company with record adjusted earnings per share nearly double the prior year and well above the high end of our March guidance range. The second quarter results combined with our strong book position has enabled us to maintain the midpoint of our full year guidance range despite a $0.17 drag from fuel and currency. Essentially, the strength and underlying demand for our products fostered greater ticket prices in both the quarter and in the remainder of the year, offsetting the rise in fuel prices since the time of our last guidance as well as the very recent significant movements in currency exchange rates following the Brexit vote.
Our record results reflect our passionate 120,000-plus employees, who in their efforts go above and beyond every day and who together with our hundreds of thousands of travel partners are the foundation of our sustained earnings improvement.
This was among the most remarkable quarters in the history of the company not only because of our record-breaking financial results but because of a significant number of milestones which will contribute meaningfully to our future success.
We introduced 3 new flagships, including Carnival Vista, purposely designed for our fun-loving Carnival Cruise Line guest with an onboard brewery experience, entertaining IMAX theater and exhilarating SkyRide experience. Carnival Vista has already generated over 1 billion media impressions. Holland America Line's Koningsdam, christened in Rotterdam by Her Majesty Queen Maxima of the Netherlands delivers a new premium experience where our guests can blend their own wine, enjoy high-end slice [ph] of scotch or dance the night away in our carefully engineered Music Walk. And last but not least, the AIDAprima made its debut with a spectacular light show, fireworks and memorable naming ceremony witnessed by over 1 million people gathered in Hamburg. These well-publicized introductions are certain to continue to stimulate increased consideration for cruising within our portfolio of the world's leading cruise lines.
Moreover, we welcomed our 10th brand, Fathom, in April, with the inaugural impact sailing to the Dominican Republic to do good [ph], followed by a historic first sailing for Cuba in May. Bar none, one of the most publicized events in the history of the cruise industry was our inaugural voyage to Cuba, with over 20 billion media impressions, bringing the cumulative total media impressions for Carnival and Cuba to nearly 55 billion to date. We could not have been more proud than when our General Counsel Arnie Perez and his wife Carmen, both Cuban born, were first to disembark when we made history as the first U.S. cruise line in more than 40 years to sail for Cuba. Having sailed there myself, I can assure you there is no better way to experience Cuba today than on our Fathom brand. We are working hard to enable more of our brands to bring guests to Cuba in the near future, a promising long-term driver of continued demand for our Caribbean itineraries.
Indeed, we have had an eventful quarter.
Returning to the financials.
China, which is definitely the world's largest cruise market, continues to deliver accretive returns on invested capital. We again achieved significant earnings growth this quarter and continue to fully expect earnings growth for the full year directionally proportionate with our over 60% capacity increase. In China, our occupancy levels remain comparable to the high levels we have consistently achieved as we introduced hundreds of thousands of new-to-cruise to our brands. Yes, the penetration level for this sizable and rapidly expanding addressable market is well below 1%, just a fraction of the more developed cruise markets. While these guests sail mostly within Asia today, over time, we have an opportunity to take them to all the great destinations our ships sailed and they have not yet been, like the unique beauty of Venice and the amazing glaciers in Glacier Bay, Alaska.
We remain confident in the long-term development of the cruise industry in China, with our capacity growth expected to be up over 30% in 2017. Now that's following the over 60% increase observed in 2016. These large year-over-year percentage increases are on a very small base, so these growth rates are an equivalent to adding about one 4,000-berth vessel each year. As a result, China represents less than 5% of our global capacity this year and will grow to just 6% next year after the entry of Majestic Princess, the first purpose-built ship for Chinese guests; and AIDAbella, the first ship in China for our AIDA brand. Of course, the capacity shift to China helps create relative scarcity in our other markets, supporting global revenue yield growth. We remain confident in the outlook for measured supply growth. In 2017, our global supply growth is just 2.7%.
Within that, we are rebalancing our portfolio to optimize the current demand environment. We expect a 5% capacity reduction in Europe, stemming from a capacity reduction in the Mediterranean region which is down over 10%. We expect a modest 5% and 3% growth in capacity in the more robust Caribbean and Alaska deployments, respectively. On the margin, these deployment changes should contribute to yield next year.
During the quarter, we continue to make progress on our cross-brand efforts to leverage our scale. On the revenue side, work on our revenue yield optimizing system continues; and as previously noted, will be rolled out on 30% of our inventory across 6 of our brands this summer. We are on track to begin prototype testing in July. Even the early stage of implementation will foster yield uplift as we refine our modeling techniques to contribute to enhanced demand forecasting. So as most of this year's bookings will be behind us by the summer, we continue to expect a greater contribution from this effort in 2017.
And on the cost side, work in our procurement area continues. We remain on track for our stated $75 million of expected cost savings in 2016. Most recently, we announced a strategic coordination of our global media planning and buying for our 7 brands in North America and the U.K., generating a significant double-digit savings on our $100 million annual media spend.
Our record quarterly results and our strong book position are a testament to the success of our ongoing strategy to drive demand well in excess of our measured capacity growth. All things considered, bookings for our ships sailing to Europe has held up well. And bookings in the Caribbean and Alaska for the remainder of the year are very strong for our brands, enabling us to raise our revenue yield expectations and affirming our conviction to deliver over 20% earnings growth this year.
We are on track for the delivery of nearly 9% return on invested capital this year and remain well on track in accelerating progress towards a double-digit threshold, again given our ongoing efforts to create demand in excess of supply, coupled with our revenue management enhancements and opportunity to further leverage our scale. Despite the geopolitical events in Europe, including the Brexit vote, we remain confident in our long-term outlook given the attractive value proposition our strong and diversified brand portfolio offers, particularly in the U.K. where our local brands P&O Cruises and Cunard, sold in British pounds, have an increasingly competitive advantage to land-based vacation alternatives in Europe and abroad.
Our increasingly strong cash flow enables us to accelerate distributions to our shareholders. Since resuming our stock repurchase program late last year, we're nearing completion on our second $1 billion share repurchase authorization, bringing the cumulative total of repurchases to date to approximately $1.9 billion and 38 million shares. In addition, recently, we announced our second dividend increase inside of a year, bringing our annual dividend distribution to over $1 billion. We plan to continue to return free cash flow and more to shareholders with our strong balance sheet and leverage ratios now comfortably at the better end of our targeted range. Our sustained earnings improvement, coupled with our strong balance sheet, has resulted in Moody's upgrading our credit rating from Baa1 to A3; and just yesterday, our Board of Directors authorizing our third $1 billion share repurchase program, all of which demonstrate continued confidence in the realization of sustained double-digit return on invested capital, which our company is inherently capable of delivering.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to David.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arnold.Before I begin, please note all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 second quarter results. Then I'll provide som
componenttext:
Thank you, Arnold.
Before I begin, please note all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 second quarter results. Then I'll provide some insights on booking trends and finish up with an update on our full year 2016 guidance.
Our record adjusted EPS for the second quarter was $0.49. This was $0.13 above the midpoint of our March guidance. The improvement was essentially driven by 2 things: $0.05 from net revenue yields which benefited from stronger pricing on close-in bookings at our North American brands; and $0.06 from lower net cruise costs, excluding fuel, as a result of timing of certain expenses between the quarters.
Now let's look at our second quarter operating results versus the prior year. Our capacity increased 2%. The North American brands were flat, while the European, Australia and Asian brands, also known as our EAA brands, were up over 5%. Our total net revenue yields were up 3.6%. Now let's break apart the 2 components of net revenue yields. Net ticket yields were up 3.5%. The increase was driven by our North American brands' deployment in the Caribbean and Alaska. Net onboard and other yields increased almost 4%, with increases on both sides of the Atlantic, mainly related to bar and casino. Net cruise costs per ALBD, excluding fuel, were down almost 2%, which is about a 3-point improvement versus what was planned in our March guidance, but again this was due to the timing of expenses between the quarters.
In summary, our record second quarter adjusted EPS was almost double the prior year or $0.24 higher, driven by operational improvements worth $0.18, a favorable net impact of lower fuel prices and currency worth $0.04 and share buyback accretion worth $0.02.
Now let's turn to booking trends. Since March, bookings for the remainder of the year are at higher prices, with less inventory remaining for sale than at the same time last year. At this point in time, for the remaining 2 quarters of 2016, cumulative bookings are well ahead at slightly higher prices. The fact that we are well ahead on the book position with less inventory left to sell for the remainder of the year compared to last year, even with our capacity increase, bodes well for pricing over the next few months.
Now let's drill down into the cumulative book position. First, for our North American brands, Caribbean occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at nicely higher prices. For Alaska, occupancy is in line with the prior year also at nicely higher prices. For the seasonal European program, occupancy is ahead of the prior year at lower prices driven by geopolitical risk impacting the Mediterranean trade as anticipated in our guidance. Secondly, for our EAA brands: For Europe, occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at higher prices. Australia and Asia are consistent with our previous guidance. As expected, we are behind on pricing given our 60% increase in China capacity and our 15% increase in Australia capacity.
For 2017, we continue to move out the booking curve. At this point in time, for the first 3 quarters of 2017, cumulative fleet-wide bookings are well ahead at prices that are in line with 2016. And recent trends have been very positive with robust booking activity at slightly higher prices. These are early indications for 2017, and I do caution you not to read too much into these trends.
Finally, I want to provide you with an update on our full year 2016 guidance. As Arnold indicated, our second quarter results, combined with a strong book position, enabled us to maintain the midpoint of our previous guidance range. This is actually a $0.17 improvement offset by a $0.17 drag from fuel prices and currency.
Our 2016 June guidance is $3.25 to $3.35. The $0.17 improvement compared to our March guidance was essentially driven by 3 things: one, improved net revenue yields worth $0.10, $0.05 of which was achieved in the second quarter and an additional $0.05 we expect to achieve in net ticket revenues during the remainder of the year; second, lower net cruise costs, excluding fuel, worth $0.03; and third, the accretive impact from the additional shares we purchased since our March guidance call worth $0.03.
Net cruise costs without fuel per ALBD are now expected to be up approximately 1.5% for 2016, 0.5 points better than our March guidance. Remember that while the yield is expected to be up approximately 1.5%, there are differences between the quarters. The first quarter was up about 1.5 points, while the second quarter was down almost 2%. However, as I mentioned during the last earnings call and taking into account the reseasonalization of our planned second quarter costs into the second half of the year, we expect third quarter net cruise costs without fuel per ALBD to be up 6% to 7%, driven by the timing of advertising expense and the remastering of Queen Mary 2 in dry dock. The expectation for the fourth quarter is that costs will be flat.
At the midpoint of our June guidance, net cash provided by operating activities is approaching $5 billion. As Arnold indicated, with such strong cash flows since late last year, we repurchased approximately 38 million of our shares, and our Board of Directors authorized a third $1 billion stock buyback program yesterday. In addition, we still have about $100 million remaining on our second $1 billion stock buyback authorization.
Our June guidance EPS calculations assumes shares repurchased through last week. For the full year, the calculations assume approximately 750 million shares outstanding on a weighted average basis, while for the third quarter, the calculations assume 743 million shares outstanding.
On a final note, given the volatility of FX rates since the Brexit vote, we want to share with you our current rules of thumb about the impact that currency and fuel prices can have on our 2016 results. To start with, a 10% change in all relevant currencies relative to the U.S. dollar would impact our P&L by approximately $0.18 for the remainder of the year and $0.09 for the third quarter. For fuel price changes, a 10% change in the current spot price represents a $0.07 impact for the remainder of the year and $0.04 for the third quarter. Fuel expense in our guidance is about $920 million for the full year. The third rule of thumb relates to our fuel derivative portfolio. A 10% change in Brent would result in a $0.03 change in realized losses on fuel derivatives for the remainder of the year and $0.02 for the third quarter.
And now I'll turn it back over to Arnold.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David.Operator, please open it up for questions.
componenttext:
Thank you, David.
Operator, please open it up for questions.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question is from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question is from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could give a little color. You're raising your full year yield guidance for the year. Is it China yield coming in line with expectations, like Caribbean coming in better? I wonder if you could throw a little bit of color on how the differe
componenttext: I wonder if you could give a little color. You're raising your full year yield guidance for the year. Is it China yield coming in line with expectations, like Caribbean coming in better? I wonder if you could throw a little bit of color on how the different regions are coming in versus your previous expectations. And also a little bit of Eastern Med, because some investors have been concerned that Eastern Med may be worse than expected. But clearly, overall, things coming in better than expected, so just wondering what areas are driving that more than others.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robin, thanks for your question. Generally speaking, obviously as we said -- just said, that Alaska and the Caribbean are strong, so those primarily North American-sourced then markets definitely are providing a lot of the higher yield expectations. At th
componenttext: Robin, thanks for your question. Generally speaking, obviously as we said -- just said, that Alaska and the Caribbean are strong, so those primarily North American-sourced then markets definitely are providing a lot of the higher yield expectations. At the same time, we are continuing to show strong improvement in Europe from our EAA brands, the seasonal European business. So the North America brands going to Europe have experienced more challenge, as we've previously communicated, but most of the drive is coming from the strength of the North American markets.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And China is still in line with your previous expectation?
componenttext: And China is still in line with your previous expectation?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very pleased with China. China continues to be accretive to us. It's, as we've indicated before, a volume and return story, more than a yield story. Yields are down in China this year, but overall our earnings are proportionate to our capacity growt
componenttext: We're very pleased with China. China continues to be accretive to us. It's, as we've indicated before, a volume and return story, more than a yield story. Yields are down in China this year, but overall our earnings are proportionate to our capacity growth. We see continued demand. And again, as we said just a few minutes ago, our capacity changes are -- they sound like big percentage increases, but in terms of the actual volume, we're going to go from 5% of our capacity to 6% next year. But China is doing well for us, and we continue to have great confidence in the business. And overall, the business is accretive, especially for the brands that are there.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, did the Brexit vote, has that changed your outlook for the remainder of the year? Is there any sort of different view factored in from that? I mean obviously the FX impact that you've updated today but...
componenttext: And then just lastly, did the Brexit vote, has that changed your outlook for the remainder of the year? Is there any sort of different view factored in from that? I mean obviously the FX impact that you've updated today but...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so at this point in time, it's the FX impact, which obviously we've calculated in. We've taken a strong look at our business, obviously, in the U.K. and in Europe and then everywhere else. And we all will see what possible ramifications would be, but
componenttext: Yes, so at this point in time, it's the FX impact, which obviously we've calculated in. We've taken a strong look at our business, obviously, in the U.K. and in Europe and then everywhere else. And we all will see what possible ramifications would be, but at this point, we have no reason to adjust anything.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Assia Georgieva with Infinity Research.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Assia Georgieva with Infinity Research.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had one question. It seems that European pricing stabilized over the month of May and through the early part of June. Is that what you're seeing? And does that give you more confidence in terms of the Q3 and the fiscal year outlook?
componenttext: I had one question. It seems that European pricing stabilized over the month of May and through the early part of June. Is that what you're seeing? And does that give you more confidence in terms of the Q3 and the fiscal year outlook?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see in Europe overall that, again, the booking curve is getting a little further out. We end up with less inventory to sell, which allows us obviously to improve closer end pricing, which contributes to the yield growth. And David may have a comment.
componenttext: We see in Europe overall that, again, the booking curve is getting a little further out. We end up with less inventory to sell, which allows us obviously to improve closer end pricing, which contributes to the yield growth. And David may have a comment.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, keep in mind that in our situation 90% of the guests on our European itineraries are Europeans, and so that's a very different picture than North Americans flying over. And I think, as we had said a number of times earlier this year, the North Americ
componenttext: Yes, keep in mind that in our situation 90% of the guests on our European itineraries are Europeans, and so that's a very different picture than North Americans flying over. And I think, as we had said a number of times earlier this year, the North Americans, while the pricing was down, we are filling the ships. And recently, we have seen some very good demand for the European itineraries from the North Americans.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's what I was seeing, and just wanted to confirm that.
componenttext: That's what I was seeing, and just wanted to confirm that.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Felicia Hendrix with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: The next question is from Felicia Hendrix with Barclays Capital.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, thank you for the color on next year. It looks like things are starting to shape up well, although it's early days. Just wanted to talk for a moment about the yield optimization or the revenue management optimization program that you're undergoing
componenttext: David, thank you for the color on next year. It looks like things are starting to shape up well, although it's early days. Just wanted to talk for a moment about the yield optimization or the revenue management optimization program that you're undergoing now. And recognizing that we'll start to see the impact next year, just wondering if you could help us understand what kind of yield contribution you might be able to get from that, from having those 6 brands more on that program.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this is Arnold, first. First of all, on the new revenue management tools, we're very excited about it. We feel the brands are collaborating exceptionally well on it. It's going to allow us many, many more capabilities in terms of more timing inq
componenttext: Okay. And this is Arnold, first. First of all, on the new revenue management tools, we're very excited about it. We feel the brands are collaborating exceptionally well on it. It's going to allow us many, many more capabilities in terms of more timing inquiries, smaller movements and price movements to optimize pricing and therefore maximize on the yield results. And as we said, we'll be pretty much booked by the end of the summer, so most of the impact of this initial phase, we'll see next year. And then into next year, we'll add some additional features which will bring in the rest of the brands as well and we'll be able to max out going to 2018 from the tool itself and the better management skills that our people will develop from being able to utilize this tool and being able to see things in a more timely and being able to respond in a more rapid fashion. I'll let David comment beyond that, but...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I agree with Arnold. And it's really a multiyear process as we keep rolling out more of the inventory on the system and we learn from it. It is a little early to try to give guidance for 2017 or the exact impact in 2017 from the system. We'll tal
componenttext: Yes, no, I agree with Arnold. And it's really a multiyear process as we keep rolling out more of the inventory on the system and we learn from it. It is a little early to try to give guidance for 2017 or the exact impact in 2017 from the system. We'll talk more about yields in December, but keep in mind overall, to achieve our double-digit ROIC goal, our expectation is that we will see solid yield improvement in 2017 and beyond to achieve those goals. I will give you more color come December.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for my next question, I apologize if this sounds like a repeat of something that you've already said and answered, but I keep getting investor questions about this so I am going to ask for, as a point of clarification, as you look at your second half
componenttext: And for my next question, I apologize if this sounds like a repeat of something that you've already said and answered, but I keep getting investor questions about this so I am going to ask for, as a point of clarification, as you look at your second half of the year, given where you viewed the second half of the year when you provided your guidance previously in the spring versus today, has anything changed?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess overall we took the ticket yield guidance, as I mentioned in my comments, up by $0.05. And so I think, as Arnold alluded to before, we're seeing strength in the North American market. And as a result of that, we took our yield guidance up for the
componenttext: I guess overall we took the ticket yield guidance, as I mentioned in my comments, up by $0.05. And so I think, as Arnold alluded to before, we're seeing strength in the North American market. And as a result of that, we took our yield guidance up for the back half of the year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What's changed is obviously we have more clarity on line of sight, and we're ahead on booking. We've got less volume to sell. We're at higher prices. And so we have affirmations for being positive.
componenttext: Yes. What's changed is obviously we have more clarity on line of sight, and we're ahead on booking. We've got less volume to sell. We're at higher prices. And so we have affirmations for being positive.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So without putting words in your mouth, it sounds like you're more optimistic about the second half because you have better visibility than you were when you last -- when we last met in this forum.
componenttext: Okay. So without putting words in your mouth, it sounds like you're more optimistic about the second half because you have better visibility than you were when you last -- when we last met in this forum.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. David, just housekeeping. Is there -- just given the uncertainty, given Brexit, given the volatility in the market, the fact that everybody's trying to figure out which companies are most exposed to which currencies, I know, in the past, you haven'
componenttext: Great. David, just housekeeping. Is there -- just given the uncertainty, given Brexit, given the volatility in the market, the fact that everybody's trying to figure out which companies are most exposed to which currencies, I know, in the past, you haven't broken this out, but is there any way to give us any understanding or any kind of magnitude to how exposed you are to the British pound?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, the British pound represents about 30% of our currency exposure. So we talk about a full year impact of $0.27 for a 10% change in all currencies relative to the U.S. dollar, so for the British pound, you're talking about roughly $0.08 for the -
componenttext: Yes, well, the British pound represents about 30% of our currency exposure. So we talk about a full year impact of $0.27 for a 10% change in all currencies relative to the U.S. dollar, so for the British pound, you're talking about roughly $0.08 for the -- on a full year basis.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: To net income.
componenttext: To net income.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: To net income.
componenttext: To net income.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citi.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the -- just the first question. You mentioned that North American passengers going to Europe, that, that trend recently strengthened. And I'm wondering, just with the volatility in Europe, the currency changes, would you expect North American-sourced
componenttext: For the -- just the first question. You mentioned that North American passengers going to Europe, that, that trend recently strengthened. And I'm wondering, just with the volatility in Europe, the currency changes, would you expect North American-sourced business to become a bigger portion of passengers sailing on European itineraries over the next several quarters? And I think it's like 10% sourced goes to -- of the European itineraries, I think 10% are sourced from North America. Would you expect that to increase over the next few quarters?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to say. You're talking about a lot of itineraries, multiple brands. Our brands do a great job looking at it itinerary by itinerary and sourcing based off of where they can get the maximum amount of yield. And so there's a lot of factors t
componenttext: It's really hard to say. You're talking about a lot of itineraries, multiple brands. Our brands do a great job looking at it itinerary by itinerary and sourcing based off of where they can get the maximum amount of yield. And so there's a lot of factors to consider, and a call like that in the short term would be very difficult for us to opine on at this point.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, okay. And then just to even further clarify China, which I think we all know the answer. You've given it in different ways, but from your vantage point, you're not seeing any material dropoff in the last -- let's say, since you reported March.
componenttext: All right, okay. And then just to even further clarify China, which I think we all know the answer. You've given it in different ways, but from your vantage point, you're not seeing any material dropoff in the last -- let's say, since you reported March. You haven't seen a material dropoff in pricing or booking trends either at the travel agent or charter level or in terms of renegotiating at significantly lower prices with the charter companies that you have deals with for 2016 pricing. Is that the case, or not?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For us, as I said, first of all, our occupancy on our sailings is very comparable, which was very strong to prior year. We see no major change in occupancy whatsoever. In terms of yields, of course, the yields are down, but on the other hand, our earnings
componenttext: For us, as I said, first of all, our occupancy on our sailings is very comparable, which was very strong to prior year. We see no major change in occupancy whatsoever. In terms of yields, of course, the yields are down, but on the other hand, our earnings are up proportionately. So we are pricing at what we need to price for it to make sense for our business in China. We're achieving that pricing in our charters and our contracts and now with the distributors. And obviously, they have to win as well. And they won't be in the business if they're not winning, but they're in the business. And so I think that, overall, things again, in a market that's really so sizable and we have such an early beginning, and we have such low penetration for a market of that scale. I think we're in good shape going forward.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Jamie Katz with Morningstar.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Jamie Katz with Morningstar.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the double-digit ROIC goals. And I know, in the past, you guys have mentioned that the Carnival brand, I think, was already yielding double digits, so I'm curious if most of the other brands are sort of catching up to speed or if t
componenttext: My first question is on the double-digit ROIC goals. And I know, in the past, you guys have mentioned that the Carnival brand, I think, was already yielding double digits, so I'm curious if most of the other brands are sort of catching up to speed or if the brands tend to be bifurcated some way and maybe it might take a little longer for some of the underperforming brands to catch up.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we've stated in the past, we expect to achieve double-digit return on invested capital. Earlier this year we stated, in the next 2 to 3 years. At the end of this year, it will be the next 1 to 2 years. We are going to approach 9% return on invest
componenttext: Well, as we've stated in the past, we expect to achieve double-digit return on invested capital. Earlier this year we stated, in the next 2 to 3 years. At the end of this year, it will be the next 1 to 2 years. We are going to approach 9% return on invested capital this year. So that's a good sign for what you can expect going forward. So on balance, we're going to get there. You're right. We did share that the Carnival brand itself was already a double-digit return on invested capital. We have other brands that are. And overall, we will be there across the base of our business in time.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are differences between the brands, but we generally don't provide detail by brand.
componenttext: There are differences between the brands, but we generally don't provide detail by brand.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. And then do you guys want to offer any color on early reads on Fathom; and how you guys are thinking about that brand going forward, whether maybe it can be a much more important part of the business down the road just by the early demand you'v
componenttext: Yes, okay. And then do you guys want to offer any color on early reads on Fathom; and how you guys are thinking about that brand going forward, whether maybe it can be a much more important part of the business down the road just by the early demand you've seen. I know it's only one ship but just curious if you have any commentary.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Yes, it is only one ship. For the Dominican Republic part of the Fathom story, those that have gone have loved the experience and felt that they were personally transformed, et cetera. It's a different targeted segment. It's a travel segment mo
componenttext: Thank you. Yes, it is only one ship. For the Dominican Republic part of the Fathom story, those that have gone have loved the experience and felt that they were personally transformed, et cetera. It's a different targeted segment. It's a travel segment more than a cruise segment, and our ability to access that segment is challenging. We remain very optimistic about the brand, but the reality is we have to see the bookings from that segment. With regards to Cuba, where we literally made history through the Fathom brand, our fall bookings are very strong for Cuba. We got a late approval. The summer has not been full, although the experience has been phenomenal. We do have opportunities remaining on some of the summer sailings into Cuba, and we'll just have to let it play out. And the team's done a marvelous job of the on-the-ground product and the ship onboard product for DOR [ph]. And obviously, we're honored and privileged and somewhat humbled to be the first one in Cuba.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to drill a little bit further into your bookings for the third and the fourth quarter in Europe just to get a sense of the visibility but also the risk. How booked are you for the European brands in the third and the fourth quarters?
componenttext: I wanted to drill a little bit further into your bookings for the third and the fourth quarter in Europe just to get a sense of the visibility but also the risk. How booked are you for the European brands in the third and the fourth quarters?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally speaking, we give -- we don't give all the details by brand, but for the third quarter, we're generally 80% to 90% booked has been the historic range. And for the quarter -- the fourth quarter, which will be 1 quarter out, it'd be 50% to 70% boo
componenttext: Generally speaking, we give -- we don't give all the details by brand, but for the third quarter, we're generally 80% to 90% booked has been the historic range. And for the quarter -- the fourth quarter, which will be 1 quarter out, it'd be 50% to 70% booked. Now I think on the last call, I said we were sort of in middle of those ranges. Or maybe that was the December call. I don't remember exactly. And the booking curve has continued to move out, so we're a little bit higher than the midpoint to those ranges. Every brand has a slightly different booking curve, and that has to do with the nationalities and the people. And so there are differences between the brands all around the world, but it's more cultural than economic, generally speaking. So hopefully that gives you enough color to make some judgments.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then recently, have you seen any deviations from those trends? Do you expect the kind of the slope of the line to continue to trend in the same pattern that it's done recently?
componenttext: And then recently, have you seen any deviations from those trends? Do you expect the kind of the slope of the line to continue to trend in the same pattern that it's done recently?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No significant deviations. I mean the -- generally speaking, the booking curve all around the globe has been moving out somewhat. And we feel very good about that situation for all the brands.
componenttext: No significant deviations. I mean the -- generally speaking, the booking curve all around the globe has been moving out somewhat. And we feel very good about that situation for all the brands.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And moving over to China for my second question. There seems to be a fair amount of debate over the relationships with the charter operators. Do you have any -- it's -- you mentioned that your earnings have grown in line with your capacity growth. Do you
componenttext: And moving over to China for my second question. There seems to be a fair amount of debate over the relationships with the charter operators. Do you have any -- it's -- you mentioned that your earnings have grown in line with your capacity growth. Do you expect that to continue as you look into the capacity that you're introducing in 2017? And the reason that I ask the question is that there seems to be some pushback on -- from some investors in China that -- with another year of such large supply growth, that there's going to be a -- you're going to hit a demand wall.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, just to put things in perspective again. While the percentages sound so large, it's the equivalent of moving one additional ship down to a market that in time is going to be far larger than the North American market and could be as large proportion
componenttext: Again, just to put things in perspective again. While the percentages sound so large, it's the equivalent of moving one additional ship down to a market that in time is going to be far larger than the North American market and could be as large proportionally as the entire global cruise market is right now. So while there may be some bumps and temporary discontinuities as distributors ramp up with their own personnel to move the volume of cruise, because a lot of those distributors sell all the type of travel products, obviously. And there might be some bumps along those lines. Overall, China remains a robust opportunity, and we're still at the very, very beginning of it. So I don't see that. You're going to have some negotiations going on. Everybody wants a better price. It is a B2B business almost now. And of course, there'll be negotiations, trying to get lower price so they can get better returns or what-have-you, but overall things are very good. The cruise product that we offer is well received and excellent. We're going to have our first purpose-built ship, the Majestic Princess, going in next year. She is being met with very, very positive response by the distributors already. And we have our first ship for AIDA, as I mentioned, going in next year. And then we have our base for Costa and the rest of the Princess, but on balance, it's the equivalent of adding one ship. And so we'll be going from 5% of our capacity to 6% of our capacity, which is not very large at all even with the industry moving in a few additional ships and stuff that can be managed. There may be a bump here in the road, here or there, but over time, it's going to be great. And we do expect to see continued earnings improvement, a direction with the capacity expansion.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And keep in mind we're also expanding the number of offices we have in China. We're now up to 12 offices, and there are more to be opened. We're working with more and more travel agents and expanding that base. Plus, we continue to educate the travel agen
componenttext: And keep in mind we're also expanding the number of offices we have in China. We're now up to 12 offices, and there are more to be opened. We're working with more and more travel agents and expanding that base. Plus, we continue to educate the travel agents on more about cruising and how to better sell cruises. So we continue to expand the opportunity in the marketplace as well as -- really as Arnold indicated, it's really just one additional -- the equivalent one additional 4,000-passenger ship entering a huge market with tremendous opportunity.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of just clarification follow-on items. David, on the British pound, that 30%, just to make sure, that was on an annual net income exposure basis.
componenttext: A couple of just clarification follow-on items. David, on the British pound, that 30%, just to make sure, that was on an annual net income exposure basis.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any additional color you could give? I know you've got borrowings and everything in euro, but any -- where does the pound; I guess, euro; and maybe a couple other currencies rank annually on that net income exposure basis, maybe highest to lowest of the t
componenttext: Any additional color you could give? I know you've got borrowings and everything in euro, but any -- where does the pound; I guess, euro; and maybe a couple other currencies rank annually on that net income exposure basis, maybe highest to lowest of the top 3, 4, 5, whatever you want to feel comfortable in providing? And if so, the percentages.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Aussie dollar is probably about 35%. I think historically I have told everybody that the British pound and the Aussie dollar represented 2/3 of our currency exposure. The remaining exposure is you've got the Canadian dollar, the euro and the Chinese r
componenttext: The Aussie dollar is probably about 35%. I think historically I have told everybody that the British pound and the Aussie dollar represented 2/3 of our currency exposure. The remaining exposure is you've got the Canadian dollar, the euro and the Chinese renminbi. And those three are probably about 10% apiece. And this is, of course, all from a net income bottom line exposure. We have a lot more than 10% of our business in euros, but we also have a lot of expenses in euros, which net out the exposure when you get to the bottom line.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, great, helpful. And then the other question, and we get it, we're getting it more frequently, is given some Asian-based competitors adding, buying and then therefore adding apparent capacity long term, it would appear that if we go out '18, '1
componenttext: Okay, okay, great, helpful. And then the other question, and we get it, we're getting it more frequently, is given some Asian-based competitors adding, buying and then therefore adding apparent capacity long term, it would appear that if we go out '18, '19, you could see some years of 6% capacity growth on a gross basis for the industry. Arnold, any color on that, maybe how that would shake out net? Or it would appear that the majority of that capacity also would be in China. Just any additional thoughts or color on that looking out '18 and beyond.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our commitment is definitely to measure capacity growth, not just supply growth. And as we are delivering double-digit return and as the ships we have do that, we will retain those ships in the fleet. As they don't do that, then obviously we would no
componenttext: Yes, our commitment is definitely to measure capacity growth, not just supply growth. And as we are delivering double-digit return and as the ships we have do that, we will retain those ships in the fleet. As they don't do that, then obviously we would not, but we are totally committed to measured capacity growth. And given the large number of ships we have and the places they represent, that influences overall global capacity for the industry. So yes, a lot of the capacity growths you're going to see, as you've already identified, is targeted in China, which means the rest of the market, rest of the world, the other 95% of today's capacity is not seeing very much growth; and that things change for whatever reasons, which we don't anticipate, but if they were to change, we can easily modify and adapt and change our replenishment strategy. We will always want the new ships because they're more efficient, more cost effective. And so you'd always want the new ships, and you would look at the timing of moving out the ships that are less efficient and not generating returns.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would you anticipate that number for the industry to maybe come down? Would you anticipate some higher scrappage rates going forward as the global fleet...
componenttext: And would you anticipate that number for the industry to maybe come down? Would you anticipate some higher scrappage rates going forward as the global fleet...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, it depends on the demand in the market, right? So for us, things are robust. Keep in mind that the industry overall is underpenetrated. In our case, with 10 brands, we have a huge base of people who have experienced cruise and love it. Cruise i
componenttext: Right now, it depends on the demand in the market, right? So for us, things are robust. Keep in mind that the industry overall is underpenetrated. In our case, with 10 brands, we have a huge base of people who have experienced cruise and love it. Cruise is still the best vacation value there is. It's a tremendous vacation experience. Onboard revenues have grown every year in the cruise industry, except -- and for us, our onboard revenues have grown every year, except 1 year in the whole history of the time we've been in the business, and so that we can look back to in time. And that's in all kinds of environments, recessionary environments, crises environments, everything. So underpenetrated, big base of people who already want a cruise, great dynamics. It's hard to say, but I don't anticipate acceleration of retirements of ships. But the point is we have mobile assets. We have a number of triggers we can pull, and we can do what we need to do because we are committed to double-digit return on invested capital and sustaining that.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from the line of Jared Shojaian with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from the line of Jared Shojaian with Wolfe Research.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Arnold, you talked about a 5% reduction in European capacity and 5% increase in the Caribbean. So my question is, what are you seeing from competitors on global redeployment? And what gives you confidence that we won't have a repeat of 2014, when the Cari
componenttext: Arnold, you talked about a 5% reduction in European capacity and 5% increase in the Caribbean. So my question is, what are you seeing from competitors on global redeployment? And what gives you confidence that we won't have a repeat of 2014, when the Caribbean became oversupplied?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the nearer term, it's not going to happen because the deployments are mostly transparent at this point. So that's the best indication is that we kind of can see a lot of where the ships are going already. So you won't see a 2014 explosion of Cari
componenttext: Well, in the nearer term, it's not going to happen because the deployments are mostly transparent at this point. So that's the best indication is that we kind of can see a lot of where the ships are going already. So you won't see a 2014 explosion of Caribbean capacity, like in 2017, you won't see that. So having said that, there could still be additional capacity in Caribbean because it's strong now for us, and I'm sure it is for others too; and similarly to the extent possible, up in Alaska as well. But -- and we're anticipating that. Every year, there's overcapacity somewhere and so on and so forth. And again, we have lots of different ways to manage our business to ensure that we deliver the results we're committed to delivering, which is a double-digit return on invested capital. But we don't anticipate an explosion in the Caribbean like you saw in 2014.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind that when we planned the 2014 deployments, our brands were not coordinating their own -- their deployment within our own company. So a number of individual brands each made what they thought were really good decisions. Now the deployment is w
componenttext: Keep in mind that when we planned the 2014 deployments, our brands were not coordinating their own -- their deployment within our own company. So a number of individual brands each made what they thought were really good decisions. Now the deployment is well coordinated within our company and there's more visibility across the whole corporation, which is how we wound up with the 5%.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. The 5% for us compares to a 20% growth we had in 2014, so it's considerably different.
componenttext: Right. The 5% for us compares to a 20% growth we had in 2014, so it's considerably different.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I just want to follow up on some of that capacity commentary because it's still -- I mean it feels like a lot of investors are still pretty concerned about the amount of industry growth over the next several years. So what leverage do you have to
componenttext: And then I just want to follow up on some of that capacity commentary because it's still -- I mean it feels like a lot of investors are still pretty concerned about the amount of industry growth over the next several years. So what leverage do you have to pull if you need to? I mean you talked about the retirements, but I mean, why wouldn't reducing utilization work? I mean, is that one opportunity? Or are there other areas that you see? I'd just love to hear about any flexibility you think you have there.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, you want the new ships because they're more efficient, so -- and inherently, they can give you a better return. So the new ships will come. The question is what do you do with the other ships. And as long as they're returning, you'll keep them. The
componenttext: Again, you want the new ships because they're more efficient, so -- and inherently, they can give you a better return. So the new ships will come. The question is what do you do with the other ships. And as long as they're returning, you'll keep them. The demand is there. There's growth in China. Cuba opens up. There's renewed interest in the Caribbean and so on and growth prospects for the Caribbean. All those things are drivers that can help give you yields and returns on some of the existing fleet. So the lever is pretty straightforward. You'll be able to tell what ships are performing and which ones aren't. And if you don't have a good redeployment plan, then it would make sense to exit.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, you had some realized gains on fuel derivatives for 2016. I think you said it was $330 million in March. Can you tell us what it's running at now? And then your marketing programs [indiscernible] are being shifted. What specifi
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, you had some realized gains on fuel derivatives for 2016. I think you said it was $330 million in March. Can you tell us what it's running at now? And then your marketing programs [indiscernible] are being shifted. What specifically was shifted, and what was the rationale? And then finally, on the Queen Mary retrofit, are you probably going to see more Cunard and Queen ships follow up over the next couple of years?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll take the first question, Steve. In terms of realized losses on fuel derivatives, it's $285 million that was built into our June guidance. As a result of the change in Brent which moved up, the losses came down just a little bit. In terms of adv
componenttext: Okay, I'll take the first question, Steve. In terms of realized losses on fuel derivatives, it's $285 million that was built into our June guidance. As a result of the change in Brent which moved up, the losses came down just a little bit. In terms of advertising built into the guidance, I mean, it was -- these are small movements that the brands planned well ahead and make decisions over time based off of what they see happening in booking trends and other things. And they will reseasonalize. Keep in mind every good plan has got to change as you see movements. It's no different than when we see strength in bookings, we raise prices. We make changes over time. So that's really essentially is not a big deal, and it's just some seasonalization between the quarters.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We manage to yield. We don't manage to a time frame. And so costs can move in and out of quarters, but we're managing to yield and return.
componenttext: We manage to yield. We don't manage to a time frame. And so costs can move in and out of quarters, but we're managing to yield and return.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Basically, Queen Mary 2 went into a dry-dock. The ships practically do 3 to 5 years, depending on the class of ship. And the others are practically new, have gone through a dry dock recently. So it's just part of dry-dock. On the other hand, Queen Mar
componenttext: No. Basically, Queen Mary 2 went into a dry-dock. The ships practically do 3 to 5 years, depending on the class of ship. And the others are practically new, have gone through a dry dock recently. So it's just part of dry-dock. On the other hand, Queen Mary 2, there was a remastering. I mean she is the only ocean liner out there, and we're very, very proud of her. And we -- wherever she goes, she's still iconic. People gather by the thousands and tens of thousands to see her sail in and sail out. And so we take great pride in her. And also, we can generate the yields from the additional investment, so we did do a remastering of the Queen Mary 2 versus just a traditional kind of dry-dock where you refresh.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Jamie Rollo with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Jamie Rollo with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few questions on China, first of all, please. Could you give us a feeling for roughly how much your yields are down by year-on-year just sort of directionally and what the yield premium is to the rest of the group now, please?
componenttext: Just a few questions on China, first of all, please. Could you give us a feeling for roughly how much your yields are down by year-on-year just sort of directionally and what the yield premium is to the rest of the group now, please?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- we've said all along the yields are down. We had previously indicated that the ticket prices were higher than the fleet average. And at this point in time, the ticket prices are in line with the overall fleet average, but it's really an apple
componenttext: Well, the -- we've said all along the yields are down. We had previously indicated that the ticket prices were higher than the fleet average. And at this point in time, the ticket prices are in line with the overall fleet average, but it's really an apples-and-oranges comparison because in China you've got a much higher percentage of the fleet is in the contemporary brands. And so you're comparing apples and oranges when you're taking the average China ticket yield to the overall fleet average ticket yield. So keep that in mind as you evaluate the numbers.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so it's fair to say it's not yield accretive to move ships to China if they match the existing brand type.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016

componenttext: Within a brand is definitely yield accretive.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016

componenttext: Understood. And you also mentioned some negotiations with the charters for next year. Is that sort of a bit more aggressive than usual because you've got several new brands entering the market, Norwegian, MSC, Dream? Or is that sort of in line with what you saw last year?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say the negotiations are in-line. I mean there's always a negotiation. And I don't want to overstate that. I mean they're our partners. They need to win too, but of course, they're going to try to get as great a return as they can possibly get. Th
componenttext: I would say the negotiations are in-line. I mean there's always a negotiation. And I don't want to overstate that. I mean they're our partners. They need to win too, but of course, they're going to try to get as great a return as they can possibly get. There are subagents involved with distributors and so on and so forth, but -- so I don't see any greater intensity in the negotiations, any big fundamental change in the tone or nature or anything like that. But there is always ongoing negotiation, as you look out into future years with the charters.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016

componenttext: And then the other question was just on the -- on your yield guidance for the rest of the year. I think, if my math is right, you need something like 3.5% to 4% in Q4. Is that sequential improvement just the mix of deployment you've got, obviously more Caribbean and more Europe? Or is that a genuine underlying improvement relative to Q3?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Stuart Gordon with Berenberg Bank.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Stuart Gordon with Berenberg Bank.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question just to break down a little bit on the $0.17 of headwind that you've now got. My back of the envelope suggests that, that would be about $0.07 or $0.08 of fuel and around about $0.10 of currency. I was just hoping you could confirm t
componenttext: Just a quick question just to break down a little bit on the $0.17 of headwind that you've now got. My back of the envelope suggests that, that would be about $0.07 or $0.08 of fuel and around about $0.10 of currency. I was just hoping you could confirm that. And on the currency, just interested how you've dealt with sterling as we move into the third quarter because obviously, before the big move, most people will have paid for their holidays. So have you already swept that into dollars so that the third quarter is not going to be such a big hit? Or was that sitting in sterling and therefore the repatriation cost still exists?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, as far as the split's concerned, the fuel price was roughly, including derivatives, $0.10. And currency was $0.07, which made up the $0.17 compared to our March guidance. In terms of the third quarter, the way it works from an accounting perspective
componenttext: Okay, as far as the split's concerned, the fuel price was roughly, including derivatives, $0.10. And currency was $0.07, which made up the $0.17 compared to our March guidance. In terms of the third quarter, the way it works from an accounting perspective is the exchange rate gets locked in for accounting when the people pay for their cruise. From an actual exchange of physical currencies from one to another, we do that, generally speaking, on a daily or a weekly basis, depending on what currencies we need. We do have bills in British pound. We retain those currencies. And the extra, we do exchange into U.S. dollars or euros or whatever currency we're short.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear: People will have paid for their holiday before the drop in sterling, so that will have been locked in at the better sterling rate for the third quarter.
componenttext: So just to be clear: People will have paid for their holiday before the drop in sterling, so that will have been locked in at the better sterling rate for the third quarter.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is correct. And in the 10% impact, I -- we take those locked-in rates into account when we give the currency impact on our P&L. So I said that 10% movement would be $0.09 for the third quarter. I took into account that a big chunk of that revenue had
componenttext: That is correct. And in the 10% impact, I -- we take those locked-in rates into account when we give the currency impact on our P&L. So I said that 10% movement would be $0.09 for the third quarter. I took into account that a big chunk of that revenue had been paid for and locked in.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess -- so when you think about the number of travel -- you have 12 offices there. I appreciated the perspective, but when you think about the volume of travel agencies, how many total travel agencies are licensed for out bound travel? And how many
componenttext: So I guess -- so when you think about the number of travel -- you have 12 offices there. I appreciated the perspective, but when you think about the volume of travel agencies, how many total travel agencies are licensed for out bound travel? And how many relationships does Carnival have today with those travel agencies? And the growth trajectory of those agencies?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, yes. So today, we are beginning to expand the number of distributors. Historically, we've worked with principally a group of 10. We're starting to expand beyond that. We're started, of course, in the -- near Shanghai, near Tianjin, where the ships
componenttext: Got it, yes. So today, we are beginning to expand the number of distributors. Historically, we've worked with principally a group of 10. We're starting to expand beyond that. We're started, of course, in the -- near Shanghai, near Tianjin, where the ships were. And we're starting to expand into -- throughout the country. That's why we expanded the offices. And some of those distributors obviously have subagents, sub-distributors that they've worked with in the past, so our reach is a little bit more than what a lot of -- quite a bit more than the 10 we work with directly through that. But we're expanding them. As we expand capacity, we're expanding the reach of distributors and going into -- not only further through the country but also more density where the ships are. So it's a nascent market, and we're building as we go.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind there's 26,000 travel agents in China. About 2,600 of them have outbound licenses. And so what we're seeing happening is, while there's a small group that tends to charter, let's say, the full ship, we're probably dealing with 250 to 300 agen
componenttext: Keep in mind there's 26,000 travel agents in China. About 2,600 of them have outbound licenses. And so what we're seeing happening is, while there's a small group that tends to charter, let's say, the full ship, we're probably dealing with 250 to 300 agents who are doing large groups and chartering part of a ship at this point in time. But those 250 or 300 travel agents are also selling through the other 24,000 travel agents around the country. That's what Arnold called, like, subagents. And they're selling into these groups and charters. So it's a tremendous distribution system, and it can be leveraged. And it's part of the reason why we're so optimistic about the growth in China, tremendous opportunity.
