headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I'm Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning. Today, I am joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; by Dav
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I'm Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning. Today, I am joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; by David Bernstein, our Chief Financial Officer; and by Beth Roberts, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. 
Before I begin, please note that some of our remarks on this call will be forward looking. Therefore, I must refer you to the cautionary statement in today's press release. 
Despite a series of geopolitical events that unfolded as the year progressed, including Turkey, Paris and Brussels, despite heightened concerns around [indiscernible], around Brexit and around China, despite fuel and currency both working against us, resulting in an $0.18 drag from our initial 2016 guidance, we had exceeded the high end of our quarterly guidance and we are raising our expectations for the year. 
This quarter, we delivered the highest quarterly earnings in Carnival Corporation's history, with record net income of over $1.4 billion, $0.17 per share higher than the prior year, exceeding the high-end of our guidance and $0.07 above the midpoint. Despite the numerous headwinds, we are well on track to achieve our new guidance midpoint for full year adjusted earnings per share of $3.35, more than doubling our 2013 earnings of $1.55 per share. More importantly, our return on invested capital will also nearly double from 4.6% to 8.8% over that same time period. 
These strong results could not happen without the hard work of our 120,000 passionate employees and without the strong support of our travel agent partners. Looking forward, our booking trends are strong heading into 2017, with higher occupancy levels and higher prices, building momentum for continued earnings growth. 
Our record results and favorable booking trends reflect our ongoing efforts to create demand in excess of measured capacity growth together with the benefits of leveraging our scale. Our [indiscernible] cruise lines continue to outperform, particularly in the Caribbean with continued strength in [indiscernible] and pricing. Moreover, all of our major brands in North America and Europe experienced net revenue yield improvement despite the geopolitical environment in Europe. 
Europe is our single largest deployment in the third quarter at 45% of our total capacity. Now there's certainly have been a lot of noise around China. So I'm going to spend a little extra time on China on my comments now. First, China is a profitable market for us. Our ships operating in China optimize our overall brand performances. As we have previously indicated, China is a unit growth opportunity and we expect the yield to be down as the distribution system improve its ability to service the growing market there. 
To demonstrate our commitment to grow the industry in China, we have factored into our results and into our guidance potential adjustments to our contracted prices in support of our distribution partners. The distributors are gaining experience translating pent-up consumer demand for cruising into sustainable market pricing and we certainly want to help them as they adapt to a rapidly growing market. 
Again, even with those adjustments, we are raising our guidance for the year, affirming that we can manage ups and downs in the symbiotic market. As we've previously pointed out, China represents just 5% of our capacity. And even with capacity growth well above our global average, it will remain a relatively small percentage of our total business. We continue to expect China to be a growth market, especially since the growth in the cruise industry is backed by the Chinese government as is evidenced by its inclusion in the current five-year plan. We will participate in this growth. We have 16 [ph] market officers in China in 2016, that's up from just 8 in 2015. We plan to open 4 more offices and to significantly expand our distribution network in 2017. Also in 2017, the brand-new Majestic Princess will enter as a first purpose-built ship for the Chinese market. Our capacity growth in China is expected to be 26% next year, compared to 66% this year. Industrywide growth in China is expected to be 31% in 2017, compared to 100% this year. Those numbers sound big. But keep in mind that these large year-over-year percentage increases [indiscernible] a very small base. So these growth rates are directionally equivalent to adding less than one 3,000 berth vessels to our China fleet and roughly two 4,000 berth vessel to the industry fleet overall in 2017 in China. 
Regardless of the rate of growth in China, we are firmly committed to overall measured capacity growth and fully capable of managing to sustainable double-digit return on invested capital. 
Concerning newbuild, our most recent announcement included 3 new ship orders for 2021 and 2022, our first orders for those years. Before 2020, there's been no change in capacity for previous announcements. To optimize the deployment however, we have allocated the newbuild long our brand. 
Over the next 4 years, 3 ships are planned to be purpose-built for Asia, our fastest-growing region which is still in its early stage of development. And an average of roughly 3 ships per year will be spread across all our established markets. In fact, we have a very measured capacity environment during this time at the brand level, with 2 ships each for our North American land Carnival Cruise Line, our global brand, Princess, our luxury brand, Seabourn, and our German brand, AIDA. Effectively, one ship every other year for those brands. In addition, over the same 4-year period, we will deliver just 1 ship each for Holland America Line, [indiscernible] in Southern Europe, P&O in the U.K. and P&O in Australia. And during this time, we will continually moving ships from our fleet. In fact, the number of berths that are eligible for removal will more than double by 2020 and more than double again by 2024. 
Yet in this potential replacement cycle increase, we expect that a greater portion of our newbuild capacity will actually replace older, less efficient ships. As in the past, we will sell ships into secondary markets that do not compete directly with our brands. Within those secondary markets, there are older ships operating today that will soon reach retirement age and need to be replaced. We expect our net capacity growth through 2020 to be 3% to 4% compounded annually, consisting of double-digit growth in Asia and obviously, 3% or less growth in our established markets in North America, Europe and Australia. 
Meanwhile, we continue our efforts to create demand in excess of measured capacity growth. We have stepped up our aggressive relations effort with 3 innovative 30-minute programs airing weekly on ABC, NBC and CW, every Saturday meaning, beginning on October. Each program showcases our brands, creating amazing vacation experiences that are designed to expand the audience for cruising by providing increased consideration and, at the same time, changing perceptions by the [indiscernible] of cruising with compelling original content. We are excited by the prospects of connecting people, places and cultures across the world to create unforgettable experiences. Collectively, these programs provide an 1.5 hours of content per week with over 150 scheduled airings and an annual expected viewership well in excess of 150 million people. And we have further innovations on the horizon that will be unveiled in January of 2017 designed to further enhance our already great guest experiences. 
Additionally, we launched the initial phase of our yield management system this quarter, helping us drive incremental revenue yields over time. We are currently market testing across 6 brands for a portion of the inventory to refine algorithms. The full rollout will be completed by late next year. Although we have already benefited from the sharing of best practices, we expect this new yield management technology to contribute in 2017 and even more so in 2018. 
We also continue to make progress on our cost containment efforts and remain on track for more than $75 million of cost savings this year. 
In summary, we are committed to measured capacity growth, currently planned at less than 3% in the established markets. Our brands are differentiating themselves in the market and delivering fantastic vacations for our guests as evidenced by our strong yield performance. We continue to build demand for cruise and continue to aggressively contain cost while still investing in enhanced guest experience and demand creation. We are improving our capability to extract yield in any environment through enhanced revenue management tools. Moreover, we remain committed to returning value to shareholders. During the quarter, we repurchased another $700 million of [indiscernible] stock through our ongoing buyback program. In the last year, we have invested nearly $2.5 billion to buy back over 50 million shares of our company stock, demonstrating conviction in our ability to execute and achieve sustainable double-digit returns on invested capital. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to David.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arnold. Before I begin, please note, all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 third quarter results. Then I'll provide an
componenttext:
Thank you, Arnold. Before I begin, please note, all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. 
I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 third quarter results. Then I'll provide an update on our full year 2016 guidance. And then I'll finish up with some insights on 2017 booking trends and a few other items to note for 2017. 
Our record adjusted EPS for the third quarter was $1.92. This was $0.07 above the midpoint of our June guidance. The improvement was driven by a number of factors: First, $0.02 cents from net revenue yields which benefited from stronger pricing on closing bookings on our North American brands; second, $0.02 from lower net cruise costs, excluding fuel, as a result of timing of certain expenses between the quarters; third, $0.01 from the favorable net impact of fuel prices and currency versus our June guidance rates; and fourth, $0.01 from the accretive impact of the shares we've repurchased since the last earnings call. 
Now let's turn to the third quarter operating results versus the prior year. Our capacity increased almost [ph] 4%. The North American brands were up over 2%, while our European, Australia and Asian brands, also known as our EAA brands, were up over 6%. Our total net revenue yields were up 2.7%. 
Now let's break apart the 2 components of net revenue yields. Net ticket yields were up 3.1%. This increase was driven by our North American brands deployment in the Caribbean, Alaska and Europe, as well as our EAA brands deployments in Europe. These net ticket yields increases were partially offset by yield reductions in Australia, driven by large industry capacity increases in a highly penetrated market, as well as yield reductions in Asia where distributors are gaining experience growing the market. The majority of these yield reductions were anticipated in our initial 2016 yield guidance, provided during our December earnings call. 
After 8 straight quarters of mid-to high single digit yield increases, our net onboard and other yields increased 1.3% over much tougher comparables from the third quarter 2015 as our current initiatives continue to pay dividends while our brands develop new initiatives for 2017 and beyond. 
Net cruise costs per ALBD excluding fuel were up over 5%, driven by the timing of advertising expenses and the remastering of Queen Mary 2 in dry dock as discussed on our last earnings call. This was about 1 point improvement versus what was planned in our June guidance. But again, this was due to the timing of expenses between the quarters. 
In summary, our third quarter adjusted EPS was $0.17 higher than the prior year, driven by 3 things: One, operational improvements worth $0.05 despite a high net cruise cost seasonalization in the third quarter; two, the favorable net impact of fuel prices and currency were $0.02; and three, share buyback accretion were $0.10. 
As Arnold indicated, since the beginning of the third quarter, we repurchased over $700 million of our shares for a total, since late last year, of over 50 million shares and nearly $2.5 billion of buybacks. At this point in time, we have approximately $500 million remaining on the $3 billion stock buyback authorization. Our September guidance EPS calculations assumes shares repurchased through last week. For the full year, the calculation assumes 748 million shares outstanding on a weighted average basis, while the fourth quarter calculation assumes 730 million shares outstanding. 
Next, I want to provide you with an update on our full year 2016 guidance. As Arnold indicated, we are well on track for achieving adjusted EPS of $3.35, which is the midpoint of our 2016 September guidance range of $3.33 to $3.37. The $0.05 improvement compared to the midpoint of our June guidance was essentially driven by 2 things: Improved net revenue yields were $0.03, $0.02 of which we achieved in the third quarter and an additional $0.01 we expect to achieve in net ticket revenues during the fourth quarter; and $0.02 from the accretive impact of additional shares repurchased since our June conference call. 
Now let's turn to 2017 booking trends. Since June, bookings for the first half of 2017 have been at significantly higher prices, with booking volumes lower than the prior year as there is less inventory remaining for sale. At this point in time, for the first half of 2017, cumulative advanced bookings are ahead at considerably higher prices. 
Drilling down into the cumulative book position. First, for our North American brands. Caribbean occupancy is well ahead of our prior year at nicely higher prices. For all other deployments, occupancy is ahead of the prior year at higher prices. 
Secondly, for our EAA brands.  For Europe deployments, occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at slightly higher prices. For the Caribbean deployment for our EAA brands, occupancy is in line with the prior year at slightly lower prices. However, prices on these bookings over the last quarter are well ahead of the prior year, clearly an improving trend. For Asia, occupancy is in line with the prior year at nicely higher prices. And for Australia, occupancy is also well ahead of the prior year at prices that are in line. However, prices on the bookings over the last quarter are well ahead of the prior year, also clearly an improving trend. 
And finally, a few other items to note for 2017. We are forecasting a capacity increase of 2.5%. We are planning for an increase in dry dock days for approximately 380 days in 2016 to 470 days in 2017. Remember, we did benefit in 2016 from lower dry dock days compared to the 563 days we had in 2015. 
As we have indicated on previous conference calls, the dry dock days will vary each year. But probably average around 450 to 475 days given the current size of our fleet. As we indicated last year, given the amount of CapEx reinvestments in the existing vessels and other areas of our business to drive yield improvement, we do expect depreciation expense to increase percentagewise, more than capacity and currently expect depreciation expense to be around $1.9 billion for 2017. 
Given the volatility of fuel prices and FX rates over the last year, we wanted to share with you the year-over-year impact that these items would have on our 2017 results if we use current fuel prices and FX rates. The 2017 year-over-year impact would be an unfavorable $0.28: $0.24 for fuel prices including the impact of fuel derivatives; and $0.04 for currency. 
Although it's early, 2017 appears to be shaping up to be another good year. We are well-positioned for continued earnings growth, given the current strength of our bookings and pricing trends for next year. 
And now, operator, let's open up the call for questions.

But I wonder if you could just sort of give any color on how chartered -- how much you're chartered for next year at this point already? Thanks.

In terms of the Europe -- North America brands, in Europe, again, our booking trends looks strong and look good as to our pricing. headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes, right now, our charter activity is strong in China. Our occupancies this year were very good. We anticipated, as we said, in opening comments, that we will see yield decline. But China is profitable. Occupancy levels, [indiscernible] the increased capacity was [indiscernible] in terms of having guest on the ships. The ships are sailing full. And chartering for next year at this point is in process, but solid, very strong. We don't see any [indiscernible] around occupancy for next year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just kind of sticking on your outlook for 2017, David. It appears that the commentary that you had for the first half this quarter has improved since the color you gave last quarter. You guys have given us some nice color on the call. But I'm just wonderi
componenttext: Just kind of sticking on your outlook for 2017, David. It appears that the commentary that you had for the first half this quarter has improved since the color you gave last quarter. You guys have given us some nice color on the call. But I'm just wondering, specifically, what is driving that improvement?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a variety of things. I mean, we've talked all along essentially about the strength of our bookings. Our booking position as well ahead. We talked of pricing at this point was considerably higher. We've been working all along, all year long on our
componenttext: There's a variety of things. I mean, we've talked all along essentially about the strength of our bookings. Our booking position as well ahead. We talked of pricing at this point was considerably higher. We've been working all along, all year long on our yield management systems. Best practices across the brands have been very helpful. As Arnold mentioned, we just rolled out, for the 6 brands, the prototype for the new revenue management system and that will be helping in addition for 2017 and beyond. So there is a lot of good, positive deployment optimization across the brands have contributed. So there's a lot of very good things going in our favor and we feel very good about the overall book position for 2017.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, thank you. And so your fourth quarter outlook is basically in line with what was implied when you reported last and also in line with consensus. There have been some travel agent reports that there are pockets of inventory in the Caribbean
componenttext: That's helpful, thank you. And so your fourth quarter outlook is basically in line with what was implied when you reported last and also in line with consensus. There have been some travel agent reports that there are pockets of inventory in the Caribbean for the remainder of the year. I'm assuming that's being contemplated in your guidance. But is there anything that you can see today that might cause some risk or concern about the guidance for the rest of the year?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We don't see any events in terms of guidance for the rest of the year. Our bookings are very strong in the Caribbean. We're well ahead with higher pricing. We don't see softness. Our brands continue to outperform in the Caribbean.
componenttext: No. We don't see any events in terms of guidance for the rest of the year. Our bookings are very strong in the Caribbean. We're well ahead with higher pricing. We don't see softness. Our brands continue to outperform in the Caribbean.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, Arnold, you touched upon this earlier in your prepared remarks. Could you just talk a little bit more about the decision to move AIDA from, it was originally -- one of your AIDA ships was anticipated to be in China next year and now
componenttext: And then just finally, Arnold, you touched upon this earlier in your prepared remarks. Could you just talk a little bit more about the decision to move AIDA from, it was originally -- one of your AIDA ships was anticipated to be in China next year and now it's going to be in the Med and then earlier in the year, you moved that China decision -- the decision for Carnival brand to be in China. You took that out. So I was just wondering if you can talk about those decisions. And would we perhaps see those bands in China in 2018?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, deployments are kind of a holistic decision. So a lot of things going in consideration. Obviously, the market concerning deployment in. But also, in the case of AIDA, AIDApearl, our new ship, we've gotten confirmation of when she's going to come in
componenttext: Again, deployments are kind of a holistic decision. So a lot of things going in consideration. Obviously, the market concerning deployment in. But also, in the case of AIDA, AIDApearl, our new ship, we've gotten confirmation of when she's going to come in. So we now know the capacity situation we'll have. So that was the relative strength of the market in Germany for AIDA. So all of those things factor in as well as the dynamics in China itself. Similarly with the Carnival, as I mentioned on previous call on that one, it was a combination of things, how well Carnival was doing in the Caribbean, the timing of capacity coming in with the Vista coming in and other things and the fact that we had distributed ports, home ports here the U.S. and getting the right ship in the right homeport. All of those things factor in ultimately for an optimized deployment decision. And that's the beauty of our inventory is that it's mobile. We can adjust and adapt and we're constantly seeking to optimize.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us the maybe the 2 or 3 main take takeaways that you came back with?
componenttext: Can you give us the maybe the 2 or 3 main take takeaways that you came back with?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The takeaways are the ones that I went over with, frankly which is number 1, cruise is in the five-year plan for China. So that means the government is committed to developing the cruise industry. The reason for that is pretty self-evident. We'll employ o
componenttext: The takeaways are the ones that I went over with, frankly which is number 1, cruise is in the five-year plan for China. So that means the government is committed to developing the cruise industry. The reason for that is pretty self-evident. We'll employ overall with port development and infrastructure and supply chain and training as well as shipbuilding that will employ millions and millions and millions of Chinese. And so the government is very interested and they see cruise as an economic engine going forward. So you've got the support of the central government and the various provincial municipal government, so that's very important. The second thing is the growth market. The third thing is that growth is constrained. I know the percentages sound large and everything. But as I tried to point out in the opening comments, we're talking onesies, twosies and ships. And the reason the growth is constrained is because we have large addressable markets that are underpenetrated everywhere in the world. And so we have lots of places to put ships on these days. And so we're not just going to take all the ships and existing markets and move [indiscernible] in China. And there is constraint on the number of ships that can be built in China -- for China -- up for China market in the near term here. So all of those things put additional constraints. Beyond that, clearly, as we anticipated, as you guys have identified through your assessment, the yields decline. We see China as a unit volume -- a unit growth story, as ultimately accretive to earnings, which has been for us and overall helping us optimize yields across the global fleet and it's working really well. Having said that, there is a gap with distribution. It's an embryonic market. Distributors are finding their way for the first time in cruise. It is a charter market, a B2B market. So that introduces possibilities of discontinuities that you might not see if you have a direct-to-consumer kind of a market. So all of those things are things we already knew going over. Those were firm. But the other thing I wasn't firm was the enthusiasm for the government for the cruise industry, the fact that the guest satisfaction levels are high, that our ships are definitely occupied, comparable to prior years despite the significant percentage increases in capacity and we see it as a future market. Now having said all of that, with all the increases we're talking about, it's 5% of our capacity next year, with the additional increases, including the majestic Princess, will be the first purpose-built ship for China entering late next year, even with that, it's going to be 6% of our capacity. So we can only grow so fast. And because of the relatively small percentage of our total fleet it is, it's very manageable for us with any fits and styles or bumps on the road we might encounter. But we are committed to work with the distributor partners, our distributor partners in building a sustainable business in China.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I can follow up another one real quick. So the biggest hurdle that you guys see still the distribution network? Or is that the infrastructure is still not really in place at this point?
componenttext: So if I can follow up another one real quick. So the biggest hurdle that you guys see still the distribution network? Or is that the infrastructure is still not really in place at this point?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the short term opportunity of course is for the distribution system to benefit fully from the pent-up demand there is for cruising by connecting it to the capacity there. So that's the immediate opportunity. The near term opportunity, of course, is
componenttext: Well, the short term opportunity of course is for the distribution system to benefit fully from the pent-up demand there is for cruising by connecting it to the capacity there. So that's the immediate opportunity. The near term opportunity, of course, is to further develop the markets now from a port and destination standpoint. And that's the near-term opportunity. And there's lots of work going on with that. And so that's the next opportunity and the near-term opportunity. We're working on it of course, the Chinese government is working on it. We're working on it in other places, the places the Chinese want to go to. So there is additional itinerary planning that needs to evolve and [indiscernible] of capable taking the large number of Chinese guests that will be frequenting them.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Last question, very simple. Your Caribbean bookings, in terms of your commentary, are probably much better, I think than folks would expect at this point. So is it fair to say that the Zika impact is basically 0 this point?
componenttext: Okay, great. Last question, very simple. Your Caribbean bookings, in terms of your commentary, are probably much better, I think than folks would expect at this point. So is it fair to say that the Zika impact is basically 0 this point?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we've seen, no material impact from Zika. We didn't get any cancellations or not enough to mention. We didn't see any impact on booking volume or timing or anything. So we have not seen an impact from Zika. Having said that, could there be a littl
componenttext: Yes, as we've seen, no material impact from Zika. We didn't get any cancellations or not enough to mention. We didn't see any impact on booking volume or timing or anything. So we have not seen an impact from Zika. Having said that, could there be a little bit of noise that is just overwhelmed by the great demand that there is for the Caribbean? And with even greater and hypothetically, you can say that. But we have seen nothing to suggest there is an impact from Zika.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jamie Katz from MorningStar.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jamie Katz from MorningStar.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious on the new ship builds that you guys are doing with [indiscernible] CSS, what the -- if there's any infrastructure spend that may be needs to happen to facilitate that or whether that sort of grows under the China government spend plan and won
componenttext: I'm curious on the new ship builds that you guys are doing with [indiscernible] CSS, what the -- if there's any infrastructure spend that may be needs to happen to facilitate that or whether that sort of grows under the China government spend plan and won't require very much investment on your part?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. There will be no investment on our part. First of all, just to explain the construct, CSSC and Fincantieri have a shipbuilding joint venture. Ourselves, CSSC and CIC, have the joint venture on a ship owning joint venture that is still being finalized
componenttext: No. There will be no investment on our part. First of all, just to explain the construct, CSSC and Fincantieri have a shipbuilding joint venture. Ourselves, CSSC and CIC, have the joint venture on a ship owning joint venture that is still being finalized as well as a ship operating joint venture that's being operationalized, that's being finalized. So we are investing in the shipbuilding infrastructure and I can tell you that that's on the part of CSSC, not sure if Fincantieri is continuing or not, you had to ask them. But that's, with CSSC and ourselves, we're looking -- we will be -- at this point, a minority participant in joint venture, open to manage the marketing, manage the fleet, and that CSSC and CIC, either majority orders or the joint venture for the domestic Chinese effort.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then your selling and administrative expenses came in quite a bit lower than we had modeled. Can you talk about maybe where you guys have made the most ends there and where you still see the best opportunity to gain on some of the expense struct
componenttext: Okay, and then your selling and administrative expenses came in quite a bit lower than we had modeled. Can you talk about maybe where you guys have made the most ends there and where you still see the best opportunity to gain on some of the expense structure you currently have in place?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have process across a number of fronts. We'll highlight more -- we are at -- we'll definitely, we will achieve our $75 million target this year and we'll have more detail on that in the next earnings call. But we continue to see opportunities across th
componenttext: We have process across a number of fronts. We'll highlight more -- we are at -- we'll definitely, we will achieve our $75 million target this year and we'll have more detail on that in the next earnings call. But we continue to see opportunities across the board. Some highlights this year were freight and marketing as well as food provisioning. Going forward, we see additional opportunities in all those areas, plus we're beginning to get to stores, our technical stores, much as a big area of expense for us, inventories on the ships, et cetera. That takes a little more to get things coded properly so you can monitor and measure. But we're starting to make progress there.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think David has a comment, go ahead.
componenttext: I think David has a comment, go ahead.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the SG&A expense, I don't know exactly which were modeled, we did gave guidance for the whole year for net cruise costs without fuel being up 1.5%. We did beat our third quarter cost guidance because of the timing of certain expenses. And I mentio
componenttext: Yes, on the SG&A expense, I don't know exactly which were modeled, we did gave guidance for the whole year for net cruise costs without fuel being up 1.5%. We did beat our third quarter cost guidance because of the timing of certain expenses. And I mentioned that one of them was advertising. So we may have spent a little bit less than the third quarter in advertising than we previously anticipated, which could have affected your comparison.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow up from Steve's question before on Zika that you're not seeing a noticeable impact. Why do you think that you're performing better than some of your competitors in the Caribbean in the fourth quarter where we've been hearing about some a
componenttext: And just a follow up from Steve's question before on Zika that you're not seeing a noticeable impact. Why do you think that you're performing better than some of your competitors in the Caribbean in the fourth quarter where we've been hearing about some aggressive discounts and promotions coming from some of those competitors lately?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're not making any comments obviously on the competitors. But just for ourselves, it runs the gamut from first and foremost. Our people and our brands have done a great job developing the guest experience. And the guests are having just tremendous
componenttext: Yes, we're not making any comments obviously on the competitors. But just for ourselves, it runs the gamut from first and foremost. Our people and our brands have done a great job developing the guest experience. And the guests are having just tremendous experiences. And we are exceeding their expectations across the brands as they go into the Caribbean, especially with the Carnival brand, so that's number 1. Number 2, in the case of the Carnival brand in particular again, we have a very large base of previous cruise goers that are loyal to the brand. And that obviously helps us because those people have experienced the brand and love it and want to do it again and again. And then thirdly, we're better in our revenue management skills. And so we have shared our best practices across the brands, our revenue management. And our people are getting increasingly sophisticated and doing very, very well. Also, we've anticipated a bit of an election slowdown historically. There's always been a little falloff in booking volumes around election time. And so there could be some of that. But in our case, again, right now, we're doing so well and we are so far ahead and the pricing is strong. We've got great constant pricing right now. And so it's been very good. But relative to what the other companies, other cruise lines, I wouldn't have a comment. But other than to say, I'm sure it's a combination of the relative moves they made in deployment and stuff. But I have no idea.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only other thing that I wanted to add is that in the Caribbean, keep in mind that our capacity is distributed across multiple home ports which I think we benefit from as well.
componenttext: And the only other thing that I wanted to add is that in the Caribbean, keep in mind that our capacity is distributed across multiple home ports which I think we benefit from as well.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Moving to China and if you think about 2017 and how you're negotiating pricing ultimately will end up, I know you're not going to give us a specific number right now. But maybe just some thoughts of how you think it will -- that will
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Moving to China and if you think about 2017 and how you're negotiating pricing ultimately will end up, I know you're not going to give us a specific number right now. But maybe just some thoughts of how you think it will -- that will proceed? And also is it the right way to think about it if you're growing capacity there -- the capacity there by 26%, would you expect the profitability of your China business to grow equal or greater to that in 2017? So that's what you're managing to that profitability growth?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Real quick, I think the important thing for us in China is to ensure that we are developing sustainable business there. Sustainable for our distributor partners, sustainable in terms of the government's desire to have the cruise industry be established th
componenttext: Real quick, I think the important thing for us in China is to ensure that we are developing sustainable business there. Sustainable for our distributor partners, sustainable in terms of the government's desire to have the cruise industry be established there and obviously, sustainable for us from a profit standpoint. So that has to be a win-win-win. So that begins the constraint about how much we will negotiate because we're not going to negotiate to a point where it's not economical for us. And that just won't happen. And so having said that, the other comment is if you take the impact this quarter, given the additional consideration we've reflected in the guidance going forward, the impact for the full year on [indiscernible] losses across our fleet is a rounding error. So we believe that we can effect [ph] a sustainable business in China over time. We're going to make practical economic decisions, our assets are mobile. And because of such a small percentage, even in the future we start looking at adding additional ships of our overall capacity, we can move a few ships around and manage [indiscernible] through smart deployment. Having said that, for next year, right now, we see good relationships with our distributor partners and an ability to extract value. Hopefully, it will be proportioned to the capacity increase are greater. But at this point, we haven't finalized those conversations. It's too early to give real guidance.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also, the capacity increase is driven, to a great extent, by the introduction of Majestic Princess. And that's the first purpose-built ship for the China market and we really do believe that that will generate a lot of great excitement and further sti
componenttext: And also, the capacity increase is driven, to a great extent, by the introduction of Majestic Princess. And that's the first purpose-built ship for the China market and we really do believe that that will generate a lot of great excitement and further stimulate demand in the market, which should be very helpful on the pricing side.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of James Hardiman with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of James Hardiman with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions here. Obviously, since the last time you guys reported, there were a number of geopolitical events. Could you maybe walk us through what happened during and following that time? It doesn't seem to have really hurt your numbers for
componenttext: So a couple of questions here. Obviously, since the last time you guys reported, there were a number of geopolitical events. Could you maybe walk us through what happened during and following that time? It doesn't seem to have really hurt your numbers for the quarter or in terms of the outlook. Was it that you didn't see any impact on demand? Was it that you're maybe a little bit more isolated because you don't have a lot of exposure to U.S. customers going to Europe? Or does it in fact impact your business and your yields would have been all the better for the third quarter in terms of the outlook if it hadn't been for those two geopolitical events?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So real quickly, in terms of [indiscernible] in the U.S, going in to Europe, we do have, in our Holland America brands, our Princess brand and even in our [indiscernible] where we have a number of Americans who go to Europe across our brands, Seabourn, et
componenttext: So real quickly, in terms of [indiscernible] in the U.S, going in to Europe, we do have, in our Holland America brands, our Princess brand and even in our [indiscernible] where we have a number of Americans who go to Europe across our brands, Seabourn, et cetera. So it is important to us. So the impact was this. In the cases when things got a little dicey in Istanbul and in Turkey, we obviously had to make deployment itinerary changes. So again, generally speaking, we go where our guests want to go and we go obviously where all the information we have says it's okay to go, it's safe to go because safety is number 1, obviously. And so we -- how it affects us is we make itinerary deployment changes, either because guests don't want to go or because we've gotten intelligence in the world community that it's wise not to go, it affects us that way. Additionally, we can see booking impacts right after the incident. Those tend to fade away. As you know, if you go back over years, this is not a year where this is the only time that it has happened, it happens to some extent almost in recent times, almost every year for the last several years, as does Zika, our [indiscernible], our [indiscernible], whatever these things Ebola  even. And so every year, there's geopolitical tensions, there's some kind of disease [indiscernible] nation, there's macro economic malaise, there is isolated or concentrated overcapacity in the cruise industry every year and in some markets around the world, all those things happen. And as part of our business. So we manage that, we anticipated. We change deployments. We do good revenue management practices, manage around it and that's basically it. So to us, it's normal business. I wish it wasn't that way. Every now and then, hopefully we'll get lucky and hopefully [indiscernible] those incidents because we think we will do better. Some of those itineraries we had to redirect are high-yielding short excursion. Items which could have added additional revenue and earnings to the bottom-line. We used to be in the Black Sea. We haven't been there for quite a lot. The Black Sea was one of the highest yielding, both from a ticket standpoint and mobile revenue standpoint, itineraries we could've had. And so hopefully, sometimes, those things are working in our favor and will do even better. But right now, we expect that stuff to happen to us every year and we had to manage it and we have to deliver double-digit return to invested capital in those environments.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one of the things that we've said previously is that, as Arnold indicated, there's always something going on out there that people to some extent have gotten used to that and they go on with their lives and they continue to travel and continue to book
componenttext: And one of the things that we've said previously is that, as Arnold indicated, there's always something going on out there that people to some extent have gotten used to that and they go on with their lives and they continue to travel and continue to book cruises. And so we did very well in the third quarter. And as we had indicated, we have raised our guidance for the year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful, and then my second question may or may not be related to the first. But can you talk a little bit about the slowdown in onboard? I know you mentioned that the comps are just fundamentally tougher? I guess A, was maybe some of that the
componenttext: That's very helpful, and then my second question may or may not be related to the first. But can you talk a little bit about the slowdown in onboard? I know you mentioned that the comps are just fundamentally tougher? I guess A, was maybe some of that the result of some of the itinerary changes that you just spoke to or may be sourcing changes as you try to bring in more Europeans to those European destinations versus North Americans which typically spend more well onboard? And then I guess just going forward, should we expect onboard to be a drag on overall yields going forward? Or does that revert back to where it's been the last 1.5 years?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first of all, we've had almost 8 quarters of very strong onboard revenue growth. So the comparisons are obviously getting more difficult. On the other hand, we're still growing. Onboard revenue is still a growth story. So we would not characterize it a
componenttext: So first of all, we've had almost 8 quarters of very strong onboard revenue growth. So the comparisons are obviously getting more difficult. On the other hand, we're still growing. Onboard revenue is still a growth story. So we would not characterize it as a drag. We would definitely characterize it as still accretive to the bottom line because it is still growing and we think there's opportunity to grow beyond where we are today obviously.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess some of it, if you look at the detail relative to that categories of onboard and what drove some of the change in the increase, we did see some really nice increases in both beverage and casino which make up about half of the onboard revenue. And
componenttext: I guess some of it, if you look at the detail relative to that categories of onboard and what drove some of the change in the increase, we did see some really nice increases in both beverage and casino which make up about half of the onboard revenue. And the areas where we saw some lower onboard revenue relating to short excursions which we talked about relating to itinerary changes and itinerary optimization across the brands, as well as shops where last year, benefited from some strong guarantee arrangements in 2015 and prior periods.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there seems to be some skepticism today about the outlook or your comments about next year that is still too early to tell much. Maybe you can give us a sense of where -- how well booked you are overall fleet wide this year versus the same time last ye
componenttext: So there seems to be some skepticism today about the outlook or your comments about next year that is still too early to tell much. Maybe you can give us a sense of where -- how well booked you are overall fleet wide this year versus the same time last year? And do you really think that it is too early to, with this data, to make any initial conclusions that you're off to a good start?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the conclusion is we're definitely off to a good start but we're not prepared to give guidance yet in full for 2017.
componenttext: Well, I think the conclusion is we're definitely off to a good start but we're not prepared to give guidance yet in full for 2017.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we'll give guidance on the revenue side in December when we get closer, consider [ph] the [indiscernible] at this point. Harry, we have said that we are ahead of the prior year. And we are ahead at considerably higher prices. So we're feeling very go
componenttext: When we'll give guidance on the revenue side in December when we get closer, consider [ph] the [indiscernible] at this point. Harry, we have said that we are ahead of the prior year. And we are ahead at considerably higher prices. So we're feeling very good about that overall position. We've talked about how we're moving the booking curve further and further out and we have continued to move it out for the early half of 2017. All the markets, I went through the details, both for the North American market and our EAA brands and everybody was pretty much ahead on pricing, except EAA for the Caribbean and Australia, which was in line. And I even said in those areas, the booking activity for the last quarter was well ahead of the prior year. So those areas were -- even though they were in line or at a slightly lower, they were improving. So we feel very good about the overall trends for the first half of 2017.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So following up then on the -- on your comments about the yield management rollout. To what degree do you think the yield management, the new system is, or maybe having -- or playing a factor in these higher prices? And perhaps you could just educate us o
componenttext: So following up then on the -- on your comments about the yield management rollout. To what degree do you think the yield management, the new system is, or maybe having -- or playing a factor in these higher prices? And perhaps you could just educate us on what's changing?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, in terms of the impact of the new system, you're not seeing much direct impact from the new system right now. You'll see, on maybe 30% of inventory going into '17, some impact. And then the full impact for the current state of the syst
componenttext: Well, first of all, in terms of the impact of the new system, you're not seeing much direct impact from the new system right now. You'll see, on maybe 30% of inventory going into '17, some impact. And then the full impact for the current state of the system and it will take it to a higher level next year. But the full impact for the current state of system will probably be more on 2018. What you are seeing though is the fact, just the fact by working on it, we're sharing best practices across our [indiscernible] cruise line brands and that sharing and then working together on the two[ph]  And so on and clearly has been advantageous and has boosted our yields. Beyond that, it's again, as I mentioned, it's a combination of creating demand, of clever deployment and of exceeding guest expectations once onboard so that when they leave, they help us create demand themselves, only for them to come back for others that they share with. The brands are differentiated, that helps as well. And we've done some smart things in terms of -- within the brands, of our various home porting decisions and distributing the home ports to access various destination markets. So it's a combination of things. We have good momentum that has to be maintained. Of course what will help us in the end, is if the other cruise companies also fill and fill in high prices, I mean, that ultimately is helpful to us. If they don't, that's a drag for us because that sets a psychological tone in the marketplace. But right now, we are doing very well and the first half of next year looks very strong.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I want to add to that, the one other thing that's been very helpful is the brands had been working collectively together, comparing price and making decisions. And as a result of that, given the fact that the size of our company, I thi
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I want to add to that, the one other thing that's been very helpful is the brands had been working collectively together, comparing price and making decisions. And as a result of that, given the fact that the size of our company, I think that has benefited us tremendously over the last couple of years as well.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a quick shifting of gears here. Carnival is rapidly becoming an impressive free cash flow generator. And your -- and it seems the market is valuing higher dividends today more than it has in the last decade. Have you given consideration to even g
componenttext: And just a quick shifting of gears here. Carnival is rapidly becoming an impressive free cash flow generator. And your -- and it seems the market is valuing higher dividends today more than it has in the last decade. Have you given consideration to even getting more aggressive with dividend payout versus share repurchases? How do you prioritize at this point one versus another?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, I'll clear it that that's a board decision right off the bat. But having said that, historically, you've seen what we've done where we've done a combination of dividend increases and share buyback. I'm sure that we will continue it in the fu
componenttext: First of all, I'll clear it that that's a board decision right off the bat. But having said that, historically, you've seen what we've done where we've done a combination of dividend increases and share buyback. I'm sure that we will continue it in the future but we evaluate it constantly. But we'll see where the board wants to go. Our current dividend yield is strong. But we'll be evaluating that each quarter.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One of the things we've said in the past is that we are targeting a 40% to 50% dividend payout ratio. So one of the things you do want to be careful is that we want to make sure that our dividend is sustainable through all cycles. And so we feel stay
componenttext: Yes. One of the things we've said in the past is that we are targeting a 40% to 50% dividend payout ratio. So one of the things you do want to be careful is that we want to make sure that our dividend is sustainable through all cycles. And so we feel staying within that range, it will be sustainable. So you can take that as guidance, that's what we discussed with the board and we continue to target that.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of David [indiscernible] with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of David [indiscernible] with Bernstein Research.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And thanks for particularly the Chinese to come through indiscernible]. We appreciate it, but I'll have another one there [indiscernible] you talked a lot about net revenue yields in the region. I was wondering. What I haven't heard as much is any color o
componenttext: And thanks for particularly the Chinese to come through indiscernible]. We appreciate it, but I'll have another one there [indiscernible] you talked a lot about net revenue yields in the region. I was wondering. What I haven't heard as much is any color on the trajectory of net cruise costs specifically as it relates to China, inclusive of things like office expansion, incremental marketing and the like. Could you potentially provide us any color or context on how to think about that for that region?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make comment on what I think is very important that David comments, his last name is the namesake for your firm, [indiscernible]. But in any event, look, it's an embryonic market. We think there are opportunities overtime to actually improve our net
componenttext: I'll make comment on what I think is very important that David comments, his last name is the namesake for your firm, [indiscernible]. But in any event, look, it's an embryonic market. We think there are opportunities overtime to actually improve our net cruise cost position on an ALBD basis, as we expand and get greater scale and so on. And we think there's opportunity to actually improve that part of the equation as well. Right now, it's not the driver for anything. And -- but as we get more capacity there and we began to expand our supply chains, our training centers and so on and so forth, we think we'll be able to actually, over time, improve on that cruise cost.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: As Arnold indicated, in 2015, we had 8 offices in China. We went to 16 offices in 2016 and we're going to open up 4 more in 2017. So clearly, we are making an investment. But we believe the investments for the long-term. Keep in mind that we've got an $8
componenttext: As Arnold indicated, in 2015, we had 8 offices in China. We went to 16 offices in 2016 and we're going to open up 4 more in 2017. So clearly, we are making an investment. But we believe the investments for the long-term. Keep in mind that we've got an $8 billion cost base, so we're 1 percentage change -- a 1 point change in our net cruise costs without fuel is $80 million. So our investment in China is really just fractions of a percent, a really very small change in the overall picture for a company of our size.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. And as a follow up, I just wanted to ask a question about the distribution system in China. I was curious, we've heard some color about various selling practices on the ground in China. I was curious what level of control you have w
componenttext: That's really helpful. And as a follow up, I just wanted to ask a question about the distribution system in China. I was curious, we've heard some color about various selling practices on the ground in China. I was curious what level of control you have with respect to pricing discipline from the travel agent community? Thanks.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet. First of all, basically, for us right now, it's a B2B business. We charter with some Asia distributors. They've been sell through their network. But they also in turn, expand their network through sub agents or sub distributors. And that's a nego
componenttext: You bet. First of all, basically, for us right now, it's a B2B business. We charter with some Asia distributors. They've been sell through their network. But they also in turn, expand their network through sub agents or sub distributors. And that's a negotiation between them and the sub distributors on pricing and so on. So how we control the pricing, which we don't really per se, control, we control what price we're getting. And then it's up to them to manage to see how much profit they're going to take and so on and so forth. But where -- all the control we have is, in the end, if they come back and say, hey, I didn't do as well as I thought, why don't you help me out, et cetera, that's a negotiation, that's a foot. It happens every year. But that's the level of control we have by our degree of willingness to negotiate. In some cases, they may have legitimate challenges. In some cases, they are just negotiating to get a better deal. And you've got to do your best to sort all that out when you don't have total transparency to the ultimate price that Chinese guests that was on the ship paid. We tried to get at that various ways. But of course, others try to make certain and we can't get to that information. And that's on -- that's just a business, normally in business. You can think of other constructs in other places where a manufacturer sells to a distributor and may not know exactly what the distributor priced them and so on in any other market, in any other industry. So that's the nature the business today. Overtime, that will probably evolve to a different model. But that's what it is today.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016

componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Jamie Rollo with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, on the supply growth in the industry. You said the Carnival is only growing at 3% to 4% after 2020, but obviously, the industry order book is much bigger than that. I was wondering what your thoughts are on the size of that order book. It's
componenttext: First of all, on the supply growth in the industry. You said the Carnival is only growing at 3% to 4% after 2020, but obviously, the industry order book is much bigger than that. I was wondering what your thoughts are on the size of that order book. It's clearly much, much bigger than it was at the last peak. Particularly as China has been able to absorb all of those new ships. Are you worried about for the capacity in the developed markets a few years ahead?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that obviously, as China is growing rapidly, and as able to absorb a lot of capacity, that makes everything easier. But on the other hand, as I try to point out earlier in the call and in some of the questions, China's going to be limited in how m
componenttext: I think that obviously, as China is growing rapidly, and as able to absorb a lot of capacity, that makes everything easier. But on the other hand, as I try to point out earlier in the call and in some of the questions, China's going to be limited in how many ships are going to be available for it to take because people are building ships while the markets as well. I think what you had to think about is the capacity growth. So we're always going to build new ships and so will others. And the reason is because the ships are more efficient, okay? And they give you the opportunity for enhanced revenue opportunity versus the existing ships. And so new ships are always going to be coming. The question is how many ships leave? How many ships go to secondary markets and so on? And in the opening comments, I referenced the fact that the number of berths that are getting to retirement, the amount of capacity that's going to go into retirement age is going to double in 2020 and they're going to double again in 2024. And so there will be a need for some of that capacity just to replace. And then the rest will get regulated by the marketplace. If there's scarce supply relative to demand, some of the less efficient ships will continue to sell. If there's not, there's relative scarcity, then some of those ships will exit. They will either go to secondary markets or they leave the fleet and be scrapped. And so that's the real dynamic. We know what we're going to do. We are committed to measured capacity growth and we know how to manage it within our brands and across the various destinations. And so based on that, we have great confidence that we'll be able to manage to the sustained double-digit return on invested capital that we have promised within the next 2 years.

componenttext: But onboard is not -- I may have misheard what you said in the beginning. But we are not weakening on onboard. We're still growing onboard. It's just not at the rapid rate that we had than some of the previous quarters. And then, I just wanted to add one comment to -- concerning then newbuild. And, for us, because we had 10 brands, 3% to 4% is not the same as 3% to 4% for a single brand type of cruise company. So we're spreading out these newbuilds across a number of brands, which gives that brand base an opportunity to absorb the capacity while they're creating the excess demand required to get the relative scarcity we're chasing. So we are, overall, managing some measured capacity growth in total. But we're also doing it by brand. And that allows us to more effectively manage against a committed base of loyal cruisers to that brand and reduce the number of new to cruise at any point in time we have to generate for any given brand

componenttext: At the risk of you playing a tape that, I think we said we were hopeful we have additional by year-end and I'd say at this point in time, while that's a possibility, we might know something before this year is out about additional brands going next year into Cuba. Again, we are hopeful. I wouldn't say we expect it. But we're working on it and hopefully, as you know, to date, we are the only ones that have received approval by Cuba to sail to and from Cuba from the U.S. So we're the only one so far. I'm sure that will change. Exactly when it will change and how many other brands, we can't get in there beyond our [indiscernible] than we have now remains to be seen but we're in a constant conversation with the various authorities in Cuba. It's been an exciting year in that regard for us. It has helped us across our fleet in a number of ways with both the positive media and so on and so forth. But beyond all that, why it hasn't been, frankly, with our single ship of 700 guests, obviously, financially, it's not hugely material. But it has been important in establishing the relationships and the dialogue and the partnerships to prepare the foundation for what will be a destination that will help refresh the Caribbean and ultimately, contribute to that relative scarcity that I like to talk about, excess demand relative to supply and be a source of strength for yields and returns in the years to come.
