componenttext: What I can tell you, Harry, is a little color on your other question. On the revenue management system is, obviously, we just -- the 2, we just put it in place and there'll be continuous learning. So we think over time, there's real upside contribution from that. And I know the teams absolutely love working with the tool.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Hardiman with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Hardiman with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could give us a little bit more color on Cuba. You had made the announcement that Fathom is transitioning back to P&O. I guess, what does that mean for the impact travel experiment? And then I guess, what happens next? I don't think we ha
componenttext: I was hoping you could give us a little bit more color on Cuba. You had made the announcement that Fathom is transitioning back to P&O. I guess, what does that mean for the impact travel experiment? And then I guess, what happens next? I don't think we had gotten an official announcement in terms of the other brands and when and how many are going to be going to Cuba. But was hoping we can get an update there.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, regarding Cuba, again, we're really privileged that we were the first, then in doing so, it paved the way for the rest of the industry. We still, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, we'll have more calls to Cuba than any other majo
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, regarding Cuba, again, we're really privileged that we were the first, then in doing so, it paved the way for the rest of the industry. We still, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, we'll have more calls to Cuba than any other major U.S. cruise company. So we feel very good about our position in Cuba. Along with everyone else, we submitted our request for additional sailings through -- from beginning in the June period and thereafter, and it's just the planning cycle in Cuba. And we're in the process of receiving the authorizations from Cuba as we speak here now about that. But we have every intention of cruising to Cuba. We have every expectation one or more of our brands will be approved from the June time period on and through May, as I mentioned, we have more sailings than anyone else. In terms of the Fathom, Adonia was basically sort of the internal charter, the brand charter that established the concept and also obviously to position us to introduce into Cuba. And we're going to probably -- well, not probably. We are going to go with larger ships and multiple brands in Cuba. With regard to the DR, we're also going with multiple brands for Fathom. So Fathom is being expanded across a number of brands in the DR. The on-the-ground experiences have resonated greatly with the guests and we will take some of the onboard stuff from Adonia and Fathom to the other brands. But the emphasis, of course, is the on-ground experiences in DR and to continue to have the opportunity for travelers to have that deep travel experience and for the DR to reap the benefits of the impact of having those travelers working alongside. The impact clearly is already in the DR. They're doing great work.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then along those same lines, remind us why the first quarter trend looks to be short of the fiscal -- full-year trend, fiscal '17 trend. I think it's 1.5 to 2.5 for the first quarter versus 2.5 for the year. I don't know if that has anything to
componenttext: Great. And then along those same lines, remind us why the first quarter trend looks to be short of the fiscal -- full-year trend, fiscal '17 trend. I think it's 1.5 to 2.5 for the first quarter versus 2.5 for the year. I don't know if that has anything to do with Cuba or even if Cuba is factored into your yield guidance in any way.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It has nothing to do with Cuba, but go ahead, David.
componenttext: It has nothing to do with Cuba, but go ahead, David.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's just the midpoint to the first quarter is 2% versus to 2.5% approximately for the year. And the first quarter had tougher comparisons in the prior year. But keep in mind, we're only talking about a 0.5 point here, and so we give you our best gue
componenttext: Yes. It's just the midpoint to the first quarter is 2% versus to 2.5% approximately for the year. And the first quarter had tougher comparisons in the prior year. But keep in mind, we're only talking about a 0.5 point here, and so we give you our best guess for each and every number.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I guess just lastly, I just wanted to circle back to China. Obviously, you've made it pretty clear that China is more about generating positive returns than yields. But I know it's early, but maybe just directionally, do you think yields are go
componenttext: Great. And I guess just lastly, I just wanted to circle back to China. Obviously, you've made it pretty clear that China is more about generating positive returns than yields. But I know it's early, but maybe just directionally, do you think yields are going to be down again for 2017? Is there even the chance that they could grow? And I guess what are the contributing factors there? Obviously, capacity in China is going to be much more manageable in '17 versus '16. It seems like you guys are pretty bullish about the improvement in your distribution, but how should I think about that?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, first of all, you touched on a couple of good points there. We have expanded distribution. That improves the B2B aspect of what we're doing there. But we're going to have tougher comparisons in the first half of the year in China with yields. A
componenttext: Yes, well, first of all, you touched on a couple of good points there. We have expanded distribution. That improves the B2B aspect of what we're doing there. But we're going to have tougher comparisons in the first half of the year in China with yields. And so based on what happened in the last half of the year, you might expect yields to be down in the first half of the year on a comparison basis. But then, expectations are that it will be up in the second half of the year. So on balance, we'll see where it lands. But China, for us, is a volume growth story. It's a return story. The yields that we have experienced this past year are certainly still generating good returns. We see possibility for increasing yields, but our focus, again, is continuing that high level of occupancy that we have, continue delivering great experience to Chinese guests to be in position to expand the market.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Katz with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jamie Katz with Morningstar.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it seems like you guys are about to launch some sort of new technology initiatives at CES. And I'm curious, given that CapEx is a little bit higher than we originally anticipated next year, is there any sort of level of CapEx associated with whatever n
componenttext: So it seems like you guys are about to launch some sort of new technology initiatives at CES. And I'm curious, given that CapEx is a little bit higher than we originally anticipated next year, is there any sort of level of CapEx associated with whatever new initiatives you guys are going to launch? And is there any sort of multi-year cost that we should be thinking about going forward?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Jaime, for the question. First of all, the capital that has -- is being employed in that initiative is kind of part of a low level 3% to 5% of our total capital spend annually that we look at for basically research and development and innovat
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Jaime, for the question. First of all, the capital that has -- is being employed in that initiative is kind of part of a low level 3% to 5% of our total capital spend annually that we look at for basically research and development and innovation. And so we have invested along the way all this time as we delivered the earnings we've delivered in that manner to position us to have the opportunity to introduce this particular, truly is a guest experience. It's driven by technology. But the technology, obviously, the guest will be invisible. And we're excited about the potential. The guest, ultimately, will decide, and we're prepared. But fundamentally, for your planning purposes, we look at a 3% to 5% level of innovation and research and development kind of investment in capital. And we feel that it is appropriate for a company of our scale and it gives us plenty of dollars to try to create breakthroughs which we think, obviously, this current introduction that will be reviewed -- revealed on January 5 has the potential to be.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I think yesterday, you guys put out a press release saying that a new ship in 2019 would be going to Carnival. It was originally planned to go to maybe P&O Cruises Australia, if I'm recalling correctly. So I'm just curious if there are any
componenttext: Okay. And then I think yesterday, you guys put out a press release saying that a new ship in 2019 would be going to Carnival. It was originally planned to go to maybe P&O Cruises Australia, if I'm recalling correctly. So I'm just curious if there are any new conclusions surrounding the Australian market, given that you're moving the new hardware back to the Caribbean, which has clearly been performing very well?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Australia remains a big growth market for our cruise and growing 20% for I don't know how many years now, 10-years plus. So it's a very strong cruise market. When we make decisions like that, you just have to keep in mind, it's very holistic. There ar
componenttext: No, Australia remains a big growth market for our cruise and growing 20% for I don't know how many years now, 10-years plus. So it's a very strong cruise market. When we make decisions like that, you just have to keep in mind, it's very holistic. There are a gazillion variables that go into play. One, obviously, the Carnival brand is doing very, very, very well here in the states. But also, we have multiple home ports in the U.S. We distribute a fleet around the U.S. for Carnival. And certain places can take certain ships, and certain places can only take certain-sized ships and so on. And balancing all that out makes a difference. And similarly, too, in Australia, certain-sized ships can fit if you look at the destinations. But we've had so much success with Vista, the Carnival Vista, we're looking at expanding the opportunity for Carnival brand, while at the same time, still giving really guest-ready and guest-preferred Hartwell in Australian market. So there's only so many shipyards, we can only build so many ships a year. And we have to allocate things and we're always trying to optimize. But it's a holistic decision involving a lot of variables, deployment, itinerary, relative yield contribution, a number of things.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the second part of the announcement was the Carnival splendor moving to P&O Australia. So we are continuing to grow that brand within Australia.
componenttext: And the second part of the announcement was the Carnival splendor moving to P&O Australia. So we are continuing to grow that brand within Australia.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to kind of follow-on to James' question on China. It kind of sounded like net yields for full year 2017 would maybe be around flattish year-over-year, at least not too far off from flat year-over-year either way. Is that correct? And then also, ho
componenttext: So just to kind of follow-on to James' question on China. It kind of sounded like net yields for full year 2017 would maybe be around flattish year-over-year, at least not too far off from flat year-over-year either way. Is that correct? And then also, how much of the China business is locked in at this point for 2017?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just remember that China represents, even with the increase next year and introduction of the Majestic Princess, the first purpose-built ship for China, our Princess line will introduce -- will represent less than 6% of our capacity. So just keep
componenttext: Yes. So just remember that China represents, even with the increase next year and introduction of the Majestic Princess, the first purpose-built ship for China, our Princess line will introduce -- will represent less than 6% of our capacity. So just keep that in mind. We'll see where yields end up, okay?  Again, it's a B2B business. In terms of guidance, of course, we've put it in. We don't give brand by brand and total geography by geography yields, so I won't do it for China either. But we've given you a good description, I think, of what you can expect. The message we like you guys to hear, clearly, is that it's a return on driven business. And with all the concerns people expressed this year on China, as well as concerns expressed in lots of other areas and whatnot, you can see we're able to deliver an ultimate result. We're very, very bullish on China long term. We have great partners in CSSC. We -- our relationship there is growing stronger and stronger. We're moving forward together to help build a long-standing, sustainable cruise industry in China, which has been declared in the 5-year plan by the Chinese government. So we're bullish, but it's a slow walk. We can only send so many ships and so on. And so we feel really confident overall.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the second part of the question, you had asked about where we stand in China. Given the historical averages of where we're booked and give or take, generally speaking, we start the year, roughly about half booked. But I did indicate before that China
componenttext: And the second part of the question, you had asked about where we stand in China. Given the historical averages of where we're booked and give or take, generally speaking, we start the year, roughly about half booked. But I did indicate before that China is a much later booking market. Every country is different. And so they are closer in booking market less than that overall.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. And then -- that all makes sense. And then the North American passengers going to Europe, I know that's still a small part of your overall mix in Europe for itineraries in Europe. It's only about 10% that you source from North America. But w
componenttext: Right, right. And then -- that all makes sense. And then the North American passengers going to Europe, I know that's still a small part of your overall mix in Europe for itineraries in Europe. It's only about 10% that you source from North America. But with the broad strength that we've seen, could that have a significant impact in benefit for you if that continues? And I understand the attack in Germany may have a negative impact, but it does seem like that -- the trend has been pretty strong recently.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the trends have been positive overall, but we've had to redo a number of itineraries along the way. That has cost us in terms of opportunity in '16. But that is all part of our business. And so again, on balance, we give guidance, the numbers we feel
componenttext: Yes, the trends have been positive overall, but we've had to redo a number of itineraries along the way. That has cost us in terms of opportunity in '16. But that is all part of our business. And so again, on balance, we give guidance, the numbers we feel are reasonable. We know the world is a volatile place, and so we factor that into everything we do. But sure, anything that's positive in the end obviously helps us. And the North American brands have a number of itineraries planned in Europe and our guests are looking forward to them, and we're looking forward to capturing the value for them.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked. Just kind of 1 or 2 follow ups. I just wanted to clarify on Cuba, what is in your yield guidance, your EPS guidance for the year in terms of Cuba? Is it just an expectation that one ship, not yet specified will contin
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked. Just kind of 1 or 2 follow ups. I just wanted to clarify on Cuba, what is in your yield guidance, your EPS guidance for the year in terms of Cuba? Is it just an expectation that one ship, not yet specified will continue to operate there from May until the end of the year? Or does that include perhaps more than that?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Robin, first of all, good morning to you. And I'm a little surprised, you're usually much earlier in the calls on your question.
componenttext: Yes. So Robin, first of all, good morning to you. And I'm a little surprised, you're usually much earlier in the calls on your question.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know what happened, yes. I'm not sure what happened either.
componenttext: I don't know what happened, yes. I'm not sure what happened either.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But concerning Cuba, look, today, we have Adonia. It's a 700-passenger ship. So the reality is you can barely find the numbers, but even though the ship is getting a premium price and is selling out and so on. And so, as you look at it, again, on Cuba, wi
componenttext: But concerning Cuba, look, today, we have Adonia. It's a 700-passenger ship. So the reality is you can barely find the numbers, but even though the ship is getting a premium price and is selling out and so on. And so, as you look at it, again, on Cuba, will be slow expansion. And so we'll have additional itineraries going there. Hopefully, we'll have more than one brand once we get the final approvals from the Cuban authorities. But they have constraints in the number of birds and the size of the birds and what size ships you can get in and so on. So financially, to be candid with you, it's important in the margin and, certainly, important to the brands. But the most important thing is positioning for the longer haul. And positioning to lift overall demand and interest in the Caribbean. And then ultimately, because of that, create additional opportunity for catching more of the value through increase on yields. And so, Cuba's a longer-term play, but you have to build it today, and that's what we're doing. But in terms of the financial impact on the corporation, you couldn't find it probably.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, great, that's helpful. And then on China, and I know that, obviously, it's early yet and you don't want to give a specific yield guidance for the market. But just on your comment that it's -- the returns will continue to be positive, or I don't
componenttext: Okay. No, great, that's helpful. And then on China, and I know that, obviously, it's early yet and you don't want to give a specific yield guidance for the market. But just on your comment that it's -- the returns will continue to be positive, or I don't know whether you indicated whether returns would grow or just that they would be positive or more relative to other brands. Well, because my question is with the Majestic going there, I think that's your first newbuild for that market, and so would be a higher investment per berth than the other tonnage that you have there. So it's fair to assume, right, that, that ship is getting a price premium to your other capacity in China. So I guess that's why I'm surprised that you wouldn't feel comfortable saying positive yields for the year just given that if returns would continue to be what they are given that newer ship.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, you got to look at the holistic. There's a lot of going on there. You've got, first of all, different ports in different seasons. We're one of the few companies that commit it year-round. So the Tianjin market is different than the Shanghai m
componenttext: Well, again, you got to look at the holistic. There's a lot of going on there. You've got, first of all, different ports in different seasons. We're one of the few companies that commit it year-round. So the Tianjin market is different than the Shanghai market, so on and so forth. So there's lots of things that move in that. But here's the real answer, fundamental underlying answer to your questions. Yes, we expect returns overall to be better in '17 than they were in '16, and returns have grown reasonably consistently in China. The most important thing for us is the way we do deployment, we know that the returns are better than what the alternative deployments would have generated for us. And that's the key for us in operating. So overall, we're lifting our overall performance. But it is -- it does represent 5% of our capacity. So it did in '16 and a little bit less than 6% in '17. So as we move forward, we're looking at building that market, but we're doing it in a way where as we grow it, we're seeing higher returns than we would have seen otherwise. And there's a natural constraint on the pace of growth because we have large addressable markets everywhere in the world that are under-penetrated everywhere in the world, including in North America. And so we can't send all the ships to China. And we need new additional capacity in the other places in the world to optimize the ultimate yield and bottom line return.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember, Robin, Majestic gets to China in July, so that's consistent with the comments made -- Arnold made about the first half versus the second half.
componenttext: And remember, Robin, Majestic gets to China in July, so that's consistent with the comments made -- Arnold made about the first half versus the second half.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. No, that's helpful. I mean, our channel check show a really nice, strong premium for Majestic, but I understand that you don't want to commit to anything.
componenttext: Okay, great. No, that's helpful. I mean, our channel check show a really nice, strong premium for Majestic, but I understand that you don't want to commit to anything.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jared Shojaian with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jared Shojaian with Wolfe Research.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, you indicated that about half of your 2017 capacity is booked at this point. So my question is, what kind of pricing do you need to see on the other half that's not yet booked in order to hit your 2.5% yield guidance? Is it possible that pricing co
componenttext: David, you indicated that about half of your 2017 capacity is booked at this point. So my question is, what kind of pricing do you need to see on the other half that's not yet booked in order to hit your 2.5% yield guidance? Is it possible that pricing could be down to get to 2.5%? Is that your expectation?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, I didn't say that exactly half was booked. I said generally speaking that the historical average, give or take, we enter the year approximately half-booked. I wasn't trying to give you an exact number. I was just trying to do that relative t
componenttext: First of all, I didn't say that exactly half was booked. I said generally speaking that the historical average, give or take, we enter the year approximately half-booked. I wasn't trying to give you an exact number. I was just trying to do that relative to China being less than that, that's all. So our pricing is up at this point and we do continue to expect to see pricing continue to be up in the rest of the year and finish the year on an overall basis, as we say, approximately 2.5%.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just to ask that a little bit differently, I mean, you've indicated that you're in a better booked position today than you were at this time last year. And then you also get the mix benefit on yield from Seabourn Encore and maybe ev
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just to ask that a little bit differently, I mean, you've indicated that you're in a better booked position today than you were at this time last year. And then you also get the mix benefit on yield from Seabourn Encore and maybe even get some benefit on -- from the yield management system. So I guess, why is your yield guidance 2.5% when you did 3% this year, if you take out the accounting re-class. Are there just any headwinds that maybe I'm not appreciating? Or are you just looking at this from more of a conservative approach given some of the issues that we felt throughout 2016 for the industry?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you were to take the accounting re-class out, as you referenced, and looked at the guidance we gave this time last year, you'll see our guidance is actually stronger this year at this time than it was last year. Keep in mind, we haven't gotten to wave
componenttext: If you were to take the accounting re-class out, as you referenced, and looked at the guidance we gave this time last year, you'll see our guidance is actually stronger this year at this time than it was last year. Keep in mind, we haven't gotten to wave season yet. We know the world's a volatile place, we just talked about a number of things that have happened, even things that happened yesterday. So we give you our best guidance, realizing that the world is full of things. It's full of typhoons and cyclones and hurricanes, and it's filled with unexpected things like a Brexit or Zika or whatever. And so we give you the guidance as we did last year with that. And if you look at it, you would say, "Okay, they're giving a stronger guidance this year at this point in time than they did last year," which reflects the difference, and the difference is last year, we were ahead on booking at slightly lower prices at this point in time. Now, we're ahead of bookings with higher prices at this time. And so you'll see us give us a little stronger yield guidance. Now keep in mind also, you're coming off a higher base. The comparisons are getting tougher and tougher as we grow yields. In the end, people take money to the bank, not percentages, right? And so the absolute dollar increase to guest, so you have to look at all that, too. But bottom line is we're confident. We, at this point in time, with the qualifiers that we haven't gotten a wave and the world is a strange and mysterious place and is volatile. But factoring that in -- and has been volatile the last many years, and we've been delivering, and that's our intention for '17 as well.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. If I could squeeze one more quick one in. Would you characterize the demand environment today as being better than what it was 2, 3 months ago?
componenttext: Great. If I could squeeze one more quick one in. Would you characterize the demand environment today as being better than what it was 2, 3 months ago?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The demand environment? You mean from consumers in general or from potential guests? I would say that 2 or 3 months ago, that's a good question. I would say this, our brands continue to do an outstanding job of exceeding guest expectations when the guests
componenttext: The demand environment? You mean from consumers in general or from potential guests? I would say that 2 or 3 months ago, that's a good question. I would say this, our brands continue to do an outstanding job of exceeding guest expectations when the guests are on board, and they continue to do an outstanding job of creating more demand for their particular target of segments. And our public relations, more broadly, has done a good job of providing an umbrella effect of getting people to increasingly consider a cruise when they're thinking about vacation holidays. The last 2 to 3 months we're a global business. Every year, there's a recession somewhere or this or that or whatever. And if you are talking globally for our business, I could not say that in the last 2 to 3 months, I see a change in global consumer attitudes or anything like that consistently. What I can say is we definitely see strength and we've seen strength for a while and we're building on that and taking advantage of it.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter 2016 earnings conference call. I'm Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation and plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning and a heartfelt happy holidays, everyone.Today, I'm
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter 2016 earnings conference call. I'm Arnold Donald, President and CEO of Carnival Corporation and plc. Thank you all for joining us this morning and a heartfelt happy holidays, everyone.
Today, I'm joined by our Chairman, Micky Arison; by David Bernstein, our Chief Financial Officer; and by Beth Roberts, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. 
Before I begin, please note that some of our remarks on this call will be forward-looking, therefore, I must refer you to the cautionary statement in today's press release.
We finished the year with another record quarter of adjusted earnings, which were $0.17 per share or 34% higher than the prior year, exceeding the midpoint of guidance by $0.10 per share and leading to the highest full-year earnings in our company's history. 
We achieved full year 2016 adjusted earnings of $2.6 billion, or $3.45 per share. That's $500 million or 28% per share higher than last year, and more than double 2013 earnings of $1.55. More importantly, we achieved return on invested capital of 9% and doubled our 2013 return on invested capital of 4.5%. We are pleased to have delivered for our shareholders doubled earnings and doubled return-on-invested capital in just 3 short years.
Strong operational improvement contributed $0.55 per share to the bottom line year-over-year, which when combined with $0.14 of accretion from our share repurchase program, enabled us to exceed the high end of our original December guidance range of $3.10 to $3.40 per share. And that's despite an $0.18 drag from fuel and currency both moving against us.
These strong results are a credit to the commitment and to the passion of our 120,000 team members, which when coupled with the support from our valued travel agent partners, enabled us to overcome the significant obstacles encountered this past year, including the rare occurrence of a simultaneous negative from fuel and currency, a series of global geopolitical events in Turkey, Paris and Brussels, as well as concerns around Zika and Brexit. It is through their collective efforts that we delivered record earnings in 2016 and are gaining momentum as we embark on 2017 with booking volumes and pricing both well ahead of the prior year. 
It was reinforcing to see constant currency revenue yield growth this year of roughly 4% inclusive of the previously disclosed 1% accounting change on top of the over 4% improvement achieved last year. We enjoyed ticket price improvements for both our North American and our EAA brands, with particularly robust ticket price improvements again in our core Caribbean deployment. 
We drove revenue yield growth by creating relative scarcity through our brand team's success and increasing demand in excess of our measured capacity growth via our ongoing guest experience efforts, coupled with our continuing public relations efforts. In fact, we recently created 3 original TV programs that are airing on major U.S. networks having already reached more than 40 million viewers during the large family-oriented programming blocks. They are designed to entertain, to educate and to engage viewers by showcasing exciting adventures, exotic cultures, beautiful ships and popular global destinations. With almost 80 original episodes, the new experiential series use compelling and authentic storytelling to share the powerful way travel by sea connects people, places and cultures around the world, while prominently featuring each of our brands. 
Not only are we experiencing very high appeal ratings at #1 or #2 in our respective time slot, but we're also achieving even more favorable consumer perception of our brands. 
This successful programming comes on the heels of many impactful shows earlier this year. In the U.K., a reality-based TV series onboard Regal Princess, The Cruise; and P&O Cruises' Battlechefs onboard Britannia. In Italy, Bravo Chef onboard our Costa Ship and our Costa Fortuna, a major motion picture, Holidays in the Caribbean. [ph] In North America, Carnival Cruise Lines was featured on Wheel of Fortune for a full week and featured on the Ellen DeGeneres Show. We have many more opportunities already in the pipeline for next year to keep cruising in the forefront of vacationers' mind, including the new Celebrity Apprentice, airing on NBC in February during wave season, our peak booking period. 
All of these efforts promote consideration around the globe by prominently featuring amazing cruise experiences in our world leading cruise lines. In fact, our brands accounted for over 70% of the industry's positive media coverage. This includes our historic voyage to Cuba, when we became the first U.S. cruise operator in over 40 years to bring U.S. cruise guests directly from the U.S. to Cuba, with over 55 billion very positive media impressions and paving the way for others in our industry to follow. 
At this time, we are proud to have more sailing scheduled to Cuba than any other major U.S. operator. Moreover, our phenomenal guest experience just gets better and better each year as we continue to deliver on consumer expectations, achieving further improvement on our Net Promoter Scores. 
We also introduced 3 new flagships in 2016, including Carnival Vista, which celebrated its U.S. arrival in November with an onboard concert by country music superstar Carrie Underwood supporting Operation Homefront, and with Miss USA, herself military, as the godmother, and including 700 military families invited as guests of honor.  Carnival Vista was designed specifically for our fun-loving Carnival Cruise Line guests with an onboard brewery experience, entertaining IMAX theater and exhilarating SkyRide experience. 
Holland America's Koningsdam presented in Rotterdam by her majesty Queen Maxima of the Netherlands, delivers a new premium experience, where our guests can blend their own wine or dance the night away in our carefully engineered Music Walk showcasing Lincoln Center Stage, Billboard Onboard and B.B. King's Blues Club. 
AIDAprima, the first of a next-generation platform, resonates with AIDA's nearly exclusively German guests, combining leading edge of our general attributes with exceptional guest experiences, including racing water slides, a lazy river, climbing wall, an expansive German spa and an ice rink for skating, for hockey, for curling and even a traditional Christmas market. 
Newbuilds will provide additional demand creation opportunities in 2017 as well, beginning with the recent delivery of Encore for our ultra-luxury brand, Seabourn. Designed by Adam Tihany in keeping with the feel of a luxury yacht, Seabourn Encore sets a new standard in ultra-luxury cruising, featuring 300 elegant suites, The Grill, a new restaurant by 3-star Michelin chef, Thomas Keller, and the debut of a new mindful living program with Dr. Andrew Weil. Later next year, we will welcome AIDAperla in Germany and, of course, Majestic Princess, the first ship purpose-built for Chinese cruisers, demonstrating our commitment to grow the cruise industry in China which remains an embryonic market with vast untapped potential. We expect to continue to profitably grow our presence in China and throughout Asia for many years to come. 
When it comes to ships, newbuilds are not the only way to simulate demand creation though. We continue to invest in our existing fleet to further enhance guest experiences, including the recent remastering of Cunard's Queen Mary 2 and the continued roll-out of Carnival Cruise Lines' Fun Ship 2.0 to now over 60% of the Carnival Cruise Line fleet. 
On January 5, we will kick off the year by unveiling our latest guest experience innovations at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. We are privileged to be the first travel company ever to be invited to provide the opening keynote address at CES where we will showcase, using our leading-edge technology, offering a new option for our guests for a true breakthrough in unobtrusive, high-touch and personalized travel at scale. 
Furthermore, we launched our new state of the art revenue management system this past year, positioning us well to drive incremental revenue and yield growth over time. The rollout of the system across 6 of our brands is expected to be completed by early 2018. We've already benefited from the sharing of best practices, and we expect this new yield management too to begin to facilitate yield uplift in 2017 and even more so in 2018.
We continue to accelerate progress on our cost containment efforts, delivering $95 million of cost savings in 2016. That's $20 million more than the $75 million included in our original 2016 guidance and bringing the cumulative savings to date to over $190 million. Work continues on our cost-containment efforts that we believe present a multiyear opportunity to further leverage our scale, including another over $75 million of savings planned in 2017.
In addition, we continue to make meaningful progress on our 2020 sustainability goals, focusing on our environmental, safety, labor and social performance. Having already reduced our unit fuel consumption by 28% since initiating the effort, we remain committed to ongoing reduction in air emissions. And just this year, AIDAprima became the first cruise ship in the world to be powered by environmentally friendly, liquefied natural gas. We are committed to continuous improvement in health, environmental, safety and security, which is not only so critical to our premium [ph] to operate, but also to our future success. 
This year, we introduced industry-leading shoreside technology to monitor real-time navigational performance and energy use across our fleet, and we opened our significantly expanded Arison Maritime Center in The Netherlands, delivering state-of-the-art Maritime training through cutting-edge bridge and engine room simulators and curriculum. 
In 2016, we delivered over $5 billion of cash from operations and returned more than half to shareholders, having distributed $1 billion through our annual dividend and investing over $2 billion in our ongoing share repurchase program. 
As a testament to the strength of our operating performance, we were able to accomplish this while also gaining back our A- and A3 credit ratings from S&P and Moody's. And we plan to continue to return excess cash and more to shareholders in 2017 with our credit metrics at the better end of our targeted range.
Now looking forward. There are large addressable markets with low penetration all over the world, including North America. And new markets in Asia where economic growth has raised discretionary income levels, fueling increased demand for vacations.  We are focused on growing our top line and have numerous innovations underway to foster cruise demand in the years ahead. Our booking trends are strong heading into 2017, positioning us well for continued growth in revenue yields. In 2017, we are projecting revenue yields up another 2.5% on top of the tougher comparisons with our prior year success, based on our proven demand creation and yield management efforts. 
At the same time, we will continue to contain cost. In 2017, at the midpoint of our guidance, we expect to deliver an improvement in earnings of $0.43 per share, however, at current rates, that is offset by $0.43 per share impact from fuel incursion. 
We remain committed to achieving increased consideration for cruise vacations and continued investment in the guest experience to create additional consumer demand in excess of measured capacity growth. We remain committed to responsibly containing cost. We remain committed to returning value to shareholders. And despite the unusual occurrence of both fuel and currency working against us at the same time, we remain committed to achieving sustained double-digit return on invested capital within 2 years. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to David.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Arnold. Before I begin, please note, all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 fourth quarter results, then I'll provide s
componenttext:
Thank you, Arnold. Before I begin, please note, all of my references to revenue, ticket prices and cost metrics will be in constant currency unless otherwise stated. 
I'll start today with a summary of our 2016 fourth quarter results, then I'll provide some insights on current booking trends and finish up with some color on our 2017 December guidance. 
Our adjusted EPS for the fourth quarter was $0.67. This was $0.10 above the midpoint of our September guidance. The improvement was almost all operational, driven by a number of factors. $0.04 came from net ticket revenue yields which benefited from stronger pricing on close-in bookings on both sides of the Atlantic, while the remaining $0.06 was an accumulation of a variety of items such as improved fuel consumption and lower depreciation expense. 
Now let's turn to the fourth quarter operating results versus the prior year. Our capacity increased over 4%. The North American brands were up almost 3%, while the European, Australia and Asian brands, also known as our EAA brands, were up over 6%. Our total net revenue yields were up 4.1%. 
Now let's break apart the 2 components of net revenue yield. Net ticket yields were up 5.2%. This increase was driven by our North American brands deployment in the Caribbean and Alaska, as well as our EAA brands deployment in Europe. Then onboard and other yields increased 1.3%, in line with our guidance as our current initiatives continue to pay dividends, while our brands developed new initiatives for 2017 and beyond. Net cruise cost per ALBD excluding fuel were up 1%, which was in line with our September guidance. 
In summary, our fourth quarter adjusted EPS was $0.17 higher than the prior year, driven by higher net revenue yields worth $0.17 and the accretive impact of the stock repurchase program worth $0.04, both of which were partially offset by the unfavorable net impact of lower fuel prices and currency worth $0.04. 
Now let's turn to 2017 booking trends. Since September, both booking volumes and prices for the first 3 quarters of 2017 have been running well ahead of the prior year. At this point in time, for the first 3 quarters of 2017, cumulative advanced bookings are well ahead at considerably higher prices. 
Now let's drill down into the cumulative booked position. First, for our North American brands. Caribbean occupancy is ahead of the prior year at nicely higher prices. For Alaska, both occupancy and prices are well ahead in the prior year. If you want to go to Alaska next summer, I suggest you book early as the remaining inventory is going fast. 
For the seasonal European program, occupancy is in line with the prior year at nicely higher prices. 
Secondly, for our EAA brands. For European deployments, occupancy is well ahead of the prior year at nicely higher prices. For the Caribbean deployments for our EAA brands, occupancy is lower than the prior year at prices that are in line. However, prices on bookings over the last quarter are well ahead of the prior year, clearly an improving trend.
Finally, I want to provide you with some color on 2017. We are forecasting a capacity increase of 2.6%. As Arnold indicated, our booking trends are strong heading into 2017, positioning us well for continued growth in revenue yields. 
For 2017, we are projecting net revenue yields up approximately 2.5% on top of the tougher comparisons from our prior year's success. For the full year, we're expecting to see yield improvement in almost all itineraries. 
Now turning to cost. Net cruise cost without fuel for ALBD are expected to be up approximately 1% for 2017. Broadly speaking, there are 3 major drivers of the cost change. First, our forecast is for 1.5 points of inflation across all of our categories globally. Second, we are planning for an increase in dry dock days from 366 days in 2016 to nearly 450 in 2017, impacting our cost metrics by a half a point. 
As we have indicated on previous conference calls, the dry dock days will vary each year, but probably average around 450 to 475 days given the current size of our fleet. Partially offsetting these 2 items, we are forecasting about 1 point of cost-saving benefit as we further leverage our scale.
Given the volatility of fuel prices and FX rates over the past year, the 2017 year-over-year impact is an unfavorable $0.43 with both fuel and currency moving against us. $0.27 for fuel prices including the impact of fuel derivatives and $0.16 for currency. Putting all these factors together, our adjusted EPS guidance for 2017 is $3.30 to $3.60 versus the $3.45 we did in 2016. 
I'll finish up by sharing with you our current rules of thumb about the impact that currency and fuel prices can have on our 2017 results. To start with, a 10% change in all relevant currencies relative to the U.S. dollar would impact our P&L by approximately $0.34 for the full year and $0.04 for the first quarter. 
For fuel price changes, a 10% change in the current spot price represents a $0.17 impact for the full year and $0.04 for the first quarter. Fuel expense in our guidance is $1.2 billion for the full year. The third rule of thumb relates to our fuel derivative portfolio. A 10% change in Brent would result in a $0.06 change in realized losses on fuel derivatives for the full year and $0.01 for the first quarter. 
And now, I'll turn the call back over to Arnold.

componenttext: Yes. I would say with China, things are looking great. But as you know, it's a B2B business. And -- but we feel very comfortable in China. So we still have additional charters and subcharters to complete and then we have to see the year through. Dave, do you want to...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Overall, Steve, I went through on my notes all the different areas of the globe, both for the North American brands as well as the EAA brands. Arnold touched on China. Remember, China is a late booking market, and as a result of that, it is early. And Australia, which I didn't mention, we are in good shape in Australia as well. It is a small piece of our business, not nearly as large as the other pieces I mentioned. So overall booking trends are good and we're very encouraged.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to kind to stay on how you're thinking about the globe and you're -- and how you're going to -- how you could perform next year, obviously, the outlook on the Caribbean is positive. But we -- despite you and some of your competitors and travel age
componenttext: So just to kind to stay on how you're thinking about the globe and you're -- and how you're going to -- how you could perform next year, obviously, the outlook on the Caribbean is positive. But we -- despite you and some of your competitors and travel agents also all talking about the Caribbean looking positive for next year, there still seems to be concern about some of the supply increases, particularly in the second and third quarter. So I was just wondering if you could address the demand that you're seeing in the Caribbean despite the increased supply and why you're so confident that you'll see growth there next year?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, I guess the industry capacity of all is going to be up 6% next year in the Caribbean and we're going to be up 5%, roughly. But again, we actually have less inventory to book now than we did at this point in time last year. So we feel very stron
componenttext: Sure. Yes, I guess the industry capacity of all is going to be up 6% next year in the Caribbean and we're going to be up 5%, roughly. But again, we actually have less inventory to book now than we did at this point in time last year. So we feel very strong at this point. We still have to get through wave season. It's still early. But things are looking very positive. And all of our indicators are -- our brands have done a great job of creating demand, especially our Carnival brand has continued to outperform in the Caribbean and did again this year. For us, we have added some new capacity, primarily in the form of the Carnival Vista. The ship is spectacular, and she's going to command premium yields and premium booking position and has demonstrated that already. So we have every confidence. The other good news for us is we have such a large base, especially in the Carnival brand, of previous cruise scores, that when we introduce a new ship, because we don't tend to do it every year, we have a large base of previous cruisers set to book with us. So our dependence on new-to-cruise, while we still need new-to-cruise, is not overweighted. So we feel very confident at this point, based on what we see in the Caribbean.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Arnold, while I have you, I thought your comment that you're committed to returning double-digit ROIC within the next 2 years, despite the current FX and fuel headwinds, was impressive. So just wondering if you could help us understand maybe some thin
componenttext: And Arnold, while I have you, I thought your comment that you're committed to returning double-digit ROIC within the next 2 years, despite the current FX and fuel headwinds, was impressive. So just wondering if you could help us understand maybe some things that you would be doing beyond your already identified cost savings to ensure that goal?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, absolutely. I think first of all, it is a headwind to have, obviously, currency and fuel both move against you at the same time, which has rarely if ever happened before and is happening with a pretty significant impact, obviously. Having said th
componenttext: Yes. No, absolutely. I think first of all, it is a headwind to have, obviously, currency and fuel both move against you at the same time, which has rarely if ever happened before and is happening with a pretty significant impact, obviously. Having said that, we also have a lot of momentum on a number of fronts, not just on cost and payments, but in driving yield and then with some small capacity addition that helps us as well. But we have multiple paths all along, when we declare double-digit, fuel prices were much higher than they were the last few years. And we are now looking at next year at basically being on balance net of fuel and currency where we were when we declared double-digit return on invested capital. So we have no reason to back off from that goal. We have multiple pathways, including, obviously, increased yields. But also in terms of managing more efficiently. Then all the tools we have in place. We have new management tool in place that will begin to kick in and we'll see the full effect on about half of our brands by 2018. We've done a lot of work in -- the brands have in creating additional demand. We have a lot more cruise scores in our base of previous cruise scores. We have much more collaboration and coordination communication across our brands to not only contain cost to help us manage cost, as you see reflected in the cost guidance, but also, frankly, to share best practices and drive yield further. So we have a number of things in place. We have a lot of momentum. And we are committed and we will deliver.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, housekeeping, Beth. I was just -- Beth, can you give us the D&A and interest expense guidance for the first quarter of '17 and the full year of 2017 and the quarterly capacity increases?
componenttext: And then just finally, housekeeping, Beth. I was just -- Beth, can you give us the D&A and interest expense guidance for the first quarter of '17 and the full year of 2017 and the quarterly capacity increases?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Interest is running about $50 million a quarter, $200 million for the year, that's net of capitalized, net of income. Depreciation is running $450 million in the first quarter, $1,850,000,000 for the year. And quarterly -- derivatives are running $47 mill
componenttext: Interest is running about $50 million a quarter, $200 million for the year, that's net of capitalized, net of income. Depreciation is running $450 million in the first quarter, $1,850,000,000 for the year. And quarterly -- derivatives are running $47 million in the first quarter, $185 million for the year. That's the realized derivatives. And the quarterly capacity projections are 4% for the first quarter, 3.6% for the second, 1.2% for the third and 2.5 -- 2% even for the fourth quarter, 2.5% on the year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

And then just again sort of recap and your thought process on the EAA brands looking into the Caribbean.

componenttext: Overall, the comment, if you break it down, it's very similar for both markets as I mentioned for the year. Occupancy is well ahead and the prices are nicely higher for both the Med as well as in Northern Europe for the EAA brands.

componenttext: At this point in time for the North American brands, the Med, with the reduced occupancy in the Med, the pricing in the Med seems to be doing much better than in Northern Europe in terms of being up more than Northern Europe.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then gentlemen, just given your overall commentary about the higher book to occupancy and pricing, would -- should we anticipate -- granted that wave is important, but should we anticipate that you obviously won't need as much bookings dur
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then gentlemen, just given your overall commentary about the higher book to occupancy and pricing, would -- should we anticipate -- granted that wave is important, but should we anticipate that you obviously won't need as much bookings during wave on a year-over-year basis, all else equal, in the same trajectory at this point?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have less to sell, as Arnold indicated, than we did at this time last year despite the capacity increase. So clearly, it's a zero-sum game, and we can only book so much. We only have so much capacity, so we do need less during wave in the remaind
componenttext: Well, we have less to sell, as Arnold indicated, than we did at this time last year despite the capacity increase. So clearly, it's a zero-sum game, and we can only book so much. We only have so much capacity, so we do need less during wave in the remainder of the year for 2017 and we'll be looking to push pricing up and try to continue to do better than our guidance.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, I know it's less than 24 hours, but it's been kind of quiet, thankfully, on the terrorist incidents front. But the incident yesterday in Germany, less than 24 hours, just any very early feedback indications from that? I know it kind
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, I know it's less than 24 hours, but it's been kind of quiet, thankfully, on the terrorist incidents front. But the incident yesterday in Germany, less than 24 hours, just any very early feedback indications from that? I know it kind of ebbs flow for a week after an event, but any thoughts there?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just general comments. We had a couple of incidents, I guess, the German situation and the situation in Turkey. But the reality is that we've weathered those storms for the past several years. And as long as the world continues in the general state it is,
componenttext: Just general comments. We had a couple of incidents, I guess, the German situation and the situation in Turkey. But the reality is that we've weathered those storms for the past several years. And as long as the world continues in the general state it is, people have chosen to continue to travel. And as long as people travel, we're going to be in good shape. If things were ever to, obviously, get exacerbated and people are afraid to travel, then we'll have a challenge. But that has not happened in recent times with all the various incidents that have occurred, and so we have no reason, at this point in time, to have a higher level of concern than normal.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus on next year's free cash flow. The first question is, is there any repurchase of shares baked into your 2017 earnings guidance? And is there any, or to what degree have you built in any uplift from your new revenue management system into
componenttext: I wanted to focus on next year's free cash flow. The first question is, is there any repurchase of shares baked into your 2017 earnings guidance? And is there any, or to what degree have you built in any uplift from your new revenue management system into the 2017 guidance?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, concerning stock repurchase, right now we have about $400 million remaining on the current amount we have designated for that. We will continue to buy back on an opportunistic basis and we'll see if we get through that amount over the next period of
componenttext: Okay, concerning stock repurchase, right now we have about $400 million remaining on the current amount we have designated for that. We will continue to buy back on an opportunistic basis and we'll see if we get through that amount over the next period of time, then the board will revisit to see what would be the next step, because this is clearly a board decision. So that's the basic story on that. We do it opportunistically, so we don't have a plan per se in terms of factoring it into guidance. What was the second part of your question?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I wanted to see if the new revenue management system was also baked into your yield guidance for next year?
componenttext: Well, I wanted to see if the new revenue management system was also baked into your yield guidance for next year?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is. We only have about 30% of the inventory for the 6 brands that have the new tool currently, being managed, because obviously, we're way ahead on bookings, so it can only impact so much of '17. But by '18, we'll have a full impact for the invent
componenttext: Yes, it is. We only have about 30% of the inventory for the 6 brands that have the new tool currently, being managed, because obviously, we're way ahead on bookings, so it can only impact so much of '17. But by '18, we'll have a full impact for the inventory in those 6 brands. But we already benefited somewhat from the sharing of best practices across the brands and the development of the tool and the sharing of what they do. So the answer is yes, it is factored in as one of many factors that contribute to yield.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Harry, I would add -- go ahead.
componenttext: And Harry, I would add -- go ahead.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, go ahead. Sorry, David.
componenttext: Yes, go ahead. Sorry, David.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I was going to say you asked about cash flow for 2017. At the midpoint of our guidance, the cash flow from operations should be close to the $5 billion mark. We do have about $3 billion in CapEx for 2017, so we do have roughly $2 billion of free cash
componenttext: Oh, I was going to say you asked about cash flow for 2017. At the midpoint of our guidance, the cash flow from operations should be close to the $5 billion mark. We do have about $3 billion in CapEx for 2017, so we do have roughly $2 billion of free cash flow. Our existing dividend is close to $1 billion. So we do have some extra money over and above the dividend to return to shareholders, as well as we have some room in our credit metrics to continue to potentially increase debt and return free cash flow and more to shareholders.

componenttext: That's going to be a board decision. As I mentioned, we have about $400 million left, and we'll have opportunity to continue to buy as we have in the past.
